From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Jul  1 00:00:02 2003

Subject: [PLUG] How to copy entire web site in Linux?
In-Reply-To: <03062922420601.25629@gate>

On Sun, 29 Jun 2003, Alex Daniloff wrote:
> I'm looking for the application or solution on how to copy the entire
> website on a hard drive with all pages, graphics and with preservation
> of all links.

wget -r -k -p

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Tue Jul  1 01:37:04 2003
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Tue Jul  1 01:37:04 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ANNOUNCEMENT: July PLUG Meeting
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306282055100.2494-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>

                         MEETING ANNOUNCEMENT

                    The Portland Linux/Unix Group
                              will meet
                      7 PM Thursday July 3, 2003
                                  at
                      Portland State University
                                in the
                        Smith Memorial Center
                               Room 298
                       On the block bounded by
   SW Montgomery, SW Broadway (7th), SW Harrison, and SW Park (9th)


      **********************************************************

                             PRESENTATION

                             An Overview
                                of the
                     Open Source Development Lab

                                  by

                          Timothy D. Witham
                          <wookie at osdl.org>

      The Open Source Development Lab (www.osdl.org) is an industry
      sponsored lab with data centers in Portland, Oregon and
      Yokohama, Japan.  The lab sponsors key industry projects,
      including industry initiatives to enhance Linux for use in
      corporate data centers (Data Center Linux) and in
      telecommunications networks (Carrier Grade Linux).
      Timothy D. Witham is the lab's director.  He will give a
      general overview of the lab and it's activities and what
      it can offer to Open Source developers.  I suppose he
      will also talk about Linus Torvalds' decision to take a
      position with the lab.

      **********************************************************

          Agenda:

              7:00 - 7:30  Business
                   We will discuss the status of our ongoing projects
                   including the monthly hands on clinics, PLUG for
                   Education, etc.

              7:30 - 8:30  Presentation

                   See above

              9:00 - ...  Beer
                                  The Lucky Labrador Brewing Company
                                  915 SE Hawthorne



                                          David Mandel
                                          Chief Activist
                                          Portland Linux/Unix Group
                                          560 SE Alexander
                                          Corvallis, Oregon 97333
                                          (541) 730-5285 cell
                                          dmandel at pdxLinux.org


          P.S.  The Mid Willamette Valley Linux Users Group meets at
                Oregon State University (generally Owen Hall room 101)
                on the first Tuesday of the month.
                See http://www.mwvlug.org/ for details.

          P.S.  The Eugene Linux Users Group meets regularly.
                See http://www.euglug.org for details.

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Tue Jul  1 02:00:02 2003
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Tue Jul  1 02:00:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Problems using X with ssh from one particular site.
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306282057180.2494-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>

I'm having a bit of a problem describing my problem, but here goes ...

I have a couple computers in Vancouver and one in Corvallis, which is
access remotely using something like:

                  ssh -X Vancouver-1
                  ssh -X Vancouver-2
                  ssh -X Corvallis

This has always worked.  No matter where I happen to be, given a Linux
machine and internet access, I seem to be able to access the three
machines.  This access includes the ability to run X applications like
xclock, emacs, and gimp over the net.

NOW THE PROBLEM:  I was at a company in Springfield today.  I couldn't
find a Linux machine, but I booted a Knoppix CD on one of their Windows
machines and everything looked fine, except I was able to access
Vancouver-1, Vancouver-2, and Corvallis using ssh - BUT	I COULDN'T
RUN X APPLICATIONS.  Everytime I tryed to start one, I got a message
about not being able to access the X server.  Anyone know why I'm
having this problem?  The display variable looks reasonable.  I would
say that the firewall is blocking me, but X should be being tunneled
thru ssh and ssh is working fine; so I don't see how this could be
causing the problem.

                                          Sincerely,
                                          David Mandel
                                          Chief Activist
                                          Portland Linux/Unix Group
                                          560 SE Alexander
                                          Corvallis, Oregon 97333
                                          (541) 730-5285 cell

attempting to learn java, and unfortunately java proggies appear at the 
top of the screen with the title bar off the screen.  Using 
Gnome/Enlightenment works fine, but this is an old, slow machine and I 
don't like the overhead (I know, it's pointless to run java apps on a 
machine this slow, but it's the only thing I've got to learn on).  

Is there anything I can do to force java proggies to appear in a more 
normal position under xfce?  Incidently, the sawmill window manager has 
the same #&@$ing problem.

Unfortunately the case is locked by the IT staff, so I've just 
disabled the bell under vim and bash, which seems to cover everything so
far.

The good news is apparently newer versions of cygwin use the audio card 
for a bell by default instead.

Btw, is it true that back in the day the computer would actually ring a bell 
(like a firebell?) when you made a mistake at the terminal? (No wonder people 
used to be afraid of computers!)

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Tue Jul  1 05:41:02 2003
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler Creelan)
Date: Tue Jul  1 05:41:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] mp3 players -- separate from the system
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306302350380.3578@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306301506270.9980-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> <1057023256.14824.27.camel@localhost.localdomain> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0306302350380.3578@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <20030701124037.GB19816@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Jeme wrote regarding mp3 players:

> Not to mention the fragility and wastefullness of those (kinda) big
> plastic disks.  (Not that I think Rich thinks twice about disposable
> anything.)

Some of them use mini-CDs, which make them pocket-sized, of course
those disks probably have less storage.

I understand the Neuros (http://open.neurosaudio.com) is the only mp3 
player that officially supports linux, with plans for FreeBSD. They've 
also contracted with Xiph.org to support Ogg, with beta firmware 
available here:

http://www.xiph.org/neurosetta/

All software used for Neuros is also available under a BSD-style 
license, according to their social contract:

http://open.neurosaudio.com/archives/000003.html

hth,

TFC

From holger at selover.net  Tue Jul  1 09:17:02 2003
From: holger at selover.net (Holger Stephan)
Date: Tue Jul  1 09:17:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Java applications appearing at edge of screen w/xfce
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0307010204140.13939-100000@ns1.billmercer.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0307010204140.13939-100000@ns1.billmercer.com>
Message-ID: <1057076212.16376.895.camel@halo>

Bill,

That'll do it in your JFrame class: 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    public void show()
    {
        java.awt.Dimension screenSize =
java.awt.Toolkit.getDefaultToolkit().getScreenSize();
        java.awt.Dimension windowSize = this.getSize();
        if (windowSize.height > screenSize.height)
            windowSize.height = screenSize.height;

        if (windowSize.width > screenSize.width)
            windowSize.width = screenSize.width;

        this.setLocation(
            (screenSize.width - windowSize.width) / 2,
            (screenSize.height - windowSize.height) / 2);
    }
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Do you know that there is a Java user group in Portland:
http://pjug.org/? The guys on the mailing list are pretty quick with
their answers.

Holger (otherwise glad to be able to give this group something back)

From m at pdxlug.org  Tue Jul  1 09:32:01 2003
From: m at pdxlug.org (Matt Alexander)
Date: Tue Jul  1 09:32:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] need regex help
Message-ID: <33056.68.107.223.201.1057077076.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>

I'm parsing HTML with Perl and I'm trying to develop a regular expression
to handle an unknown number of text fields between <SPAN> tags.  I want to
then combine all the text fields into one variable.  Here's what I have so
far:

($text) = /((<SPAN.*?>((.*)(<SPAN.*?>|<\/SPAN.*?>)))+?)/;

I'm hoping to then use regex backreferences somehow to pull out the fields
between the <SPAN> tags.

Any suggestions?
Thanks,
~M

From danh at fork.com  Tue Jul  1 09:57:02 2003
From: danh at fork.com (Dan Haskell)
Date: Tue Jul  1 09:57:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] [PDXLUG July 01, 2003 Meeting Announcement]
In-Reply-To: <1252.192.168.1.251.1057027090.squirrel@webmail.tearitalldown.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0307010924360.16353-100000@cohiba.fork.com>


On Mon, 30 Jun 2003, Robby Russell wrote:

> Why? Feel free to join the list and bring up that suggestion...but I doubt
> that it'll hold much ground.
> 
> We changed our meetings to be the first tuesday of the month after our
> first meeting which conflicted with PLUGs. It was a group vote to do so,
> out of courtesy of those who are involved in both groups.

That's exactly what I'm asking for here - courtesy for those involved in
both groups. As for the "why" go back and read the posting you're
responding to.

> We've been in existance for about 6 months now, have about 100
> subscribers, several sponsors, print material, our own bootable distro, a
> large media library, our highly active irc channel, etc, etc...
> 
> Why doesn't PLUG change it's name?

Hmmmm. Because PLUG has had that name for close to ten years? You guys
split off because you wanted to differentiate yourselves from PLUG - and
then chose the same name, a very similar domain name, and the same meeting
time. You're failing to differentiate.

> Are you implying that the average person who looks up Portland Linux User
> Group shouldn't see our name towards the top of the list as well?
> 
> If Linux has taught me/us one thing about our world...it's choice. Give
> people a choice.

So give them a clear choice - don't muddy the waters.

> We're not trying to take away PLUG subscribers...and this isn't a
> competition. Is it wrong to have more than 1 group in town? Is it wrong to
> have more than 3 in town? Who cares.

If you read my posting, you'll see I never complained about your choice to
start your own group. You're free to have your own group and run it the
way you please. My only complaint is with the confusion you have created
by using our old name, picking a similar domain name, etc. When you do
that sort of thing, you start impacting the function of *our* group. We
have worked hard to establish a sort of name-brand-familiarity, which you
are diluting.

[snip]
> Can I suggest that you change your linux/Unix group to :
> The REAL Portland Linux/Unix Group
[snip]

Once again, we have had the name for close to ten years. If you want to
offer people choice, give them choice - not confusion. If you want to
differentiate yourselves from PLUG - do so. The current situation benefits
no one.

The whole thing is starting to sound like it's straight out of a
Monty Python movie: "Portland Linux/Unix Group? Cawk! We're the Portland
Linux User's Group!"

Dan

I don't know how to do it under cygwin specifically but in win2K you can
shut it off for the entire machine by disabling it under the device
manager, does NT have a device manager?  (it's been about 4 years since
I've been on an NT box)

Well that's too good to pass up. But Slug.org,net,com were all taken so 
I've decided (in the spirit of Monty Python) to start another splinter 
faction: the Stumptown Linux Users Group of Oregon at SLUGO.net. The 
SLUGO group will absolutely refuse to take ourselves too seriously. 
(come on guys, we're supposed to be having fun right?) If anyone has an 
interest in wasting time on a whimsical diversion starting sometime in 
August, let me know (off list is fine).

I actually think there are useful reasons to have more than one Linux 
group in Portland. I have to agree with Dan though, I'm not clear on the 
philosophical distintions between the existing PLUGs. That said, the new 
PdxLug folks do seem to be doing some interesting projects. As I see it, 
that's one of the advantages to having several smaller groups instead of 
one monolithic group - the freedom to take initiative and experiment.

Grand Poobah of Slugo.net

From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Tue Jul  1 12:20:03 2003
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: Tue Jul  1 12:20:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Problems using X with ssh from one particular site.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306282057180.2494-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306282057180.2494-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>
Message-ID: <1057087118.2467.27.camel@kat.zotnet.com>

Most of this times you cannot X it is due to DNS/IP issues.  X likes to
know which machine is what.

Also some version ssh require keys not passwords, it gets sticky.

The best way to test is run X on the server with the debug flag on a
higher port (2222).  The following will work, but will die after the
first ssh connection goes away.

        sshd -d -p 2222

Then run on the knopix CD.

        ssh -p 2222 -v -X Vancouver-1

Make sure you are not root for the ssh connection.

You may see a X Forwarding being denied message right there or some
other message.

>From there you can play with "xauth, list" and see what is being set up.

I have things like

        mp.zotnet.com:14  MIT-MAGIC-COOKIE-1  e7a5263xxxxxxae73dxxxxxxxxb
        mp.zotnet.com/unix:14  MIT-MAGIC-COOKIE-1  e7a52633xxxxxxxxae73xxxxxxxb


BTW "xlogo" is a small way to test X settings.


Other places to check:  /etc/ssh/sshd_config (or what ever)

#X11Forwarding no
X11Forwarding yes
#X11DisplayOffset 10
#X11UseLocalhost yes


On Sat, 2003-06-28 at 21:20, David Mandel wrote:
> I'm having a bit of a problem describing my problem, but here goes ...
> 
> I have a couple computers in Vancouver and one in Corvallis, which is
> access remotely using something like:
> 
>                   ssh -X Vancouver-1
>                   ssh -X Vancouver-2
>                   ssh -X Corvallis
> 
> This has always worked.  No matter where I happen to be, given a Linux
> machine and internet access, I seem to be able to access the three
> machines.  This access includes the ability to run X applications like
> xclock, emacs, and gimp over the net.
> 
> NOW THE PROBLEM:  I was at a company in Springfield today.  I couldn't
> find a Linux machine, but I booted a Knoppix CD on one of their Windows
> machines and everything looked fine, except I was able to access
> Vancouver-1, Vancouver-2, and Corvallis using ssh - BUT	I COULDN'T
> RUN X APPLICATIONS.  Everytime I tryed to start one, I got a message
> about not being able to access the X server.  Anyone know why I'm
> having this problem?  The display variable looks reasonable.  I would
> say that the firewall is blocking me, but X should be being tunneled
> thru ssh and ssh is working fine; so I don't see how this could be
> causing the problem.

On Tue, 1 Jul 2003, Joshua Hoblitt wrote:

> links to local movie listings - including the McWorldDomination's pages

Something to consider when dealing with OMSI:

They had promised to provide a drop for a wireless connection
for KBOO radio in order to facilitate a remote broadcast for
the Waterfront Blues Festival during the July 4th Weekend.

At the last moment, they reneged. Something about the director
of technology saying that it 'was too much work'. All they promised
to do was to provide a network drop (RJ-45) into their backbone.
(During a holiday weekend with load would be light; as well as
a community organization supporting another community organization).

These guys can be a little slipery.

Mark




From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Jul  1 15:11:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue Jul  1 15:11:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] [PDXLUG July 01, 2003 Meeting Announcement]
In-Reply-To: <3F01DB91.8010904@hevanet.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306301838190.10216-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
 <3F01DB91.8010904@hevanet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0307011328310.13601@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Tue, 1 Jul 2003, david pool wrote:
> I actually think there are useful reasons to have more than one Linux
> group in Portland. I have to agree with Dan though, I'm not clear on the
> philosophical distintions between the existing PLUGs. That said, the new
> PdxLug folks do seem to be doing some interesting projects. As I see it,
> that's one of the advantages to having several smaller groups instead of
> one monolithic group - the freedom to take initiative and experiment.

There's a small flaw in your reasoning here, David, if I may attempt to
elucidate.

PLUG (as we know it) is not a formal organization with any inhibiting
structures or hierarchy that prevents a person from going out and doing
whatever they feel needs doing to improve teh community.  It may be that
this mailing list is unpleasant for some people and they want a list that
is more limited in scope or moderated for content or whatever they like
adn they can set up a mail server and do so or even talk to someone with
access to the plug server and set up the list right here alongside this
one.

If your organizations are unstructured and open, there is no meaning to
"forking" or what have you.  I honestly see the PDX LUG split as an ego
problem where people want to make their own name for themselves.  It's ALL
about the name and not at all about the community.

J.

    jeme at brelin.net

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Jul  1 15:21:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue Jul  1 15:21:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OT - Spoof Plural?
In-Reply-To: <05AD3C7EEA42D311809300902785AC8A0559C608@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>
References: <05AD3C7EEA42D311809300902785AC8A0559C608@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0307011520420.13601@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Mon, 30 Jun 2003, Daggett, Steve wrote:
>   The Verbix Conjugator says: "spoofs" or "spoofed".
>
> http://www.verbix.com/webverbix/go.asp?T1=spoof&D1=20&H1=120&imageField.x=10
> &imageField.y=12
>
>   It also says: "Warning! The verb you entered does not exist in Verbix
> verb database. The conjugations may not be accurate.".

In that context, "spoofs" would be a present-tense conjugation of the verb
"spoof".  It's not a pluralization of the singular noun "spoof".

In other words, "to spoof" not "a spoof".

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org

From jhoblitt at ifa.hawaii.edu  Tue Jul  1 15:35:02 2003

From dpool at hevanet.com  Tue Jul  1 15:46:02 2003
From: dpool at hevanet.com (david pool)
Date: Tue Jul  1 15:46:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] [PDXLUG July 01, 2003 Meeting Announcement]
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306301838190.10216-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> <3F01DB91.8010904@hevanet.com> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0307011328310.13601@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <3F020F0B.9030807@hevanet.com>

Jeme A Brelin wrote:

>There's a small flaw in your reasoning here, David, if I may attempt to
>elucidate.
>
>PLUG (as we know it) is not a formal organization with any inhibiting
>structures or hierarchy that prevents a person from going out and doing
>whatever they feel needs doing to improve teh community.  
>

Hm. I suppose technically this is true. If I wanted to do fundraising, 
for example, I could say that I'm a member of the PLUG and start 
soliciting people and organizations. I could decide to store the funds 
in my own name and dedicate them to purchasing beer at spontaneous 
gatherings (ie when I'm thirsty).

On the other hand, some people, like David Mandel, might object on the 
basis that he gets thirsty too, and it's not fair that he's not getting 
any beer.

The fact that the PLUG lacks formal organization, makes it unclear on 
how to get agreement on my idea for a meeting fund. It's easier to set 
up SLUGO and cleanly seperate who's funding my next round. Even better, 
at SLUGO, we've got a clear decision criteria: Majority rule (and I'm 
the only one who can vote).

d

Book News
================================================
Review books are available--email me for a copy.

***Please include the book order number on your requests.

Let me know if you need your books by a certain date.
Allow at least four weeks for shipping.
Send or email me copies of your newsletters and book reviews.

Don't forget, your members get 20% off any O'Reilly book they purchase
directly from O'Reilly. Just use code DSUG when ordering.
http://www.oreilly.com/

***Group purchases with better discounts are available***
Please let me know if you are interested.

Press releases are available on our press page:
http://press.oreilly.com/

***Linux in a Nutshell, 4th Edition
Order Number: 4826
"Linux in a Nutshell, 4th Edition" is an essential desktop reference
for the commands that Linux users need every day. The book covers all
substantial user, programming, administration, and networking commands
for the most common Linux distributions. It's several quick references
rolled into one: sed, gawk, RCS, CVS, vi, Emacs, bash, tcsh, regular
expressions, package management, bootloaders, and desktop environments
are all covered, along with core command-line utilities. You get it all
in this concise and comprehensive volume.
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/linuxnut4/

Chapter 5, "Red Hat and Debian Package Managers," is available online:
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/linuxnut4/chapter/index.html


***Secure Coding: Principles & Practices
Order Number: 2424
Nearly all attacks on computer systems have one fundamental cause:
insecure code. Flaws in design, implementation, testing, and operations
allow all too easy access for attackers. This book looks at the problem
of bad code in a new way. Packed with advice based on decades of
experience in computer security, "Secure Coding" explains why so much
code today is filled with vulnerabilities, and tells readers what they
must do to avoid exploitation by attackers.
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/securecdng/

Chapter 1, "No Straight Thing," is available online:
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/securecdng/chapter/index.html


***Perl 6 Essentials
Order Number: 4990
"Perl 6 Essentials" is the first book to offer a peek into the next
major version of the Perl language. It covers the development of Perl 6
syntax as well as Parrot, the language-independent interpreter
developed as part of the Perl 6 design strategy. This book is essential
reading for anyone interested in the future of Perl. It will satisfy
your curiosity and show you how changes in the language will make Perl
more powerful and easier to use.
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/perl6es/

Chapter 1, "Project Overview," is available online:
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/perl6es/chapter/index.html


***Tomcat: The Definitive Guide
Order Number: 3188
"Tomcat: The Definitive Guide" offers something for everyone who uses
Tomcat, from system and network administrators who will find detailed
instructions on installation, configuration, and maintenance to
seasoned enterprise Java developers who will have a complete reference
for setting up, running, and using this powerful software. The book
covers all major platforms, contains details on Tomcat configuration
files, and even has a quick-start guide to get developers up and
running with Java servlets and JavaServer Pages
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/tomcat/

Chapter 6, "Tomcat Security," is available online:
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/tomcat/chapter/index.html


***Google Pocket Guide
Order Number: 5504
"Google Pocket Guide" unleashes the power behind that blinking curser
by delivering a thorough, concise tour of Google's features. You'll
find practical examples to inspire going beyond the basic keyword
search; secrets for constructing more powerful queries using Google's
special syntax; and tips on understanding and refining the results
Google provides. Crafted from our best-selling "Google Hacks" title,
"Google Pocket Guide" provides exactly the information you need to make
your searches faster and more effective.
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/googlepg/

Sample Excerpts on "Google Basics," "Froogle," and "Consulting the
Dictionary" are available online:
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/googlepg/chapter/index.html

Safari News
================================================
***"Go On Safari" Tip of the Week Winner--Tony King, Chicago.pm
"I just signed-up for Safari a couple of days ago as they are having a
free 14-day trial offer. I've been reviewing it for my office and it's
a very good reference tool. While I wouldn't want to read a whole book
online, it beats the price of having to purchase those books
individually and having that many technical books at the click of a
mouse can't be beat."

Your group can also participate in this introductory program just for
user group members. To "Go on Safari," any of your members who sign up
for our Safari 14-day free trial can send comments on their
experiences, or tips and tricks for how they used Safari  (it only
needs to be 2 sentences long, but it may be longer) to
safari_talk at oreilly.com.
(Please include your UG name in the email.)

Every week someone will be chosen from the tips or comments submitted
to receive fun stuff from O'Reilly (T-shirts, book bags, or other
surprises). If a member of your user group is selected, your group
receives free gifts, too. Whatever the individual member receives, your
UG will get one, too, to give away at your next meeting, or use however
you see fit. Recipients--and their comments--will be announced in the
User Group Newsletter.

**Please use this special UG URL to sign up for the 14-day trial**
http://www.oreilly.com/safari/ug

For more information on Safari:
http://safari.oreilly.com/

***Top Ten Digital Video Tips
Unless the guy next door happens to be Steven Soderbergh, you'll
probably have a hard time getting good advice about how to master your
DV camcorder. Yes, you can pore over each dryly composed paragraph in
your multilanguage owner's manual, but chances are all that will
improve is your French. Instead, check out these ten handy tips that
will transform your ho-hum footage into compelling video.
http://www.macdevcenter.com/pub/a/mac/2003/06/13/dv_tips.html

Guide"

***Join the Linux Users' Group of Davis for a Special Meeting,
Davis, CA--July 21
Seth David Schoen, Electronic Frontier Foundation, will be speaking
about "The Empire Strikes Back: Constraining Free Software
Development." He will review the story of the DVD Wars, the broader
debates over copyright policy, and current regulatory initiatives. He
will also discuss new technologies such as software-defined radio and
trusted computing, and emphasize that free software's future is far
from assured.
http://www.lugod.org/meeting/upcoming/

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Tue Jul  1 17:04:02 2003
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Tue Jul  1 17:04:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Comcast complaint
In-Reply-To: <1056981890.5189.5.camel@obelisk.spek.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306270202090.6475-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>

On 30 Jun 2003, Brent Rieck wrote:

> Hello,
>   Has anybody seen the manual switch instructions yet?
> connect.comcast.net bounces me to a non-existent server
> (online.comcast.net).
>
> thanks,
> Brent

I don't use attbi or comcast for anything except my internet
connection.  (I use DavidMandel.com, pdxLinux.org, etc for
web sites and mail.  The people (person) owning these domains
haven't ever told me that I will have to change my email address,
unlike most of the "real" ISP routinely do.)

On the other hand, I can't let this go by without complaining about
Comcast.  I just ordered Comcast in a new location.  Their tech
came and sort of installed things.  I mean he left before making
sure anything worked.  He didn't even have a laptop so he could
register the connection for the customer and the registration process
required an MS Windows PC.  I finally dug up a PC running Windows 2000
and tryed to run the install program.  Errors!! Errors!! Errors!!
Well, I did get it to run and got everything working in fairly short
order.  But still, I wasn't totally happy about the experience.
A less experienced user could have had real problems.

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Jul  1 17:34:01 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue Jul  1 17:34:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] [PDXLUG July 01, 2003 Meeting Announcement]
In-Reply-To: <3F020F0B.9030807@hevanet.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306301838190.10216-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
 <3F01DB91.8010904@hevanet.com> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0307011328310.13601@shaft.bitmine.net>
 <3F020F0B.9030807@hevanet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0307011724120.17614@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Tue, 1 Jul 2003, david pool wrote:
> Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> >PLUG (as we know it) is not a formal organization with any inhibiting
> >structures or hierarchy that prevents a person from going out and doing
> >whatever they feel needs doing to improve the community.
>
> Hm. I suppose technically this is true. If I wanted to do fundraising,
> for example, I could say that I'm a member of the PLUG and start
> soliciting people and organizations. I could decide to store the funds
> in my own name and dedicate them to purchasing beer at spontaneous
> gatherings (ie when I'm thirsty).

Right.  Nothing that PLUG IS prevents you from doing this.  There are
things, however, that PLUG IS NOT that do.

> On the other hand, some people, like David Mandel, might object on the
> basis that he gets thirsty too, and it's not fair that he's not getting
> any beer.

And other people, particularly the ones who gave you money, might wonder
why you're using a wholly informal organization as a guise for procuring
beer money.

> The fact that the PLUG lacks formal organization, makes it unclear on
> how to get agreement on my idea for a meeting fund.

You're talking about a centralized structure for collecting and
disseminating funds in the name of PLUG.  Whenever you start to talk about
informal structure people ALWAYS bring up the idea of fund raising.

The simple fact is that an organization like PLUG has no need for
fundraising.  There are certain things that are done for the sake of PLUG
that cost a little money, but all of those can be managed by the voluntary
and direct contribution of PLUG members to the problem.  The
accountability remains with those who do the work, not some Treasurer,
Minister, President, or Board.  PLUG is not an organization that needs
money.  There are no paychecks to sign and no grand headquarters to
maintain.  Hence, PLUG is not an organization that needs formal structure.

The same is true for the PDXLUG.  That group doesn't need or want a formal
structure (though some felt it was necessary to write a mission
statement... even though there's no process for determining whether a
particular action is within that mission which makes the whole process of
writing such a thing and parading it around nothing more than ego
masturbation).  They can't set up a real fund any more than PLUG can.

I don't see how your statement relates to the argument that nothing PDXLUG
was created to do needed the creation of PDXLUG to do.

> It's easier to set up SLUGO and cleanly seperate who's funding my next
> round. Even better, at SLUGO, we've got a clear decision criteria:
> Majority rule (and I'm the only one who can vote).

Um, so SLUGO is just David.  I don't really do self-assigned nicknames.

-Slick.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org



From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Tue Jul  1 18:17:02 2003
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler Creelan)
Date: Tue Jul  1 18:17:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Comcast complaint
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306270202090.6475-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>
References: <1056981890.5189.5.camel@obelisk.spek.org> <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306270202090.6475-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>
Message-ID: <20030702011605.GA22630@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

David Mandel observed:

> I just ordered Comcast in a new location.  Their tech
> came and sort of installed things.  I mean he left before making
> sure anything worked.  He didn't even have a laptop so he could
> register the connection for the customer and the registration process
> required an MS Windows PC.  I finally dug up a PC running Windows 2000
> and tryed to run the install program.  Errors!! Errors!! Errors!!
[..]
> A less experienced user could have had real problems.

The same thing happened to me and I was rather miffed. I'd even set up
a pc running Win2k for him to test the connection with. When I 
tried the installer I got weird errors too, until finally on my second
call to tech support they told me the installation required the Windows 
128-bit encryption pack (?) and I had to get it from a friend, it wasn't
on the CD.

Furthermore the installation program didn't work at all anyway, because the
registration server it pointed to was decommissioned, so I had to just 
manually type in the new server address. If only they'd just given me the
address on a card to begin with I would have done everything under linux 
with mozilla. :P

TFC

In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0307011514190.13601@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306282057180.2494-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>

Message-ID: <1057120851.2464.52.camel@kat.zotnet.com>

On Tue, 2003-07-01 at 15:15, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> On Sat, 28 Jun 2003, David Mandel wrote:
> > I COULDN'T RUN X APPLICATIONS.  Everytime I tryed to start one, I got a
> > message about not being able to access the X server.  Anyone know why
> > I'm having this problem?  The display variable looks reasonable.
> 
> This is simple and obvious, but sometimes unstated assumptions are the
> root cause.
> 
> xhost +?
> 
> J.

Ahhhhh!  This is very insecure!

X over ssh uses xauth/magic cookies and a fake display (tunneled).

Also since it works from some machines and not others, it is likely
DNS/IP, or a setting on passwords/keys.

-- 
Zot O'Connor

http://www.WhiteKnightHackers.com

CRIME meeting Tuesday July 8, 2003 @ 10AM @ Verizon

Speakers: Professors Sarah Mocas and Mark Morrissey, Computer Science Department, Portland State University

Topic:  ?Current Thoughts in Digital Forensic Education"

Sarah will talk about current research in Digital Forensics and Mark
will follow with how PSU is re-designing the digital forensics
course-and will solicit input on the course.


This will be even more interactive than usual, since both Sarah and Mark
are seeking input on issues and content for courses and programs.



C.R.I.M.E. meets in the Verizon (Airtouch) Cellular building (Take I-5
South to Carmen Drive. The building is on the West side [Tigard side] of
the Freeway). The meeting room is in the back of the building. The talk
begins at 10:00 a.m.The street address is 15575 Sequoia Pkwy, Tigard. 
Lunch generally follows the meeting.

From alan at clueserver.org  Tue Jul  1 23:05:03 2003
From: alan at clueserver.org (alan)
Date: Tue Jul  1 23:05:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Problems using X with ssh from one particular site.
In-Reply-To: <1057120851.2464.52.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0307011408200.15779-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>

Some implementations of ssh have x forwarding turned off.  Make sure that 
you are starting ssh with the proper command line options to override this 
behaviour.

From dpool at hevanet.com  Wed Jul  2 07:44:02 2003
From: dpool at hevanet.com (david pool)
Date: Wed Jul  2 07:44:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] [PDXLUG July 01, 2003 Meeting Announcement]
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0306301838190.10216-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>	<3F01DB91.8010904@hevanet.com>	<Pine.LNX.4.52.0307011328310.13601@shaft.bitmine.net>	<3F020F0B.9030807@hevanet.com>	<Pine.LNX.4.52.0307011724120.17614@shaft.bitmine.net> 	<3F023FE3.8000205@hevanet.com> <1057118308.5378.31.camel@halo>
Message-ID: <3F02EFB3.7020500@hevanet.com>

Holger Stephan wrote:

>You got to be kidding! Linux users in Portland a too large group for one
>name? If we keep splitting up when there are more than 38 of us we're
>not going to get anywhere.
>

Lets see... about a million people in the portland metro area, 70% of 
them with computer access so 700,000. A conservative estimate is 2-3% 
are using linux, but roll in the unixes like OS 10 and I'd wager it's 
more like 5-10%. So that's between 35,000 - 70,000 users.

Even on the low end, that's a lot of people we're not reaching. If 
people are interested in taking the initiative to start up a group with 
a different focus than the PLUG, I think that's fine - go scratch the itch.

What's strange is to hear the argument that those doing so are 
ego-maniacs AND we want them back in our group. I think the other 
argument I'm hearing makes more sense: they're ego-maniacs AND we want 
them in a seperate group with a very distinct group name.

Mind you, I'm not saying anyone is or isn't an ego-maniac, just that the 
logic of the first argument seems flawed.

david

From danielx.j.petcher at intel.com  Wed Jul  2 08:11:02 2003
From: danielx.j.petcher at intel.com (Petcher, Danielx J)
Date: Wed Jul  2 08:11:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] [PDXLUG July 01, 2003 Meeting Announcement]
Message-ID: <7D6F4CF55743264F8B23E20353705EEC0A8F4D@orsmsx408.amr.corp.intel.com>

Your statistics are interesting, but inflated. For the majority of
computer users, the box on their desk is just a tool. It's a means by
which they accomplish some sort of real work (even if that real work is
just shootin' rocks in an Asteroids-style game.) Their computer is an
appliance, like a toaster or a vacuum cleaner.

The majority of computer users don't care what operating system they
use; they just want to surf pr0n, read their Email, process words, or
whatever other application they like. This majority of folks is really
not interested in hanging around some bar drinking beer or coffee with
geeks. They're even less interested in talking about their appliances in
some conference room.

There are a lot of interested people who aren't reached by users'
groups. There are a lot more disinterested people who will never want to
be reached by users' groups.

We now return you to the present ranting and raving, already in
progress....

-djp
http://folding.stanford.edu - the brain you save may be your own!

From list at sonofhans.net  Wed Jul  2 08:51:02 2003
From: list at sonofhans.net (Randall Hansen)
Date: Wed Jul  2 08:51:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] perl does nothing but segfault
Message-ID: <20030702085031.27a49f36.list@sonofhans.net>

Folks ~

As of about 36 hours ago, perl on my workstation does nothing but
segfault.  Some trivial things work (e.g. $ perl -e "print 'foo'"),
but any script which uses a module fails instantly with "Segmentation
fault."

My system:
  Debian 'testing' (aka 'Sarge')
  Linux kernel 2.4.20
  Perl 5.8.0

After a while debugging two nights ago, in desperation I rebooted -
and it worked!  (I felt the icy touch of Windows on my neck...)  For a
few hours anyway, until it stopped again.

None of the commands, daemons, or cron jobs I run seem to do it --
I've tried all the ones I can think of.  I rebooted again (argh)
yesterday, and it's been fine since then, but it still makes me
nervous.

I don't know enough to debug the problem - even what logs to start
examining.  I don't know how long the system runs before perl dies, or
any idea what precipitates it.  

I was talking about it yesterday and Wil asked what kernel I was
running.  "A rooted one," Ingy replied, before I had a chance to.
Funny, but I hope wrong.  The only thing open to the public is port
22, and I keep the box very up to date.  I ran 'chkrootkit' yesterday
(booted from a CD) and it found nothing.

Wil also wondered if it were corrupted memory or disk corruption where
perl lives.  How can I check for these definitively?

I'm still gathering information, and will post back if anyone's
interested.  Until then, can anyone help?

Thanks in advance,

Randall

From randall at sonofhans.net  Wed Jul  2 13:15:03 2003
From: randall at sonofhans.net (Randall Hansen)
Date: Wed Jul  2 13:15:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] perl does nothing but segfault
Message-ID: <20030702084950.2820fba9.randall@sonofhans.net>

Folks ~

As of about 36 hours ago, perl on my workstation does nothing but
segfault.  Some trivial things work (e.g. $ perl -e "print 'foo'"),
but any script which uses a module fails instantly with "Segmentation
fault."

My system:
  Debian 'testing' (aka 'Sarge')
  Linux kernel 2.4.20
  Perl 5.8.0

After a while debugging two nights ago, in desperation I rebooted -
and it worked!  (I felt the icy touch of Windows on my neck...)  For a
few hours anyway, until it stopped again.

None of the commands, daemons, or cron jobs I run seem to do it --
I've tried all the ones I can think of.  I rebooted again (argh)
yesterday, and it's been fine since then, but it still makes me
nervous.

I don't know enough to debug the problem - even what logs to start
examining.  I don't know how long the system runs before perl dies, or
any idea what precipitates it.  

I was talking about it yesterday and Wil asked what kernel I was
running.  "A rooted one," Ingy replied, before I had a chance to.
Funny, but I hope wrong.  The only thing open to the public is port
22, and I keep the box very up to date.  I ran 'chkrootkit' yesterday
(booted from a CD) and it found nothing.

Wil also wondered if it were corrupted memory or disk corruption where
perl lives.  How can I check for these definitively?

I'm still gathering information, and will post back if anyone's
interested.  Until then, can anyone help?

Thanks in advance,

Randall

From gilmanhunt at comcast.net  Wed Jul  2 13:18:01 2003
From: gilmanhunt at comcast.net (gilmanhunt at comcast.net)
Date: Wed Jul  2 13:18:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] IMAP "public folders"
Message-ID: <E19XnPQ-0002zW-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

This smells to my semi-experienced sinuses like a kludge. So I'm asking if
there's a better way to do this.

Here's what we're trying to do. We're "upgrading" our accounting software to
something that uses Windows. Many (about 30) of our users are going to be
replacing their MacIntoshes with Windows computers.  Their email is currently
Outlook Express and/or Entourage, accessing the (thankfully) Linux mail server
with the POP protocol.  We want to duplicate the contents of the Mac's inbox on
the PC in whatever they're using on the PC (probably, again, outlook).

Not finding any conversion utilities for mac->windows outlook inboxes, we're
looking at a solution that involves: creating an imap "public folder", copying
the mac inbox to the public folder, copying the public folder to the PC inbox.

I can't find anything related to an "imap public folder" in documents for the UW
Imap daemon. Cyrus is ... closer, but I don't want to install cyrus for such a
temporary fix.

Here's what I've found, though;
I can create a file and change the permissions to 666, and then hard link it
into a user's ~/Mail/ directory, and bingo, the Mac version of "mail.app" sees
it as a folder and will move stuff to it and out of it, and said stuff is
visible (and read/writable) by all other people that have links to it. I can see
uses for that, but, frankly, this is what smells like a kludge. There's no
documentation for it, there's no configuration files for it like Samba might have.

What should I be doing here?

~Russ



From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Wed Jul  2 13:27:01 2003
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: Wed Jul  2 13:27:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Problems using X with ssh from one particular site.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0307011408200.15779-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>
References: 
	 <Pine.LNX.4.44.0307011408200.15779-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>
Message-ID: <1057177594.2467.99.camel@kat.zotnet.com>

He said it worked from other computers, and he is using 'ssh -x'

On Tue, 2003-07-01 at 14:09, alan wrote:
> Some implementations of ssh have x forwarding turned off.  Make sure that 
> you are starting ssh with the proper command line options to override this 
> behaviour.
> 

He said it worked from other computers, and he is using 'ssh -x' which
should force the client.

You can still override this (perhaps Knoppix is the problem,  Here's a
test.  Run Knoppix on a machine that works and see it it works running
Knoppix!).

Again doing the '-v' at both end would tell you this.

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Wed Jul  2 13:31:02 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Wed Jul  2 13:31:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] IMAP "public folders"
In-Reply-To: <E19XnPQ-0002zW-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <E19XnPQ-0002zW-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <1057177783.23205.52.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Wed, 2003-07-02 at 12:36, gilmanhunt at comcast.net wrote:

> I can't find anything related to an "imap public folder" in documents for the UW
> Imap daemon. Cyrus is ... closer, but I don't want to install cyrus for such a
> temporary fix.

Well, if you want my opinion, I'd install Cyrus and switch everyone over
to IMAP permanently.  This solves the problem of platform and MUA client
portability once and for all, and lets you back up your mail spool
centrally.  There really aren't any downsides and IMAP is a much more
intelligent protocol than POP.  I'm biased, of course, since I sell
Cyrus IMAP-based solutions.

Wil

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Wed Jul  2 15:22:01 2003
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Wed Jul  2 15:22:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Problems using X with ssh from one particular site.
In-Reply-To: <1057087118.2467.27.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0307021512070.2862-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>

Thanks for the advice.

I'm not absolutely sure what the problem was, but I fixed it.
Actually, I seem to have had a couple problems interacting.
I made a small error in the configuration of my machine in Corvallis
when I installed broad band.  As a result, that machine couldn't
couldn't ssh to itself and use X until I fixed and DNS (or hosts file)
problem.  And then I had another problem, but it went away when I
changed versions of Knoppix.  The truth is I'm not sure what this
problem was, but I don't have it now - even when I use the previous
version of Knoppix.  Maybe it had something to do when the temperature
on Monday, or the time of day, or the number of beers I had at lunch...

                                                   Dave Mandel

On 1 Jul 2003, Zot O'Connor wrote:

>
> Most of this times you cannot X it is due to DNS/IP issues.  X likes to
> know which machine is what.
>
> Also some version ssh require keys not passwords, it gets sticky.
>
> The best way to test is run X on the server with the debug flag on a
> higher port (2222).  The following will work, but will die after the
> first ssh connection goes away.
>
>         sshd -d -p 2222
>
> Then run on the knopix CD.
>
>         ssh -p 2222 -v -X Vancouver-1
>
> Make sure you are not root for the ssh connection.
>
> You may see a X Forwarding being denied message right there or some
> other message.
>
> >From there you can play with "xauth, list" and see what is being set up.
>
> I have things like
>
>         mp.zotnet.com:14  MIT-MAGIC-COOKIE-1  e7a5263xxxxxxae73dxxxxxxxxb
>         mp.zotnet.com/unix:14  MIT-MAGIC-COOKIE-1  e7a52633xxxxxxxxae73xxxxxxxb
>
>
> BTW "xlogo" is a small way to test X settings.
>
>
> Other places to check:  /etc/ssh/sshd_config (or what ever)
>
> #X11Forwarding no
> X11Forwarding yes
> #X11DisplayOffset 10
> #X11UseLocalhost yes
>
>
> On Sat, 2003-06-28 at 21:20, David Mandel wrote:
> > I'm having a bit of a problem describing my problem, but here goes ...
> >
> > I have a couple computers in Vancouver and one in Corvallis, which is
> > access remotely using something like:
> >
> >                   ssh -X Vancouver-1
> >                   ssh -X Vancouver-2
> >                   ssh -X Corvallis
> >
> > This has always worked.  No matter where I happen to be, given a Linux
> > machine and internet access, I seem to be able to access the three
> > machines.  This access includes the ability to run X applications like
> > xclock, emacs, and gimp over the net.
> >
> > NOW THE PROBLEM:  I was at a company in Springfield today.  I couldn't
> > find a Linux machine, but I booted a Knoppix CD on one of their Windows
> > machines and everything looked fine, except I was able to access
> > Vancouver-1, Vancouver-2, and Corvallis using ssh - BUT	I COULDN'T
> > RUN X APPLICATIONS.  Everytime I tryed to start one, I got a message
> > about not being able to access the X server.  Anyone know why I'm
> > having this problem?  The display variable looks reasonable.  I would
> > say that the firewall is blocking me, but X should be being tunneled
> > thru ssh and ssh is working fine; so I don't see how this could be
> > causing the problem.
> >
> >                                           Sincerely,
> >                                           David Mandel
> >                                           Chief Activist
> >                                           Portland Linux/Unix Group

<RANT>
I am a member of both PLUG and PDXLUG and I have NO PROBLEM differentiating
between the two groups. I also resent the generalized insults that PLUGgers
have been posting based upon their LIMITED perspective and PERSONAL
opinions. Based upon the responses from PDXLUG, I don't think that a
name-change will fly. However, it may be possible for us,(PDXLUG), to better
differentiate between our groups which I will suggest to PDXLUG. In the
meantime, I think it would be a better use of everyone's time to stick to
facts and refrain from the name-calling and over-generalizations that make
it more difficult to make any positive changes.
</RANT>

Cordially,
Kurt Harlan




From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Jul  2 16:09:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Wed Jul  2 16:09:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: LUG-fest [was July 01, 2003 Meeting Announcement]
In-Reply-To: <BB28B284.76%kurt@kurt-harlan.net>
References: <BB28B284.76%kurt@kurt-harlan.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0307021607310.4165@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Wed, 2 Jul 2003, Kurt Harlan wrote:
> However, it may be possible for us,(PDXLUG), to better differentiate
> between our groups which I will suggest to PDXLUG.

I still haven't heard any kind of reason WHY you should differentiate
yourselves.  The only thing that is confusing is the name.  Otherwise, the
"groups" are identical and have large overlap in membership, the same
goals, and the same (read: no) organizational structure.

So why differentiate yourself?  The only thing that differentiates now is
the name and even that doesn't try very hard to be different.

So why bother differentiating?  What's the difference?

J.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Wed Jul  2 17:11:02 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)

Subject: [PLUG] Re: LUG-fest [was July 01, 2003 Meeting Announcement]
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0307021607310.4165@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <BB28B284.76%kurt@kurt-harlan.net>
	<Pine.LNX.4.52.0307021607310.4165@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <86y8zgpj0o.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Jeme" == Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> writes:

Kurt> However, it may be possible for us,(PDXLUG), to better
Kurt> differentiate between our groups which I will suggest to PDXLUG.

Jeme> I still haven't heard any kind of reason WHY you should
Jeme> differentiate yourselves.  The only thing that is confusing is
Jeme> the name.  Otherwise, the "groups" are identical and have large
Jeme> overlap in membership, the same goals, and the same (read: no)
Jeme> organizational structure.

Jeme> So why differentiate yourself?  The only thing that
Jeme> differentiates now is the name and even that doesn't try very
Jeme> hard to be different.

Jeme> So why bother differentiating?  What's the difference?

>From what I've been able to deduce, the people who came to PDXLUG from
PLUG wanted less "noise" on the mailing list.[1] No one really defines
what they mean by noise.  Maybe they think of LUG-like entities as
strictly technical "help" resources, which to me seems too narrow.

The self-declared differentiation at the beginning was that they
wanted the freedom to ban people who they didn't like.  From the
welcome message:

  mailman> Remember we do have the right to refuse service to anyone.[2]

For part of a discussion of that, see:
  <http://www.pdxlug.org/pipermail/pdxlug/2003-January/000077.html>

A lot of the "resistance" to this topic on the PDXLUG mailing list has
been to any discussion of the naming issue or of "governance" type
questions (e.g. what does it mean to be a 'group'?  how are decisions
made?  etc).  I can understand not wanting to help discuss those
problems, but I don't understand not wanting the discussions to take
place at all.  And where else but the group mailing list are you going
to find people interested in contributing to those discussions?


[1] It seems somewhat contradictory that one of the people who
    mentioned this as a reason was Kurt, and yet he is evidently still
    subscribed to the "noisy" PLUG list.  Maybe it's because PDXLUG
    isn't seen as a fully viable replacement yet.

[2] It may just be a figment of my imagination, but I have always
    assumed that you, Jeme, were their (not mine) archetypal example
    of someone to refuse service.

-- 
Russell Senior         ``shtal latta wos ba padre u prett tu nashtonfi
seniorr at aracnet.com      mrlosh''  -- Bashgali Kafir for ``If you have
                         had diarrhoea many days you will surely die.''

>
> I still haven't heard any kind of reason WHY you should differentiate
> yourselves.  The only thing that is confusing is the name.  Otherwise, the
> "groups" are identical and have large overlap in membership, the same
> goals, and the same (read: no) organizational structure.
>
> So why differentiate yourself?  The only thing that differentiates now is
> the name and even that doesn't try very hard to be different.
>
> So why bother differentiating?  What's the difference?
>
> J.
> --
>    -----------------
>      Jeme A Brelin
>     jeme at brelin.net
>    -----------------
>  [cc] counter-copyright
>  http://www.openlaw.org
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

> eth1, it runs o.k., the internal box can browse the
> outside world. I guess it means that my iptable works
> fine. The problem is that everytime I start the
> iptables it will appear the error message: " iptables
> v1.2.7a: host/network "start92.168.0.0 not found. Try
> iptables -h or -help..."
> I am using DSL not the modem. I look all over the
> related files to try to find any error about
> "92.168.0.0" but couldn't find any. Could anyone help
> me with this problem.
>

> work, I only familiar with samba and ipchains setting
> but not with the iptables setting. Please help!
> Thanks
> 

Hey Melinda,
You might try looking in /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-eth0 (or
whatever your internal facing interface is) and make sure that the
NETWORK= entry is correct.

Steve

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Wed Jul  2 20:59:01 2003
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)

Subject: [PLUG] SECOND ANNOUNCEMENT: July PLUG Meeting (fwd)
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0307022056220.4904-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>


                         MEETING ANNOUNCEMENT

                    The Portland Linux/Unix Group
                              will meet
                      7 PM Thursday July 3, 2003
                                  at
                      Portland State University
                                in the
                        Smith Memorial Center
                               Room 298
                       On the block bounded by
   SW Montgomery, SW Broadway (7th), SW Harrison, and SW Park (9th)


      **********************************************************

                             PRESENTATION

                             An Overview
                                of the
                     Open Source Development Lab

                                  by

                          Timothy D. Witham
                          <wookie at osdl.org>

      The Open Source Development Lab (www.osdl.org) is an industry
      sponsored lab with data centers in Portland, Oregon and
      Yokohama, Japan.  The lab sponsors key industry projects,
      including industry initiatives to enhance Linux for use in
      corporate data centers (Data Center Linux) and in
      telecommunications networks (Carrier Grade Linux).
      Timothy D. Witham is the lab's director.  He will give a
      general overview of the lab and it's activities and what
      it can offer to Open Source developers.  I suppose he
      will also talk about Linus Torvalds' decision to take a
      position with the lab.

      **********************************************************

          Agenda:

              7:00 - 7:30  Business
                   We will discuss the status of our ongoing projects
                   including the monthly hands on clinics, PLUG for
                   Education, etc.

              7:30 - 8:30  Presentation

                   See above

              9:00 - ...  Beer
                                  The Lucky Labrador Brewing Company
                                  915 SE Hawthorne



                                          David Mandel
                                          Chief Activist
                                          Portland Linux/Unix Group
                                          560 SE Alexander
                                          Corvallis, Oregon 97333
                                          (541) 730-5285 cell
                                          plug at sco302.DavidMandel.com


          P.S.  The Mid Willamette Valley Linux Users Group meets at
                Oregon State University (generally Owen Hall room 101)
                on the first Tuesday of the month.
                See http://www.mwvlug.org/ for details.

          P.S.  The Eugene Linux Users Group meets regularly.
                See http://www.euglug.org for details.

From speralta at willamette.edu  Wed Jul  2 21:44:02 2003
From: speralta at willamette.edu (Salvador J Peralta)
Date: Wed Jul  2 21:44:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] iptables error message
In-Reply-To: <20030703032428.54117.qmail@web10905.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.21.0307022134330.22473-100000@gemini.willamette.edu>


On Wed, 2 Jul 2003, Lynn Yuan wrote:

> Hi Steve,
> 
> Thank you for your quick reply. My eth0 in this case
> is    192.168.0. this linux box is among my another
> internal network, and the eth1 for this box is
> 172.16.1.. I check the file ifcfg-eth0 and ifcfg-eth1,
> both file setting seem o.k..(ip address and network,
> broadcast,)
> Is there any other files I should take a look at?

How are you starting iptables?  If you cannot start it manually, then your
syntax is probably bad.  In redhat 9.0, why not try doing 

/etc/init.d/iptables status and/or
/etc/init.d/iptables restart.

If that doesn't work, have a look at the file specified in
IPTABLES_CONFIG.

Regards,

Salvador


Since you are using
redhat, the first
place I would look is at the start

From stevea at nwtechops.com  Wed Jul  2 21:54:01 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Wed Jul  2 21:54:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] iptables error message
In-Reply-To: <20030703032428.54117.qmail@web10905.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20030703032428.54117.qmail@web10905.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <1057207957.1294.17.camel@main>

On Wed, 2003-07-02 at 20:24, Lynn Yuan wrote:
> Hi Steve,
> 
> Thank you for your quick reply. My eth0 in this case
> is    192.168.0. this linux box is among my another
> internal network, and the eth1 for this box is
> 172.16.1.. I check the file ifcfg-eth0 and ifcfg-eth1,
> both file setting seem o.k..(ip address and network,
> broadcast,)
> Is there any other files I should take a look at?
> 
> Melinda
> 

There are a few more Melinda. I think the most likely candidate is
probably in /etc/sysconfig/iptables. However, if your using firestarter
to configure and start iptables then this file is likely not going to
contain any information of value (the firestarter init script expects a
different configuration file). If your using /etc/init.d/iptables to
start the firewall then /etc/sysconfig/iptables would be the place to
look. Also, you can look at /etc/init.d/functions for clues since it is
sourced by the /etc/init.d/iptables script.

Steve






From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Thu Jul  3 01:26:02 2003
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Thu Jul  3 01:26:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Problems using X with ssh from one particular site.
In-Reply-To: <1057120851.2464.52.camel@kat.zotnet.com>

On 1 Jul 2003, Zot O'Connor wrote:

> Ahhhhh!  This is very insecure!
>
> X over ssh uses xauth/magic cookies and a fake display (tunneled).
>
> Also since it works from some machines and not others, it is likely
> DNS/IP, or a setting on passwords/keys.
>
> --

Yes, I did resolve the problem and my biggest problem seemed to be
that I changed the ip of one machine without making a change to the
DNS (or /etc/hosts file).

From m at pdxlug.org  Thu Jul  3 08:34:02 2003
From: m at pdxlug.org (Matt Alexander)
Date: Thu Jul  3 08:34:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Multiple TCP/IP connections application question
Message-ID: <33070.68.107.223.201.1057246432.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>

Let's say you have two instances of the same program that are both
accessing the same remote IP address and service.  When the packets return
to the OS, how are they redirected to the right program instance?

For example, if you had several instances of a script that was sending
different GET/PUT data to a website and returning different results.  How
are the results matched up with the correct calling program?
Thanks,
~M



From griffint at pobox.com  Thu Jul  3 08:49:02 2003
From: griffint at pobox.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Thu Jul  3 08:49:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Multiple TCP/IP connections application question
In-Reply-To: <33070.68.107.223.201.1057246432.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>; from m@pdxlug.org on Thu, Jul 03, 2003 at 08:33:52AM -0700
References: <33070.68.107.223.201.1057246432.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
Message-ID: <20030703084832.A2619@aracnet.com>

Each local program gets its own local "port" for the TCP/IP connection.
This port is part of the return address.

You can get a listing of open ports and connections with the netstat
utility.

Terry

On Thu, Jul 03, 2003 at 08:33:52AM -0700, Matt Alexander wrote:
> Let's say you have two instances of the same program that are both
> accessing the same remote IP address and service.  When the packets return
> to the OS, how are they redirected to the right program instance?
> 
> For example, if you had several instances of a script that was sending
> different GET/PUT data to a website and returning different results.  How
> are the results matched up with the correct calling program?
> Thanks,
> ~M
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

-- 
Terry Griffin <griffint at pobox.com>
http://www.blindchicken.com/~terryg/



From srau at rauhaus.org  Thu Jul  3 08:51:01 2003
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)
Date: Thu Jul  3 08:51:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Multiple TCP/IP connections application question
In-Reply-To: <33070.68.107.223.201.1057246432.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
References: <33070.68.107.223.201.1057246432.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
Message-ID: <20030703154707.GD7636@rauhaus.org>

* Matt Alexander <m at pdxlug.org> [030703 08:31]:
> Let's say you have two instances of the same program that are both
> accessing the same remote IP address and service.  When the packets return
> to the OS, how are they redirected to the right program instance?
> 
> For example, if you had several instances of a script that was sending
> different GET/PUT data to a website and returning different results.  How
> are the results matched up with the correct calling program?
> Thanks,
> ~M

A tcp socket is defined by source ip, destination ip, source port, and
destination port.

So in your example, when a client connects to the web site, the client
OS hands the client socket a random, high-numbered ( >1024 ) port to use
as the source port.

Each new client will have a different high-numbered source port, and the
server at the other end will send return data for the given client to
that client's high-numbered port.

--Stafford



From sandbox at pacifier.com  Thu Jul  3 08:53:01 2003

Looks like a typo somewhere.  Have you tried,

# grep -r start92.168.0.0 /etc

--
Kyle Accardi

  A few weeks ago I upgraded my CUPS installation to 1.1.9. The laser
printer is working just fine, but I've discovered a problem with the color
deskjet just this morning.

  The job goes in the queue and the printer status shows "processing".
However, before anything gets to the printer I see the message, "Printer not
connected. Will try again in 30 seconds."

  The printer _is_ connected -- that's not been changed since the software
upgrade -- and I haven't a clue what might be wrong. And, of course, I'm
trying to print some maps to send to a client today.

  I've tried modifying the printer within the CUPS GUI admin tool, but that
didn't help. I can try deleting the printer and re-installing it. If anyone
has some suggestions about the cause -- and solution -- to this problem I'd
greatly appreciate them.

Thanks,

Rich

Tyler,

    Fortunately, my experience was a bit smoother.  I don't like to
admit it, but I had been using the Windows 2000 machine for some
real work a few weeks ago, so it was up to date with 128 bit encryption
and everything installed.  Moreover, the error messages I got weren't
completely fatal.  I was able to get around them or ignore them or
whatever.  Still:
    -  I was given false information by their tech.
    -  I had to install strange legacy equipment to do the installation.
    -  and the installation required more skill on my part than the
       typical customer has.

                                                        Dave

P.S.  On the other hand, it is fast, has decent availability, and is
      almost affordable.

From lynnming at yahoo.com  Thu Jul  3 15:06:01 2003
From: lynnming at yahoo.com (Lynn Yuan)
Date: Thu Jul  3 15:06:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] iptables error message
In-Reply-To: <1057207957.1294.17.camel@main>
Message-ID: <20030703220525.47038.qmail@web10907.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi Steve

The way I did to install the iptables is I download
the file called "zeller-firewall", and follow the
steps to set up my iptables files. I start the
iptables by type "/etc/rc.d/init.d/iptables start". 
Actually I check those files you mentioned before I
post my question, but couldn't find any "92.168.0.0".
The internal network seems fine, the 172.16.1.x
machine can browse the internet without any problems,
so I guess the error message just a warning or
something nothing serious.

Melinda
--- "Steven A. Adams" <stevea at nwtechops.com> wrote:
> On Wed, 2003-07-02 at 20:24, Lynn Yuan wrote:
> > Hi Steve,
> > 
> > Thank you for your quick reply. My eth0 in this
> case
> > is    192.168.0. this linux box is among my
> another
> > internal network, and the eth1 for this box is
> > 172.16.1.. I check the file ifcfg-eth0 and
> ifcfg-eth1,
> > both file setting seem o.k..(ip address and
> network,
> > broadcast,)
> > Is there any other files I should take a look at?
> > 
> > Melinda
> > 
> 
> There are a few more Melinda. I think the most
> likely candidate is
> probably in /etc/sysconfig/iptables. However, if
> your using firestarter
> to configure and start iptables then this file is
> likely not going to
> contain any information of value (the firestarter
> init script expects a
> different configuration file). If your using
> /etc/init.d/iptables to
> start the firewall then /etc/sysconfig/iptables
> would be the place to
> look. Also, you can look at /etc/init.d/functions
> for clues since it is
> sourced by the /etc/init.d/iptables script.
> 
> Steve
> 
> 
> 
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Thu Jul  3 20:01:02 2003
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Thu Jul  3 20:01:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] iptables error message
References: <20030704022532.35497.qmail@web10904.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <3F04EDB5.2090800@pacifier.com>

Lynn Yuan wrote:

> I did try "grep -r start92.168.0.0", and waiting for a
> long long time (at least 20 mins) nothing come out.


It should only take a few seconds.  You need to run this as root and don't 
forget to tell grep which directory to look in

# grep -r start92.168.0.0 /etc

If you left out the /etc part, grep will sit there forever waiting for you 
to tell it where to look.

--
Kyle Accardi




From stevea at nwtechops.com  Thu Jul  3 20:13:02 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Thu Jul  3 20:13:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] iptables error message
In-Reply-To: <20030704022532.35497.qmail@web10904.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20030704022532.35497.qmail@web10904.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <1057288327.1240.11.camel@main>

On Thu, 2003-07-03 at 19:25, Lynn Yuan wrote:
> Hi 
> 
> I did try "grep -r start92.168.0.0", and waiting for a
> long long time (at least 20 mins) nothing come out.
> 
> Melinda

I would almost bet that "start" is coming from the iptables start script
and is not written to the config file. You might stop the grep and redo
it with just the 92.168.0.0

From lynnming at yahoo.com  Thu Jul  3 21:43:01 2003
From: lynnming at yahoo.com (Lynn Yuan)
Date: Thu Jul  3 21:43:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] iptables error message
In-Reply-To: <3F04EDB5.2090800@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <20030704044227.92755.qmail@web10907.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi 

Finally, I solved the problem by replacing the
192.168.0.0 with $EXTERNAL_IP in the firewall.iptables
file - the FTP section, since the error occured after
execute the ssh which is FTP part, so I just give it a
try, and that is.

Sorry to confuse you, it's all my fault.
Thank again for your help.

Melinda

From bmdimaculangan at bhpi.com.ph  Thu Jul  3 22:19:02 2003
From: bmdimaculangan at bhpi.com.ph (Billy Dimaculangan)
Date: Thu Jul  3 22:19:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] FW: port 80 problem
In-Reply-To: <20030627164410.GA13017@constraint>
Message-ID: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCMEEACNAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>

do i need to do something in my iptables config, to enable port 80 to the
outside world

>-----Original Message-----
>From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org
>[mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org]On Behalf Of Bill Barry
>Sent: Saturday, June 28, 2003 12:44 AM
>To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
>Subject: Re: [PLUG] FW: port 80 problem
>
>
>On Fri, Jun 27, 2003 at 02:19:31PM +0800, Billy Dimaculangan wrote:
>> I have here a Linux server that is acting as proxy server with
>2(two NICs),
>> one is facing the Internet and the other is facing our LAN.  The
>problem I
>> have is the webpage hosted in that server is only available in our local
>> area network.  When I tried a port scan using the local address port 80
>> seems to ok, but when I port scanned the IP Address facing the
>Internet port
>> 80 is not available. That is why the webpage hosted in that
>server is only
>> available for the local area network and inaccessible in the
>outside world.
>> I would like to know is how could I make this port 80 available to the
>> outside world?
>
>What does netstat tell you about port 80? I.e. what does
>netstat -an | grep ":80"
>return?
>
>It is possible that your web server is configured to only listen to
>port 80 on the local network.  If you are running apache this is
>configured with the listen directive in httpd.conf
>http://httpd.apache.org/docs/mod/core.html#listen
>yours may be something like
>Listen 192.168.0.1:80
>where you probably want it to be just
>Listen 80
>
>Bill Barry
>
>_______________________________________________
>PLUG mailing list
>PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
>http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug




From speralta at willamette.edu  Thu Jul  3 22:53:01 2003
From: speralta at willamette.edu (Salvador J Peralta)
Date: Thu Jul  3 22:53:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] iptables error message
In-Reply-To: <1057288327.1240.11.camel@main>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.21.0307032241570.3150-100000@gemini.willamette.edu>


On Thu, 3 Jul 2003, Steven A. Adams wrote:

> On Thu, 2003-07-03 at 19:25, Lynn Yuan wrote:
> > Hi 
> > 
> > I did try "grep -r start92.168.0.0", and waiting for a
> > long long time (at least 20 mins) nothing come out.
> > 
> > Melinda
> 
> I would almost bet that "start" is coming from the iptables start script
> and is not written to the config file. You might stop the grep and redo
> it with just the 92.168.0.0


92.168.0.0 is almost certainly being pulled into an initialization script
as a variable.  Based on her earlier posts, I am guessing that it's a
value of the NETWORK she is on.

My hypothesis is that one of her ethernet cards is not a trusted device
and iptables is whining that her firewall is blocking one of the devices,
probably eth1.




 
> > --- Kyle Accardi <sandbox at pacifier.com> wrote:
> > > Lynn Yuan wrote:
> > > > I start iptables by typing
> > > /etc/rc.d/init.d/iptables
> > > > start. My interanl linux boxes can browse internet
> > > > without any problems, but the error message
> > > (iptables
> > > > v1.2.7a: host/network 'start92.168.0.0' not found
> > > try
> > > > 'iptables -h for more information) occured when I
> > > > start the iptables by /etc/rc.d/init.d/iptables
> > > start
> > > > or restart. I search configaration files under
> > > > /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts,
> > > > /etc/firewall/firewall.conf.iptables,
> > > > firewall.local.iptables, firewall.dns,
> > > firewall,banned
> > > > even the files under /etc/rc.d/init.d/iptables
> > > etc.,
> > > > but couldn't find any '92.168.0.0'.
> > > 
> > > 
> > > Looks like a typo somewhere.  Have you tried,
> > > 
> > > # grep -r start92.168.0.0 /etc

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Fri Jul  4 13:02:02 2003

Subject: [PLUG] Volunteers for Booth at O'Reilly Open Source Conference
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0307041159440.17330-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>

PLUG has a booth at the O'Reilly Open Source Conference on Wednesday
July 9, 2003 and Thursday July 10, 2003.  I was sort of coordinating
things for this, but I have taken a NEW JOB and won't be available.
As a result, Dale Zeutenhorst <dzeut at MicroSharp.com> has been kind
enough to step in at the last minute and take over.  He will need
volunteers to help man (or woman) the booth.

So,

    (1)  If anyone has any ideas on the best (and cheapest) way
         of using this space and want to help contact Dale.

    (2)  Also, I signed up for the booth as the Portland Linux/Unix Group,
         but we would love to have people from the Mid-Willamette
         Valley Linux Users Group and the Eugene Linux Users Group
         and the groups in Astoria and Tillamook and Bend and Medford
         or where ever.   If anyone is coming from where ever bring
         some literature for the table if you have any.  Also, a small
         sign would be nice.  Since we registered as the Portland
         Linux/Unix Group the conference will provide us with a sign
         (I assume), but we are happy to share with other groups.
         This booth is definitely non-commercial, but it is ok
         to make people aware of key group sponsors and group
         consultant lists and things like that.  Just keep it low key.
         Is Free Geek coming to the conference?  If not, we would
         have some of their flyers on the table.  What about
         LinuxFund.org?

    (3)  Finally, we need volunteers to man the booth.
         If you don't have a conference pass at this point, you may
         still be able to get one by volunteering to man the booth,
         but volunteer SOON.  Dale needs to get the name of our
         volunteers to O'Reilly ASAP.  We are really late on this.
         Also, I don't know what type of pass O'Reilly will give
         conference volunteers, but they have hinted that it might
         be a pretty good pass if there aren't too many of them.
         So, it you want to volunteer contact:
                    Dale Zeutenhorst <dzeut at MicroSharp.com>
         with your:

                    Email address:
                    Phone number:
                    Information Dale can use to schedule you.
