From jorgens at coho.net  Fri Jul  4 23:04:01 2003
From: jorgens at coho.net (Steve Jorgensen)
Date: Fri Jul  4 23:04:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ubd2 mount problem in user mode linux
Message-ID: <01C34281.B5B0C0A0.jorgens@coho.net>

I'm gradually learning the stuff I need to make my uml strategy work, and I 
just hit a wall I can't seem to get past on my own.  I'm running the uml 
with the desired ubd0 image just fine, but I can't seem to make any other 
ubd device work right.  First off, the image that rootstrap made did not 
have ubd1, ubd2, etc, though it has ubda0, ..., ubdb0, ... and many others 
I won't need.  Anyway, I made the ubd2 node using mknod /dev/ubd2 b 98 2, 
but mount behaves very strangely.

Whether I try to pass an unmounted partition directly (e.g. /dev/hde6) or 
an image file, I get the same strange behavior when I try to mount it in 
uml using mount -t ext /dev/ubd2 /testmount.  The mount says it was 
successful, but if I ls /testmount, I see a mirror image of the uml root 
directory - not good!  To test and make sure my image file itself was not 
somehow a copy of the uml image, I tried creating a dummy file in the root 
before mounting.  Sure enough, the dummy file shows up in ls /testmount.

Does anyone know what is going on and/or how to fix it?

Thanks,

- Steve Jorgensen



From jorgens at coho.net  Fri Jul  4 23:21:02 2003
From: jorgens at coho.net (Steve Jorgensen)
Date: Fri Jul  4 23:21:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ubd2 mount problem in user mode linux
Message-ID: <01C34284.1863B610.jorgens@coho.net>

OK, I found the answer.  I had tried to search the Web before posting the 
question here, but I found it only just after posting.  The minor numbers 
for ubd<n> devices are 0, 16, 32, ..., not 0, 1, 2, ... in case anyone was 
curious.

On Friday, July 04, 2003 11:12 PM, Steve Jorgensen [SMTP:jorgens at coho.net] 
wrote:
> I'm gradually learning the stuff I need to make my uml strategy work, and 
I
> just hit a wall I can't seem to get past on my own.  I'm running the uml
> with the desired ubd0 image just fine, but I can't seem to make any other 
> ubd device work right.  First off, the image that rootstrap made did not
> have ubd1, ubd2, etc, though it has ubda0, ..., ubdb0, ... and many 
others
> I won't need.  Anyway, I made the ubd2 node using mknod /dev/ubd2 b 98 2, 
> but mount behaves very strangely.
>
> Whether I try to pass an unmounted partition directly (e.g. /dev/hde6) or 
> an image file, I get the same strange behavior when I try to mount it in
> uml using mount -t ext /dev/ubd2 /testmount.  The mount says it was
> successful, but if I ls /testmount, I see a mirror image of the uml root
> directory - not good!  To test and make sure my image file itself was not 
> somehow a copy of the uml image, I tried creating a dummy file in the 
root
> before mounting.  Sure enough, the dummy file shows up in ls /testmount.

>

Subject: [PLUG] Anti-Mosquito for Linux
Message-ID: <20030705170428.GA20386@or.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

I downloaded S. Punyaratapundhu's Anti-Mosquito program for Windows
2000, and noticed a tarball bundled up with it, it turned out to be a
linux version of the same program! 

I didn't see this advertised on his website anywhere (though I don't 
read Thai), but got the Win2k zip file here:

http://download.thaiware.com/program4/antimosz.zip

Supposedly this program emits sound that mosquitos and other insects 
dislike, so you can use your laptop outside in the summer, although 
it's hard to verify that it's doing anything...

From bderr at myrealbox.com  Sat Jul  5 11:46:02 2003
From: bderr at myrealbox.com (Brian Derr)
Date: Sat Jul  5 11:46:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] .muttrc
Message-ID: <20030705184504.GA19947@brian.brianandkellyderr.com>

I've been using mutt to read email for a while now and I notice
that when I hit 'c' to change mailboxen sometimes it will automatically
have an inbox selected for me.  Most of the time, however, it doesn't.
Does anyone know of a setting that I can put in my .muttrc to make it
have that behavior all the time (if there are new messages in that inbox
anyway)?

Brian

From jtodd at loligo.com  Sat Jul  5 11:59:01 2003
From: jtodd at loligo.com (John Todd)
Date: Sat Jul  5 11:59:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OT:  VoIP software?
In-Reply-To: <4950.68.96.48.205.1057425787.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
References: <4950.68.96.48.205.1057425787.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
Message-ID: <p0521066bbb2cce47e0d9@loligo.com>

>Does anyone have recommendations for VoIP software?  Ideally I'd like it
>to be free (or very low cost), able to make computer-to-computer calls and
>computer-to-phone calls (not as important to me).  It doesn't have to run
>on Linux, but it would be a nice bonus if it did.
>Thanks,
>~M

Linux:
   kphone (SIP client)

Windows:
   free SIP client: Xten (http://www.xten.com/)

This is actually quite a large topic area.  I'd suggest starting 
backwards, and find the vendor that you want to supply you with 
computer-to-phone service and starting to use the software that works 
with their protocols.  The most common protocols today are H.323 and 
SIP, with SIP being really what is becoming the leading protocol for 
DIY systems.  You should look at iconnecthere.com as a provider; 
reasonable rates, and reasonable policies.

For more information, see:

http://www.pulver.com/products/sip/
http://www.iptel.org/info/products/

I'm considering doing a PLUG presentation on Asterisk, which is an 
Open-Source telephony server that will support VoIP channels as well 
as analog.  However, time is a bit on the scarce side these days...

JT





From steveshome at comcast.net  Sat Jul  5 12:17:02 2003
From: steveshome at comcast.net (Steve Christiansen)
Date: Sat Jul  5 12:17:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] .muttrc
In-Reply-To: <20030705184504.GA19947@brian.brianandkellyderr.com>; from bderr@myrealbox.com on Sat, Jul 05, 2003 at 02:45:04PM -0400
References: <20030705184504.GA19947@brian.brianandkellyderr.com>
Message-ID: <20030705121615.A32499@comcast.net>

On Sat, Jul 05, 2003 at 02:45:04PM -0400, Brian Derr wrote:
> I've been using mutt to read email for a while now and I notice
> that when I hit 'c' to change mailboxen sometimes it will automatically
> have an inbox selected for me.  Most of the time, however, it doesn't.
> Does anyone know of a setting that I can put in my .muttrc to make it
> have that behavior all the time (if there are new messages in that inbox
> anyway)?

>From the mutt docs:

  3.11.  Defining mailboxes which receive mail

  Usage: mailboxes [!]filename [ filename ... ]

  This command specifies folders which can receive mail and which will
  be checked for new messages.  By default, the main menu status bar
  displays how many of these folders have new messages.

  When changing folders, pressing space will cycle through folders with
  new mail.

  Pressing TAB in the directory browser will bring up a menu showing the
  files specified by the mailboxes command, and indicate which contain
  new messages.  Mutt will automatically enter this mode when invoked
  from the command line with the -y option.

  Note: new mail is detected by comparing the last modification time to
  the last access time.  Utilities like biff or frm or any other program
  which accesses the mailbox might cause Mutt to never detect new mail
  for that mailbox if they do not properly reset the access time.
  Backup tools are another common reason for updated access times.

  Note: the filenames in the mailboxes command are resolved when the
  command is executed, so if these names contain ``shortcut characters''
  (such as ``='' and ``!''), any variable definition that affect these
  characters (like ``$folder'' and ``$spool'') should be executed before
  the mailboxes command.

-- 
Steve Christiansen
Linux/UNIX Software Developer
steveshome at comcast.net

am trying to get my wheel to work.  Here is what I have attempted
to it to work.  I am not having any luck.  The wheel still does not work.

From:   /usr/X11/XFConfig:

Section "InputDevice"
  Driver        "mouse"
  Identifier    "Mouse[1]"
  Option        "Device"        "/dev/mice"
  Option        "Emulate3Buttons"       "on"
  Option        "Name"          "AutoDetected"
  Option        "Protocol"      "ImPS/2"
  Option        "Vendor"        "AutoDetected"
  Option        "ZAxisMapping" "Y"
  Option        "Resolution" "1"
EndSection

On Sun, Jul 06, 2003 at 10:41:16AM -0700, Andrew Dennis wrote:
> I went back, read the web page and got the mapping right.  My
> next question has to do with mouse performance.  The movement
> on the screen is rather chunky.  The refresh rate seems very low
> and it's tough to hit the right spot when trying to click on small icons.
> I have upped the resolution seen below to 160.  I can't tell if it helps
> or not.  There is a brief period ( about 10 seconds) during the login
> process when the mouse works really well, but after the desktop
> settles down, the chunkiness returns.  Anyone had this problem and
> know the fix?

What window manager do you use? It sounds like that is the
culprit. Try running X w/out a WM (ie: just put xterm in your
.xinitrc or something) and see if the mouse performs correctly.

-Rogan

From siobhan at spiderland.net  Sun Jul  6 19:28:01 2003
From: siobhan at spiderland.net (Siobhan Elliott)
Date: Sun Jul  6 19:28:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Mouse Wheel - Next Question
In-Reply-To: <3F085F3C.5020501@ardware.net>
References: <3F085699.1080807@ardware.net> <3F085F3C.5020501@ardware.net>
Message-ID: <20030707022638.GA31383@quench.spiderland.net>

begin  electrogrammati illius Andrew Dennis
> I went back, read the web page and got the mapping right.  My
> next question has to do with mouse performance.  The movement
> on the screen is rather chunky.  The refresh rate seems very low
> and it's tough to hit the right spot when trying to click on small icons.
> I have upped the resolution seen below to 160.  I can't tell if it helps
> or not.  There is a brief period ( about 10 seconds) during the login
> process when the mouse works really well, but after the desktop
> settles down, the chunkiness returns.  Anyone had this problem and
> know the fix?

I am not sure what is causing the problem, but you can use 'xset' command
to, amongst other things, adjust your mouse parameters (acceleration
and threshold) (man xset, look for 'mouse'). I use a Logitech Optical
and it seemed a bit grindy and slow also, but with:

xset m 2/1 4

in my .xinitrc it is now downright, er, zippy.

HTH,
 
> Thanks
> 
> Andy
 
Siobhan

the quinessentially '60s interpretation of infinity: a bad LSD trip
and a lava lamp."     --Mr. Cranky reviews "2001"

Andrew Dennis wrote:
> I am using KDE on a Suse 8.1 install. I changed my .xinitrc and at
> the login prompt, I chose failsafe as the window manager (not sure
> if that means anything, there was not a choice of "nothing").
> After login, I got just the xterm and the same behavior. It
> was still chunky.

Here's what I've got.  Never had a problem with mine.  I think the 
important lines are the ZAxisMapping & Buttons.

Section "InputDevice"
   Identifier  "Mouse1"
   Driver      "mouse"
   Option      "Device"          "/dev/input/mice"
   Option      "SendCoreEvents"    "true"
   Option      "Protocol"        "IMPS/2"
   Option      "ZAxisMapping"    "4 5"
   Option      "Buttons"         "5"
EndSection

From robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com  Mon Jul  7 03:56:01 2003
From: robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com (robinsoq )
Date: Mon Jul  7 03:56:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Etherboot.
Message-ID: <200307070355.AA309264544@opusnet.com>

I've figured out how to get Redhat installation images for network images to be
exported via server.  I use mknbi-linux <kernel> <ramdisk> and dump to some file
where I keep my boot images.  Works like a charm.  A few gotchas though, has
anyone rewritten Redhat 9's ftp install to be smart enough to ask for three 
locations to find the RPMS at?  I'm not too keen on having to have the iso 
images and a copy of all the binary rpms on them as well on my ftp site.

Reading Intel's doc it looks like PXE is an extension to dhcp and that it can work 
with any PXE compliant card with a single generic ethernet card driver.  What I don't 
get is what as far as PXE my mobo has on it and if I want to flash a network boot 
program into my onboard ethernet how I go about that.  I don't even know if I can 
use an etherboot disk on this thing.  My mobo is a D845PEBT2.

I use the bootp menu feature with etherboot, a major downfall of this is no 
connection to a central authentication server to prevent just anyone on any 
machine from using a particular network boot image I post.  I generally 
don't want to give public access to a dos boot with fdisk or a Linux installer,
however, having these around is one of the goals of network delivered
booting.  The other gotcha I'm running into is how to come up with a Linux 
system that will boot into and run out of ram entirely for performing 
restoration from my network connected tape server and dump spaces.  Don't 
know if I'll need nfs or if I need to look at rmt closer.  
I wonder if grub can be used as a network bootable OS since it can password 
protect boot selections?  I've heard that only a four meg initrd ram disk is 
possible which evidently can decompress to sixteen megs.  For a modern 2.4.21 
kernel based Linux system I'm wondering how to fit into sixteen megs let alone 
whether or not I can use NFS to deal with the excess.  Maybe I can create a 
very small system around perhaps a 2.2 kernel, open a large ramdisk using that 
system, copy to it off the network, and then pivot root to a newer 2.4 kernel.

I want to run Linux out of ramdisk for backups as a Linux system with recent 
tools can generally mount, dump, and restore any PC filesystem.  One curiosity 
I have is if the MBR from one hard disk is compatible with another insofar as I 
might copy the MBR of a 30 gig drive and want to put it onto a different 
sized/different manufacturer's drive?

BTW: XOSL's mirroring capability is a really nice tool when messing around with
     Windows.  Other than the cd booting feature cut out, I've had really 
     good service with it.

BTW: The ltsp kernel for ltsp 3 has finally been progress patched and it looks 
     really nice :-)

As far as information on Linux from scratch I want to create a 2.4 system that
will run out of at most 32 megs of ramdrive and operate in 32 megs of ram, maybe 
use nfs if required, and provide the backup/restore capabilities I'm after.  

     --  Michael 



From danielx.j.petcher at intel.com  Mon Jul  7 09:50:02 2003
From: danielx.j.petcher at intel.com (Petcher, Danielx J)
Date: Mon Jul  7 09:50:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Etherboot.
Message-ID: <7D6F4CF55743264F8B23E20353705EEC0A8F50@orsmsx408.amr.corp.intel.com>

> -----Original Message-----
> From: robinsoq [mailto:robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com]
> Sent: Monday, July 07, 2003 3:55 AM
> To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
> Subject: [PLUG] Etherboot.

<snip>

> Reading Intel's doc it looks like PXE is an extension to dhcp and that
> it can work with any PXE compliant card with a single generic ethernet
> card driver. What I don't get is what as far as PXE my mobo has on it
> and if I want to flash a network boot program into my onboard ethernet
> how I go about that.  I don't even know if I can use an etherboot disk
> on this thing.  My mobo is a D845PEBT2.

<more snippage>

[Daniel Petcher] 

If there's an Intel NIC on that motherboard, there are two ways to get
at the Intel Boot Agent: IBAUTIL.EXE is a DOS-based utility that will
edit boot settings on the Flash EEPROM of the NIC to allow you to set
some parameters regarding what protocols it will listen for on POST.

The second way is to hit CTRL-S to interrupt the POST (Power-On Self
Test) at the moment your system is scanning the PCI bus for your NIC.
This action will bring-up a menu-driven interface for configuring the
NIC's Boot Agent.

I don't think I've expressed any opinions in this message, but if I
have, you can be assured that they are not necessarily the opinions of
Intel. I'm just a contractor testing network software drivers there.

-djp

From robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com  Mon Jul  7 12:47:02 2003
From: robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com (robinsoq )
Date: Mon Jul  7 12:47:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Comcast: Static IP
Message-ID: <200307071246.AA525992276@opusnet.com>

Can you sign up with a service that will adapt the Internet name servers to your 
current ip, a dynamic dns service?  I know the change for static ips when I changed 
over took a couple of days to sync.  I imagine there have to be dynamic services 
that update more quickly.  For one thing, a dial up ISP is usually a dynamic ip 
system where often times an individual modem has a a static ip assigned it but 
you don't always get the same modem.  Doesn't tinydns or Bind 9 have a runtime 
ip to ethernet name mapping mechanism?  Ed Sawicki is the expert on the latter.

Ironically, I have dns and dhcp but I use static assignments because I don't know how
to program a particular hostname to be assigned an ip in a certain range thereafter 
triggering a dns update at assignment time so that other people can look up that 
name at it's affective ip without my needing to maintain a range or ip list.

I don't run but three servers and my workstations/terminals probably don't need the
level of identification they have, but then again I want to allow internal servers.

>When I first got @Home, I had a static IP because my Mac couldn't handle the
>dynimic one they were trying to give us. When ATTBi took over, they removed
>the >static IP, but that was okay as we didn't use the Mac any more. I didn't
>aruge that. Now I am in need of a static IP for my server. Does anyone know of 
>any way to get one?? I REALLY need this, as a IP changing every 3 days sucks.

Try checking register.com and ask them if they can offer you a service that will
track your dynamic ip address.  Static ip at opus costs a one time $50 to get 
bridged which turns the router into a transparent pass through and then an 
additional $5/month or so for each static ip.

One trick you could try is to use your old PC to get the comcast to work and then
hook your Mac up to it to share the connection.  One thing to look at is if you can
get a true router box as opposed to an internal card where often these only work
under Windows because of the collusion that Microsoft and sadly Intel also are so
famous for.  In all fairness IBM, Compaq, HP, etc. have occasionally committed the
crime of collusion and rigging also.

      --  Michael Robinson

From sigma_x at comcast.net  Mon Jul  7 13:32:03 2003
From: sigma_x at comcast.net (sigma_x at comcast.net)
Date: Mon Jul  7 13:32:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Comcast: Static IP
Message-ID: <E19Zcdq-0001uR-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

I think that there are ways to do it like that (dydns.com/org? has a setup with 
my Linksys router..)

You bring up something interesting to me tho, about inner networks. I am 
guessing your servers in the inner network each have a seperate domain/sub-
domain, such as computer.domain.com right? How does one set something like that 
up, while still using a router? I had it working before I started using a 
router, but I don't know how to do with with a router..

--Roman

--
Roman Robinson
sigma_x at comcast.net
> Can you sign up with a service that will adapt the Internet name servers to your 
> current ip, a dynamic dns service?  I know the change for static ips when I 
> changed 
> over took a couple of days to sync.  I imagine there have to be dynamic services 
> that update more quickly.  For one thing, a dial up ISP is usually a dynamic ip 
> system where often times an individual modem has a a static ip assigned it but 
> you don't always get the same modem.  Doesn't tinydns or Bind 9 have a runtime 
> ip to ethernet name mapping mechanism?  Ed Sawicki is the expert on the latter.
> 
> Ironically, I have dns and dhcp but I use static assignments because I don't 
> know how
> to program a particular hostname to be assigned an ip in a certain range 
> thereafter 
> triggering a dns update at assignment time so that other people can look up that 
> name at it's affective ip without my needing to maintain a range or ip list.
> 
> I don't run but three servers and my workstations/terminals probably don't need 
> the
> level of identification they have, but then again I want to allow internal 
> servers.
> 
> >When I first got @Home, I had a static IP because my Mac couldn't handle the
> >dynimic one they were trying to give us. When ATTBi took over, they removed
> >the >static IP, but that was okay as we didn't use the Mac any more. I didn't
> >aruge that. Now I am in need of a static IP for my server. Does anyone know of 
> >any way to get one?? I REALLY need this, as a IP changing every 3 days sucks.
> 
> Try checking register.com and ask them if they can offer you a service that will
> track your dynamic ip address.  Static ip at opus costs a one time $50 to get 
> bridged which turns the router into a transparent pass through and then an 
> additional $5/month or so for each static ip.
> 
> One trick you could try is to use your old PC to get the comcast to work and 
> then
> hook your Mac up to it to share the connection.  One thing to look at is if you 
> can
> get a true router box as opposed to an internal card where often these only work
> under Windows because of the collusion that Microsoft and sadly Intel also are 
> so
> famous for.  In all fairness IBM, Compaq, HP, etc. have occasionally committed 
> the
> crime of collusion and rigging also.
> 
>       --  Michael Robinson
>

> >--

From bballfan at effectnet.com  Mon Jul  7 13:45:02 2003
From: bballfan at effectnet.com (Jon Ladwig)
Date: Mon Jul  7 13:45:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Comcast: Static IP
In-Reply-To: <E19ZbRI-0000V8-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <EBEKLKENGDOIDOCHLDGLKELACJAA.bballfan@effectnet.com>

My experience with attbi was that the dynamic ip did not
change. I had the same ip for a year; it even followed
when I moved a short distance. 

I expect comcast to be the same. The ip should only change if
- comcast changes something backstage (rare/unlikely)
- you allow the dhcp lease to expire
- you connect with a different machine (MAC address)

My setup has a linksys router directly after the cable modem.
Since I only request dhcp with it, and it renews the lease
automatically, my ip address doesn't change.



Does your ip really change every 3 days, or are you just
concerned it might? 


Jon

From heinlein at madboa.com  Mon Jul  7 13:53:02 2003
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon Jul  7 13:53:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Comcast: Static IP
In-Reply-To: <EBEKLKENGDOIDOCHLDGLKELACJAA.bballfan@effectnet.com>
References: <EBEKLKENGDOIDOCHLDGLKELACJAA.bballfan@effectnet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0307071348000.5779@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 7 Jul 2003, Jon Ladwig wrote:

> My experience with attbi was that the dynamic ip did not change. I
> had the same ip for a year; it even followed when I moved a short
> distance.
>
> I expect comcast to be the same. The ip should only change if
> - comcast changes something backstage (rare/unlikely)
> - you allow the dhcp lease to expire
> - you connect with a different machine (MAC address)

This has been my experience as well. I use zoneedit.com to maintain my
DNS records, and I've had to update my IP address very few (3, perhaps
4) times in the last three years.

If you're concerned about it, try running ntpd or something on one of
your machines. That'll generate enough network traffic to convice the
comcast network that your interface is in use. (Of course, you ought
to be running ntpd anyway. :-)

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>



From grishnav at egosurf.net  Mon Jul  7 14:01:02 2003

On Mon, 2003-07-07 at 13:52, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> On Mon, 7 Jul 2003, Jon Ladwig wrote:
> 
> > My experience with attbi was that the dynamic ip did not change. I
> > had the same ip for a year; it even followed when I moved a short
> > distance.

I had the same IP with @home from the time I signed up until the time
they went out of buisness.

I had the same IP with ATTbi from the time they bought @home, through
the Comcast merger, up until just over a week ago, where it has changed
once every 3 days since.

Sadly, each of the leases is good for 7 days. I can't see how this could
be helping anything. Their tables have to be very polluted at this
point; that or they keep getting flushed by mistake (intentionally??).

Fortunately, no-ip.com has been totally reliable throughout - even with
the client running on my 2k box instead of my linux box. :)

Grish <grishnav at egosurf.net>

From grishnav at egosurf.net  Mon Jul  7 14:03:02 2003

In-Reply-To: <E19ZciV-0002Ca-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

On Mon, 2003-07-07 at 13:35, sigma_x at comcast.net wrote:
> Humm.. I think that perhaps NoIP is not as good as something such as DyDNS 
> because they cost the same ($25/yr) and the latter one is intergrated with my 
> Linksys router. They also seem to have the same features.
> 

NoIP is free, otherwise I'd be using DynDNS right now.

NoIP only costs money if you need some of the extra features. I don't
know what your requirements are, but I've found that I don't. A simple
DNS entry (not a forwarder) was all that I needed, and they have
provided it for free without fail for several years now.

-- 
Grish <grishnav at egosurf.net>




From robbert at vafam.com  Mon Jul  7 15:36:02 2003
From: robbert at vafam.com (robbert at vafam.com)
Date: Mon Jul  7 15:36:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Comcast: Static IP
Message-ID: <105761734601@leo.hosting4u.net>

Just so you know, Comcast.net prohibits the running of servers on its network.  If you say this is your parent's service, perhaps you should consult with them first before you risk having their service cut off.  

>From it's acceptable use policy under the section of prohibited activity:

(xiv) run programs, equipment, or servers from the Premises that provide network content or any other services to anyone outside of your Premises LAN (Local Area Network), also commonly referred to as public services or servers. Examples of prohibited services and servers include, but are not limited to, e-mail, Web hosting, file sharing, and proxy services and servers; 

Robbert

----------

home right now. My IP has been having LOTS of traffic, but still changes. Lots 
as in a few GB per day, and constantly. I am going to go with DynDNS.org.

From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)

Subject: [PLUG] Comcast: Static IP
In-Reply-To: <105761734601@leo.hosting4u.net>
References: <105761734601@leo.hosting4u.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0307071550300.5779@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 7 Jul 2003 robbert at vafam.com wrote:

> (xiv) run programs, equipment, or servers from the Premises that
> provide network content or any other services to anyone outside of
> your Premises LAN (Local Area Network), also commonly referred to as
> public services or servers. Examples of prohibited services and
> servers include, but are not limited to, e-mail, Web hosting, file
> sharing, and proxy services and servers;

I've always interpreted the @home/att/comcast no-servers policy to
mean that I can't offer it to any person who doesn't ordinarily (and
legally) have console access to my home computers, i.e., my immediate
household.

That doesn't mean, however, that I can't provide an e-mail or a web
server for my own personal use when I'm away from home; I just need to
make sure that it's got a reasonable set of access restrictions.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>



From m at pdxlug.org  Mon Jul  7 16:06:02 2003

From robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com  Mon Jul  7 17:50:03 2003
From: robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com (robinsoq )
Date: Mon Jul  7 17:50:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Comcast: Static IP
Message-ID: <200307071749.AA344719508@opusnet.com>

There has been some class action against cable providers because of abuse
of customers who don't have an alternative.  Many people in West Linn who
want more than dial up are not only forced to buy cable, they are also 
forced to buy cable TV.  There was some deal that said third parties must
be allowed to offer their telecommunication services on the lines of the big
boys for free but that seems to have failed.  It surprises me that the 
telecommunications lobby is as strong as it is with the number of customers 
that are becoming angered over abusive practices and poor services.

Long term it looks like laws similar to the anti collusion ones are going to
be needed to prevent a few broadband providers from essentially dominating all
Internet use and setting all the rules.  

For that matter, when are the anti collusion laws going to be enforced?  I'd 
like to see mandatory labeling for any hardware product that is unless 
otherwise indicated assumeably generic.  Where products are not generic 
the information to use them with a wide variety of software platforms is 
withheld.  A prime example is the soundmaker Cadenza integrated into the 
D845PEBT2.  It's not just classes of hardware that are not Linux or 
other environment friendly, Gateway, Dell, ... have a horrendous history 
of modifying, rigging, hardware to fail in software environments 
other than their target .  Part of the problem with this hardware rigging
is that it is a nuisance even for users of the target operating system.  
It disgusts me that a driver should have to have a patch applied to it 
from the same OEM cd.  Is any PC compatible producer resisting collusion,
rigging, and design obscurity?  I've about had it with Intel.  It's ridiculous
to not be able to get a Microsoft sound card to work under Windows, and yes
I did check that 98SE is a supported choice.

The courts have said that noone can replace the PC, but how hard would it be?
Maybe the time has come for a new platform to be produced that is from the 
onset based on an open, gpl'ed, hardware design.  With gpl hardware debugging
Linux, at least the port to that platform, gets a whole lot easier.

     --  Michael C. Robinson

From jeme at brelin.net  Mon Jul  7 18:26:07 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Mon Jul  7 18:26:07 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Comcast: Static IP
In-Reply-To: <200307071749.AA344719508@opusnet.com>
References: <200307071749.AA344719508@opusnet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0307071818120.32009@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Mon, 7 Jul 2003, robinsoq  wrote:
> It surprises me that the telecommunications lobby is as strong as it is
> with the number of customers that are becoming angered over abusive
> practices and poor services.

Why does that surprise you?  The strength of the lobby has nothing to do
with the happiness of the customers (or even, really, their complacency),
but with the deep pockets of their campaign funds and the high paying jobs
they can offer the family members of the legislators and regulators.

> Long term it looks like laws similar to the anti collusion ones are
> going to be needed to prevent a few broadband providers from essentially
> dominating all Internet use and setting all the rules.

What's the need of laws that don't get enforced -- indeed, have no
mechanism for enforcement?

You can't put a corporation in jail or sentence it to death.  These legal
fictions have all the rights of individuals and can face almost none of
the dissuasive criminal punishments.  What do you do when a non-person
(with all the rights of a person except the right to vote -- at least with
a legal ballot) is convicted of breaking the people's law?  Fine it.
That's all.  This has a two-fold destructive effect:  First, it makes the
government dependent on crime for revenue and second, it means that you
can feel free to break the law as long as you have the money to cover it.

> For that matter, when are the anti collusion laws going to be enforced?

As soon as the public agencies remember they are agents of the public.

J.

On Mon, 2003-07-07 at 16:49, Dirk Ouellette wrote:
> From: Dirk Ouellette <hapibeli at comcast.net>
> To: PLUG <plug at lists.pdxlinux.org>, Austin Linux Users <alg at austinlug.org>
> Subject: Photo uploading
> Date: 07 Jul 2003 16:22:13 -0700
> 
> Did I see a short script in some past post for uploading photos from a
> camera that is recognized only as a usb mass storage device?
> TIA, Dirk


Most USB cameras are emulated SCSI devices. Try dmesg to see what device
it's using but normally it's the first unused SCSI device. In my case it
assigns /dev/sdb1 since /dev/sda is used by my 2940U2W.

Steve

From russj at dimstar.net  Mon Jul  7 20:29:02 2003
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Mon Jul  7 20:29:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] [Fwd: Photo uploading]
In-Reply-To: <1057621748.18735.14.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1057621748.18735.14.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <3F0A3A4A.9080504@dimstar.net>


Dirk Ouellette wrote:

>Did I see a short script in some past post for uploading photos from a
>camera that is recognized only as a usb mass storage device?
>TIA, Dirk
>

This is the script I use. It uses jhead to get the date/time of the 
photo and rename it:

#!/bin/bash
# A script to copy photographs from a Fuji finepix camera mounted
# as a vfat volume via USB and linux SCSI emulation /dev/sda1
# with the user option.

MOUNT_POINT=/local/camera

# Get the single command line parameter which should a non-existent 
directory
new_dir=$1

if [ -z $new_dir ]
then
        echo "Usage: $0 new_directory_name";
        exit -1;
fi

# Prevent overwriting of existing directories
if [ -f $new_dir -o -d $new_dir ]
then
        printf "That directory exists already - please rename it or 
choose a new name for this one\n";
        exit -1 ;
fi

mounted=`grep ${MOUNT_POINT} /etc/mtab | wc -c`
if [ $mounted -gt 0 ]
then
        umount ${MOUNT_POINT};
fi
mount ${MOUNT_POINT}
printf "Starting the copying now\n";
time cp -pr ${MOUNT_POINT}/dcim/100_fuji $new_dir
copy_count=`ls $new_dir | wc -l`;
printf "Copied $copy_count files to $new_dir\n";

printf "Renaming files\n";

jhead -ft -nf -c $new_dir/*.jpg;

# Clear up after the copying
umount ${MOUNT_POINT}

-- 
Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

Top post? http://www.caliburn.nl/topposting.html

From plug at ardware.net  Mon Jul  7 20:55:02 2003
From: plug at ardware.net (Andrew Dennis)
Date: Mon Jul  7 20:55:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Mouse Wheel - Still no luck
In-Reply-To: <20030708012554.GA24248@brian.brianandkellyderr.com>
References: <3F085699.1080807@ardware.net> <3F085F3C.5020501@ardware.net> <20030707022638.GA31383@quench.spiderland.net> <3F0A1778.3060402@ardware.net> <20030708012554.GA24248@brian.brianandkellyderr.com>
Message-ID: <3F0A40B4.5020100@ardware.net>

This is not a speed problem. This is more of a drawing problem.
For example if I try to execute a menu item, I will drag the arrow
down to the item I want and click the mouse button, then a half
second later, the arrow catches up and moves down to the next
item and then the mouse click occurs and I end up choosing the
wrong item.

So, the arrow is getting drawn every half second (a slight exageration
I am sure), instead of twenty time per second.

Is there anyway to adjust how often the mouse is refreshed?

Thanks

Andy

From marcm at dsl-only.net  Mon Jul  7 22:54:02 2003
From: marcm at dsl-only.net (Marc)
Date: Mon Jul  7 22:54:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Opening an image at a particular X-Y coordinate?
In-Reply-To: <32960.68.107.223.201.1057619140.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
References: <32960.68.107.223.201.1057619140.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
Message-ID: <20030708055346.GA19181@mentorg.com>

This may work for you:

    display -crop 48x64+176+118 -geometry 400% image.jpg

This will take a 48x64 pixel (width x height) block starting at top-left
coordinate 176,118 (i.e. centered on 200,150), zoom the image by 4x, and then
display it.

The "display" program is part of the ImageMagick package:

    http://www.imagemagick.org/
    
Good luck,

Marc

From aschlemm at comcast.net  Mon Jul  7 23:33:02 2003
From: aschlemm at comcast.net (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Mon Jul  7 23:33:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Comcast: Static IP
In-Reply-To: <E19Zcdq-0001uR-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <E19Zcdq-0001uR-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <200307072332.13689.aschlemm@comcast.net>

For VPN access to the office where we have a Netgear FVS318 firewall/NAT 
appliance and I've been using DynDNS.org's free service so I can use 
FQDNs as the remote end point on the VPN tunnel setup in the office. 
There are a number of DynDNS.org clients out there that support 
multiple DynDNS-type services and a variety of operating systems are 
also supported. 

I'm using "ddclient" on my OpenBSD firewall which is a Perl script. It 
gets invoked automatically by "dhclient" if my assigned IP address 
changes. I've also noticed that "ddclient" updates my DynDNS.org 
profile if it hasn't been updated for more than 15 days so I don't lose 
the domain name. DynDNS.org appears to revoke ownership of names that 
haven't been updated for a certain period of time.

Tony

On Monday 07 July 2003 13:30 pm, sigma_x at comcast.net wrote:

From aschlemm at comcast.net  Mon Jul  7 23:49:01 2003
From: aschlemm at comcast.net (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Mon Jul  7 23:49:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Comcast: Static IP
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0307071550300.5779@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
References: <105761734601@leo.hosting4u.net> <Pine.LNX.4.56.0307071550300.5779@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <200307072348.27926.aschlemm@comcast.net>

I've never seen any port probes hitting my firewall from my ISP since I 
lost I lost my @Home service back in 2001. @Home used to look for open 
news servers and were regularly probing port 119 on all of the systems 
on their network. 

Since my service went to ATTBI and now Comcast I've never seen them 
doing any port probing looking for any open services. Perhaps they have 
script kiddies in their employment since I get several 100 port probes 
a day from different locations. ;)

About the only services I run on my firewall are "ssh", "sendmail" and 
"ntpd" and I block all inbound connections to my firewall from the 
cable modem side. I run "ntpd" so all of my internal systems have a 
stratum 2 time server to sync with. I still use "tin" for reading 
usenet and it seems to want to use "mail" to send email and so I rolled 
my own "m4" file for a sendmail configuration and got sendmail working 
with my ISP's mail servers. 

I'm not running my own email server since I still get all of my inbound 
email via POP3 from Comcast's POP server and as I mentioned before all 
inbound connections are blocked on my firewall so no one can connect to 
any running service from the outside. 

Tony

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Jul  8 00:18:01 2003

On Mon, 7 Jul 2003, Russ Johnson wrote:
> Heh, you sound as if this AUP is news. :)

It's not new, but it's still outrageous.  I am still outraged and you all
should be, too.  They're trying to turn a network of peers into a deeply
divided network of castes -- particularly of "content providers" and
passive viewers.

The technology is removing the formerly obvious hierarchical
stratification of network connections, but business is working hard
against technology and hard against progress.

> It's the same AUP that AT&T and @Home had.
> No servers, none of the time.
> I've even heard of people that got their service shut off because they
> played a network game over their cable connection...

And it sickens me and I don't understand how anyone could accept such a
thing without shouting about it every day.  That was my whole point.

Just because it's been going on for a long time doesn't mean it's OK.

From robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com  Tue Jul  8 02:50:08 2003
From: robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com (robinsoq )
Date: Tue Jul  8 02:50:08 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux from scratch is interesting...
Message-ID: <200307080249.AA549388596@opusnet.com>

I'm using the Linux From Scratch guide put out October 2002.  Why is it so important not
to compile utilities with dynamic binding before chrooting into the LFS system?
I am wondering how to adapt this system as my real goal is to make this work over
nfs and boot off of network.  Maybe I only have to modify my approach to the init
scripts?

One curiosity I'm running into is with configure.  Does it detect what platform your
on affecting the compilation result?  I ask as I'm compiling on a Pentium III but want
this LFS system to work on a true 386 also.  I look at the gcc spec file on my host 
system, valhalla, don't see any optimizations though.  I guess another good question
is if there is a way to compile for multiple architectures and arrange to have the
system use the best library for the system it's running on?  Well, architecture is
probably the wrong term for 386 verses Pentium 4 or AMD K6 where I tend to think a 
different architecture would be an alpha or a PPC.  The IA32 architecture should be
contained in everything from an AMD K6 to a Pentium 4 to an IDT Winchip I would 
think, unless that's just the Intel implementation of x86.

Anyone know why optimizations crash the compilation of binutils?  Well that's what the
guide said would happen anyways though my compile didn't crash so I guess I'm not 
optimized then.

My LFS system is being built in an extra partition on my host box.  I'm wondering if
the host box should have this system in it's fstab and integrity check the partition
for it at boot?  Will my network clients fsck my LFS system?

Anyone know why diffutils, a special utility for decrypting function labels produced
from C++ code where overloading of functions is possible, and other various tools are
needed in a base Linux system?  Bash I can see, but why do I need gawk?  

Anyone have an example of using strings from the binutils package?

This static system I'm producing, I suppose if it works on a 386 on up that I can tar
it up and use it later to build a dynamically linked Linux system from scratch where 
a host distribution is on the box already and the custom system goes on another 
partition.  Do I need seperate swap partitions for these two systems?  Any tips when
I get to the nfs export part?   

GCC-3.2 seems to have some fascinating bugs.  What's this copying problem compiling gcc
with a local gcc-2.2.3 compiler when a static structure is passed all about?  Why not distribute patched code instead of providing a patch?  Valhalla has gcc-2.2.5 so I guess
I don't have to worry about this bug.

     --  Michael 



From robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com  Tue Jul  8 04:56:01 2003
From: robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com (robinsoq )
Date: Tue Jul  8 04:56:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ipchains
Message-ID: <200307080455.AA68157726@opusnet.com>



---------- Original Message ----------------------------------
From: "Billy Dimaculangan" <bmdimaculangan at bhpi.com.ph>
Reply-To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Date:  Tue, 8 Jul 2003 17:43:13 +0800

>i found this entry in the ipchains config, how do i delete this entry?
>
>ACCEPT     tcp  ----l-  0.0.0.0/0            202.61.68.98          * ->   80
>
>
>
>TY.
>
>
>_______________________________________________
>PLUG mailing list
>PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
>http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>


First hint is to use the verbose flag, ipchains -nvL.  If you can get the rule number
you can delete that specific rule.  Another option if you have scripted the firewall that
you want is to shutdown your network interfaces temporarily, flush all rulesets, set your
default input, output, and forward rules to ACCEPT, and then apply your firewall.  In the
days when I used portsentry I would have problems with being unable to get rid of reject
rules and I also think that it was programmed to reject anyone who would probe the wrong
port.  Unfortunately as much as this is a crackers way to find a weakness it is also a
valid hack in some cases in determining what services are available and I ran into 
blocking people I didn't want to block.  Linux has powerful networking code where many
of the tools are just wrappers with limited functionality.  Another possibility is to
reprogram your syslogd by changing /etc/syslog.conf.  What log level does ipchains use
anyways?  I use to have a syslog rule that logged packet messages to a seperate file
from the rest of the logs and even managed to program firewall rules to allow a friend
to do udp tunneling not knowing the ports that needed to be opened ahead of time.

     --  Michael  



From vincentdamewood at yahoo.com  Tue Jul  8 06:11:02 2003
From: vincentdamewood at yahoo.com (Vincent Damewood)
Date: Tue Jul  8 06:11:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux from scratch is interesting...
In-Reply-To: <200307080249.AA549388596@opusnet.com>
Message-ID: <20030708131026.30671.qmail@web13803.mail.yahoo.com>

--- robinsoq  <robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com> wrote:
> I'm using the Linux From Scratch guide put out
> October 2002.  Why is it so important not
> to compile utilities with dynamic binding before
> chrooting into the LFS system?

Because they are linked against your current
libraries, when you chroot, the libraries don't exist
any more and all your binaries become broken. You will
eventually rebuild everything again dynamicly, only
linked against the right copies of the libraries.

<Snip>

> One curiosity I'm running into is with configure. 
> Does it detect what platform your
> on affecting the compilation result?

Yes.

> I ask as I'm
> compiling on a Pentium III but want
> this LFS system to work on a true 386 also.

Here's how:
http://hints.linuxfromscratch.org/hints/crosscompiling-x86.txt

<snip>

> Anyone know why diffutils, a special utility for
> decrypting function labels produced
> from C++ code where overloading of functions is
> possible, and other various tools are
> needed in a base Linux system?  Bash I can see, but
> why do I need gawk?  

I thought diffutils was used for comparing files and
creating and applying patches. I've never heard of it
having anything to do with C++ function overloading.

> Anyone have an example of using strings from the
> binutils package?

It may not be Linux, but I can use the strings program
to get some information about my kernel in FreeBSD.

<snip> 

> Do I need seperate swap partitions for
> these two systems?

No. A single swap partition will work.

<snip>

I hope I've managed to be of some assistance.


__________________________________

SBC Yahoo! DSL - Now only $29.95 per month!
http://sbc.yahoo.com

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Jul  8 08:54:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue Jul  8 08:54:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux from scratch is interesting...
In-Reply-To: <200307080249.AA549388596@opusnet.com>
References: <200307080249.AA549388596@opusnet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0307080818210.9926@shaft.bitmine.net>

[Michael, can you adjust your linewrap so that it either does not wrap
lines or wraps them at <80 columns.  Those long lines make reading a pain
and I think some are as likely to skip the message as try to decipher it.]

On Tue, 8 Jul 2003, robinsoq  wrote:
> Why is it so important not to compile utilities with dynamic binding
> before chrooting into the LFS system?

As Vincent Damewood pointed out, this is because you'd be linking against
libraries or versions of libraries that just won't exist in your chrooted
system.

I know the LFS book says that you should rebuild everything dynamic and
that's a good idea, but I also like to keep copies of the static binaries
in /sbin just in case /lib is damaged or inaccessible at some point.

> I am wondering how to adapt this system as my real goal is to make this
> work over nfs and boot off of network.  Maybe I only have to modify my
> approach to the init scripts?

You'll also have to build with the most generic options for your processor
family in order to maintain binary compatibility.

> One curiosity I'm running into is with configure.  Does it detect what
> platform your on affecting the compilation result?

Yes.

> I ask as I'm compiling on a Pentium III but want this LFS system to work
> on a true 386 also.

Right.  There are environment variables that can control the options make
passes to gcc.  The cross-compiling hint will help.

> My LFS system is being built in an extra partition on my host box.  I'm
> wondering if the host box should have this system in it's fstab and
> integrity check the partition for it at boot?  Will my network clients
> fsck my LFS system?

I've never built LFS with a filesystem that requires fsck.

> Anyone know why diffutils, a special utility for decrypting function
> labels produced from C++ code where overloading of functions is
> possible, and other various tools are needed in a base Linux system?

diffutils is the GNU diff and patch programs for noting the difference
between files and generating and applying patches.  It's absolutely vital
when compiling software from multiple sources.

<URL: http://www.gnu.org/software/diffutils/diffutils.html >

> Bash I can see, but why do I need gawk?

gawk is the GNU implementation of awk.  It's used in shell scripts
throughout a system.  You'll also find that the LFS book will include
short scripts for patching or modifying a particular configure script or
Makefile and those scripts may well need awk.

And, quite frankly, a unix system without awk just isn't a unix system.

> Anyone have an example of using strings from the binutils package?

I've used strings to look for undocumented command options and all kinds
of odd things.  It can be used to identify some trojans, too.

> Why not distribute patched code instead of providing a patch?

One of the main points, for me, of build a system from scratch is knowing
exactly how it differs from the generic source as created by the package
maintainers.  I download the source from the maintianer's site and check
it against any available signature keys and then apply patches myself.

People used to ask me WHY I went to these pains to keep track of the
software on my computer.  I don't know that I have an answer that I can
put together in english and make any real sense.  But the answer would be
very similar to the answer to why I ride a fixed gear bike.  Perhaps I
just like to be in as direct control of my machines as possible.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org



From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Tue Jul  8 09:10:03 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Tue Jul  8 09:10:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Mouse Wheel - Still no luck
In-Reply-To: <3F0A40B4.5020100@ardware.net>
References: <3F085699.1080807@ardware.net> <3F085F3C.5020501@ardware.net>
	 <20030707022638.GA31383@quench.spiderland.net>
	 <3F0A1778.3060402@ardware.net>
	 <20030708012554.GA24248@brian.brianandkellyderr.com>
	 <3F0A40B4.5020100@ardware.net>
Message-ID: <1057680536.1182.18.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Mon, 2003-07-07 at 20:55, Andrew Dennis wrote:
> This is not a speed problem. This is more of a drawing problem.
> For example if I try to execute a menu item, I will drag the arrow
> down to the item I want and click the mouse button, then a half
> second later, the arrow catches up and moves down to the next
> item and then the mouse click occurs and I end up choosing the
> wrong item.
> 
> So, the arrow is getting drawn every half second (a slight exageration
> I am sure), instead of twenty time per second.
> 
> Is there anyway to adjust how often the mouse is refreshed?

My guess is that your video card or the X server driver for it doesn't
support hardware cursor, which makes it fall back to software cursor,
which can be pretty slow.  Please send us the output in the X.log file
after running the command:

X -probeonly >~/X.log 2>&1

Wil

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Tue Jul  8 09:13:02 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Tue Jul  8 09:13:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ipchains
In-Reply-To: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCCEFOCNAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
References: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCCEFOCNAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <1057680708.1182.21.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Tue, 2003-07-08 at 02:43, Billy Dimaculangan wrote:
> i found this entry in the ipchains config, how do i delete this entry?
> 
> ACCEPT     tcp  ----l-  0.0.0.0/0            202.61.68.98          * ->   80

Use:

iptables --line-numbers -vl

to get the line number of the rule, then:

iptables -D <WHATEVER_CHAIN> <LINE_NUMBER>

See the man page for iptables for an explanation.

Wil

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Tue Jul  8 09:14:02 2003
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor Pikus)
Date: Tue Jul  8 09:14:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] apt problems
In-Reply-To: <1057673002.2898.42.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0307080910370.14985-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

I've seen this once, but not on RH9. If one of the packages it wants to
update is apt or rpm, try updating these packages manually.
If it does not help, you can remove all files under /var/state/apt and
/var/cache/apt (but not directories!) and have it start from scratch.

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Tue Jul  8 09:22:02 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)

Subject: [PLUG] apt problems
In-Reply-To: <1057673002.2898.42.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Tue, 2003-07-08 at 07:03, Dirk Ouellette wrote:
> I hope I'm not being rude in posting here, but I have a problem with apt
> on my RedHat 9 box. When I apt-get update or try to upgrade,my system
> gets as far as ;

Posting a Red Hat question to a Debian isn't necessarily rude, but as
I'm sure you'll find from the flames you get, kinda stupid :)

> Fetched 1500kB in 27s (55.4kB/s)
> Reading Package Lists... 66%
> 
> and then hangs. This came on out of nowhere though possibly when I
> upgraded my kernel with up2date[ Redhat's app].

Have you done an 'rpm --rebuilddb' recently?  Are there any obvious lock
files in /var/lib/rpm?  You might find you'll need to manually dump and
rebuild the RPM database using the steps described by Jeff Johnson here:
http://www.rpm.org/hintskinks/repairdb/

I've got an issue right now with my own RPM database, but haven't
actually tried to rebuild it.

Wil

From jon at vertex-networking.com  Tue Jul  8 09:27:08 2003
From: jon at vertex-networking.com (Jon Ladwig)
Date: Tue Jul  8 09:27:08 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Comcast: Static IP
In-Reply-To: <E19ZbRI-0000V8-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <EBEKLKENGDOIDOCHLDGLCEKPCJAA.jon@vertex-networking.com>

My experience with attbi was that the dynamic ip did not
change. I had the same ip for a year; it even followed
when I moved a short distance. 

I expect comcast to be the same. The ip should only change if
- comcast changes something backstage (rare/unlikely)
- you allow the dhcp lease to expire
- you connect with a different machine (MAC address)

My setup has a linksys router directly after the cable modem.
Since I only request dhcp with it, and it renews the lease
automatically, my ip address doesn't change.



Does your ip really change every 3 days, or are you just
concerned it might? 


Jon

From icepirate at comcast.net  Tue Jul  8 09:28:00 2003
From: icepirate at comcast.net (Mark Morgan)
Date: Tue Jul  8 09:28:00 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Mouse Wheel - Next Question
In-Reply-To: <3F085F3C.5020501@ardware.net>
References: <3F085699.1080807@ardware.net> <3F085F3C.5020501@ardware.net>
Message-ID: <3F087A3A.9060004@comcast.net>

Andrew Dennis wrote:
>> From:   /usr/X11/XFConfig:
>>
>> Section "InputDevice"
>>  Driver        "mouse"
>>  Identifier    "Mouse[1]"
>>  Option        "Device"        "/dev/mice"
>>  Option        "Emulate3Buttons"       "on"
>>  Option        "Name"          "AutoDetected"
>>  Option        "Protocol"      "ImPS/2"
>>  Option        "Vendor"        "AutoDetected"
>>  Option        "ZAxisMapping" "Y"
>>  Option        "Resolution" "1"
>> EndSection>>

Here's what I've got.  Never had a problem with mine.

Section "InputDevice"
   Identifier  "Mouse1"
   Driver      "mouse"
   Option      "Device"          "/dev/input/mice"
   Option      "SendCoreEvents"	"true"
   Option      "Protocol"        "IMPS/2"
   Option      "ZAxisMapping"    "4 5"
   Option      "Buttons"         "5"
EndSection




From holger at selover.net  Tue Jul  8 10:11:02 2003
From: holger at selover.net (Holger Stephan)
Date: Tue Jul  8 10:11:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Photo uploading
In-Reply-To: <1057618727.18735.1.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1057618727.18735.1.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1057684216.2577.236.camel@halo>

Dirk,

Since none of the experts answer, you'll have to make do with mine for
now: 

I use an USB reader to upload from a flash card. RedHat assigns it to
/dev/sda1. I added this to /etc/fstab:

/dev/sda1 /mnt/usb vfat user,uid=500,noauto  0  0

(500 is me). Then I created an empty directory /mnt/usb and allowed
write access to my account. Now I use a script to suck up the pictures:

if [ $# -ne 1 -a $# -ne 2 ];
then
  echo 1>&2 "Usage: copyusb destinationpath"
  echo 1>&2 "   destinationpath: This path will be created if it does
not exist."
  exit 1
fi

if [ ! -d $1 ]; then
    mkdir $1
fi
if [ -d $1/usb ]; then
    rm -rf $1/usb
fi
mount /mnt/usb
cp -vr /mnt/usb $1/
chmod -R a+rw $1/usb
umount /mnt/usb
echo "Done!"
# End of script

- Holger

On Mon, 2003-07-07 at 16:22, Dirk Ouellette wrote:
    Did I see a short script in some past post for uploading photos from a
    camera that is recognized only as a usb mass storage device?
    TIA, Dirk
    
    
    _______________________________________________
    PLUG mailing list
    PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

From robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com  Tue Jul  8 15:21:01 2003
From: robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com (robinsoq )

>
>>Just because it's been going on for a long time doesn't mean it's OK.
>>
>Agreed.
>
>Russ

I'll second that, Long term the options are to try and bring DSL where there
is cable and dissatisfied customers or perhaps WiFi when DSL isn't a viable
option.  The other possibility is satellite, unforunately, the Starband 360 
which seems to be the major two way choice is Windows only and I for one am 
bothered by it's poor refresh characteristics during browsing.  Cable users 
sadly probably are better off than their satellite counterparts, and to 
think that cable gets blasted so often yet no providers are smart enough 
to actually offer a better deal in order to compete.  In some ways what do 
you lobby for and who do you lobby to cause efforts to be made in the public 
good on this issue.  I for one would love being able to have Linux on a high 
speed satellite connection with good range without paying too much or dragging
Redmond in.  I'll bet you can argue that satellite and cable are often rigged
technologies, but how do you go about that intelligently and what is success
in today's environment?

     --  Michael

 upsetting all the anti open relay sites.  For one

 Linux The Ultimate Solution, also blasts qmail for all 
 the extra stuff, daemontools etc., that it needs and
 claims that the mailing lists don't answer a lot of
 good qmail questions.  I for one haven't done very well
 with the Life with Qmail site.  Qmail may be a better
 choice when it comes to serious mail needs if your
 going to read the source and actually be able to 
 understand it, an option that can be quite time 
 consuming and a massive challenge to focus.

From robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com  Tue Jul  8 17:41:01 2003
From: robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com (robinsoq )
Date: Tue Jul  8 17:41:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Adventures in ISC dhcp 2...
Message-ID: <200307081740.AA250020114@opusnet.com>

What group does the group section refer to?

If I could say group and then the mnemonic label
of a shared-network I'd defined before I'd know,
but it doesn't seem to work that way.

Do you put the group section in the shared
network section you want it to be associated
with?

I ask as I'm implementing dhcp2 backup
server on a gateway and there are two 
different shared networks on that box.

As far as failover, I'm guessing that I 
need to define the same static mappings 
and then have two different dynamic 
ranges on my two dhcp servers.



BTW: I have a working DNS that replace
     the staticly mapped hostnames with
     their ip addresses.  It might be
     nice to replace this scheme with
     dynamic dns and a range for each
     subnetwork I define.  I don't subnet
     having an open class C mask but I do
     put computers in the same room within
     blocks of 15 ip's a piece.  In a
     sense I arbitrarily subnet.

     My DNS is a series of A records, I
     don't how I'd map MAC addresses to
     a range of ips + hostname and  
     have the DNS dynamicly update the
     hostname to ip mappings so that I
     don't need to keep a list of 
     numbers. I want to avoid losing the 
     ability to access a workstation or 
     terminal by hostname instead of ip.

     Essentially I have this:

     192.168.1.0 to 192.168.1.15   # server room
     192.168.1.16 to 192.168.1.31  # network 1
     192.168.1.32 to 192.168.1.47  # network 2
     192.168.1.48 to 192.168.1.63  # network 3
       ...  up to network 6 ...
     192.168.1.112 to 192.168.1.127 # Dynamic Range 1
     192.168.1.128 to 192.168.1.143 # Dynamic Range 2
       ...  my Jetdirect 170X box is at...
     192.168.1.254
       ...  And I guess that ...
     192.168.1.255
 
     is the broadcast for all nets I defined.



I don't know how I'd do failover to a second
server for the network booting part of the
following template.  For starters I want
workstations to be able to get their mappings
in a failure from a second dhcp server where 
the static mappings for booting up as a 
terminal are the same as the mappings that
are needed if you are going to load up as a
workstation.  I'm guessing the second dhcp 
server needs a different dynamic ip range 
than Dynamic Range 1.

Just so everyone knows, in the event my
primary dhcp is down it probably means
that both my mailhub and X server are 
down also.  My master lan dns used to
be on my mail server but I've moved it
out to one of my two gateways so that
my master/slave inside and out servers
are on my gateways.  Out refers to the
name servers for robinson-west.com 
serving Internet clients.

I'm using LTSP and for one don't want NFS and
X-Windows on a gateway box.  Do I need to
put the backup dhcp server on a non gateway
box?  I want to avoid the latter as it means
another server since I only have one behind my 
two Internet gateways.  My X server will
eventually by my master mail hub where this
is the only machine that will allow accessing
the spool anyways.  Slave mail servers are
evidently not supposed to allow such access
to the mail spool merely existing to feed
mail to the master hub when it comes back.
I exclusively use terminal booting for mail
access when I have my own site up and 
eventually I want to use my Linux From Scratch
system as a netbooted Linuce for backing
up workstations similar to the way one would
use Norton Ghost. 

Should I transition to dhcp 3 for failover
and how would I get there from my 
template?

Without a backup dhcp server for workstations,
my slave Bind 8.4 name server serving my lan
is pointless since I'm still facing single
point of failure.

NOTE: The template has some questions in it...

i.e., Say this is a template for dhcp server 1 "..."

"
# Is this needed for clients I don't statically define
# later on in the last part of the group section?

allow unknown-clients;



shared-network foo
{

     default-lease-time 7200;
     max-lease-time     7200;

     subnet 192.168.1.0 255.255.255.0
     {

            # First dynamic ip block.
            range 192.168.1.112 192.168.1.127;
     }
}



group
{

   option broadcast-address ...;
  
   option routers ...;

   option domain-name-server ...;

   option root-path ....;

   use-host-decl-name  on; # <- What does this do?

   option log-server ...;



   # This enables vendor tags.

   option option-128 e4:45:74:68:00:00;



   # Don't know why a default needed here.

   filename "/lts/vmlinuz-ltsp.nb";



   # Following is the motd for bootp menu.
   option option-184 "...";
   option option-185 "...";
                  .
                  .
                  .
   option option-187 "...";
   option option-189 "...";



   # Set timeout for menu and default selection.

   option option-160 "timeout=15:default=192";



   # The actual bootp menu.
  
   option option-192 "Linux (Default):::/lts/vmlinuz-ltsp.nb";
                  .
                  .
                  .
   option option-197 "Redhat 9 install:::RH9-install";



   # The hosts that are fixed follow.

   host aaa
   {

        hardware ethernet "replace with aaa's MAC address";
        fixed-address aaa.ayyy.bzzz;
        option option-188 "Welcome aaa";
   }

       .
       .
       .

   host zzz
   {

        hardware ethernet "replace with zzz's MAC address";
        fixed-address zzz.ayyy.bzzz;
        option option-188 "Welcome zzz";
   }
}
"

For the second server I guess the only change would be that
the shared-network foo section should have a different range.

Sorry about the length here :-)

    -- Michael C. Robinson

From pietvw at onlinemac.com  Tue Jul  8 20:00:02 2003
From: pietvw at onlinemac.com (Piet van Weel)
Date: Tue Jul  8 20:00:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Zoom 3025C Modem (Gack) Win Modem
In-Reply-To: <20030619181528.GF11783@brian.brianandkellyderr.com>
Message-ID: <000001c345c6$1dcfbaa0$8a425cc6@gamma>

Greetings...

OK... I wish to thank all of you who extended me a gracious hand in
getting the modem up and running.

I finally got it up and running, and now that I know how.. it's fairly
simple!! 

Simply go to this website http://www.linuxant.com/drivers/ (I have a
Zoom 3025C).. select the driver for the Distro and Kernel you're using.
Download it... install it... and away you go...

Once again... thanks for your outstanding understanding support!!!

Piet van Weel

From sean at fork.com  Tue Jul  8 20:29:01 2003
From: sean at fork.com (Sean Whitney)
Date: Tue Jul  8 20:29:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Comcast: Static IP
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0307080014180.4564@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <105761734601@leo.hosting4u.net>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0307071556540.29989@shaft.bitmine.net>
	 <3F0A3942.2030607@dimstar.net>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0307080014180.4564@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <1057721276.18940.4.camel@einstein.seansdomain.org>

I hate to be the one to rain on everyone's parade but the only reason
that cable companies are as draconian as they are is because government
regulations allow them too.  Data services provided by cable companies
fall under different rules than data services provided by telephone
companies.

The moment that the FCC get's it's mind changed by telco's that they are
competing at an unfair advantage with cable companies for data services
it's all over.  The AUP from your DSL provider will read the same as for
a cable company.

But there's trade-offs. The regulations concerning wait times for cable
companies call centers are much more stringent that telephone companies.

Sean

On Tue, 2003-07-08 at 00:18, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> On Mon, 7 Jul 2003, Russ Johnson wrote:
> > Heh, you sound as if this AUP is news. :)
> 
> It's not new, but it's still outrageous.  I am still outraged and you all
> should be, too.  They're trying to turn a network of peers into a deeply
> divided network of castes -- particularly of "content providers" and
> passive viewers.
> 
> The technology is removing the formerly obvious hierarchical
> stratification of network connections, but business is working hard
> against technology and hard against progress.
> 
> > It's the same AUP that AT&T and @Home had.
> > No servers, none of the time.
> > I've even heard of people that got their service shut off because they
> > played a network game over their cable connection...
> 
> And it sickens me and I don't understand how anyone could accept such a
> thing without shouting about it every day.  That was my whole point.
> 
> Just because it's been going on for a long time doesn't mean it's OK.
> 
> J.
-- 
Sean Whitney <sean at fork.com>

From Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com  Wed Jul  9 10:45:02 2003
From: Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com (Daggett, Steve)
Date: Wed Jul  9 10:45:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Comcast: Static IP
Message-ID: <05AD3C7EEA42D311809300902785AC8A0559C62C@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>

> Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> Gadzooks! Why would ANYONE willfully endure a commercial 
> organization's
> such blatant contempt for their customers?  And why would 
> anyone willfully
> contribute to this heinous and egregious subversion of the 
> entire design
> of the internet?

  I agree with the sentiment, but you should keep in mind is that these
rules usually aren't targeted at the intelligent, skilled, and respectful
users.  They're primarily directed at the idiots and losers.  Like a 16 year
old hosting a porn or gaming site for a hundred thousand of his or her
closest friends, or some ninny trying to start up a commercial site on their
cable modem.  The Internet is "magic" to 99% of the population.  They don't
know or care how much traffic their actions create.  

  The nasty be true fact is that the infrastructure behind a cable modem or
DSL is not a limitless quantity.  Bandwidth is a limited, shared, resource.
It costs money.  There has to be some method for protecting the majority of
the users from the actions of the few.

  I agree that Comcast's, formerly ATTBi's, restriction are extreme.  Even
with the restrictions, I occasionally enable incoming HTTP or SSH on my
cable modem connection.  I keep my activities at a low level.  I've never
been threatened or had my service interrupted.  

  I'm also working on a new End User Agreement for a wireless ISP project.
One of my goals is to allow the customer to run servers, but put in enough
restrictions to protect the bandwidth from rouge users.  It also need to be
understandable to the non-technical and pass legal review... its not an easy
task.  The *easy* way out is to simply say *no servers* for normal users.
Servers would only be allowed, at a higher rate and a bandwidth cap, for
business users.  My partners and I are still looking at the issue...

Steve D...



From paul at lankow.net  Wed Jul  9 11:34:02 2003
From: paul at lankow.net (Paul Lankow)
Date: Wed Jul  9 11:34:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Comcast: Static IP
In-Reply-To:

References: 
    <05AD3C7EEA42D311809300902785AC8A0559C62C@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>
Message-ID: <2092.192.168.1.252.1057775568.squirrel@localhost>

>> Jeme A Brelin wrote:
>> Gadzooks! Why would ANYONE willfully endure a commercial
>> organization's
>> such blatant contempt for their customers?  And why would
>> anyone willfully
>> contribute to this heinous and egregious subversion of the
>> entire design of the internet?

You also need to keep in mind that this service is marketed as for
entertainment use in the home. Sadly, the rules are required to protect
the masses. It is no different than a lifeguard at a pool. If you're by
yourself, horseplay is your business. If you're in a crowd, it's
everybody's business. If you want to run servers and have a static IP,
I'm sure they have a product (a bigger pool) to accommodate that, at an
appropriate price. @Home had a corresponding @Work service. I suspect
Comcast has something similar.

I have been very happy with the service I get considering the price I
pay. I run servers for personal use only, which I believe is in the
spirit of their rules. Since my bandwidth usage is in-line with a home
entertainment system, they've never asked me to shut them down.

Regards,
Paul

____________________________
We can not direct the wind,
But we can adjust the sails.
-Bertha Calloway




From robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com  Wed Jul  9 12:57:02 2003
From: robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com (robinsoq )
Date: Wed Jul  9 12:57:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Secure network booting...
Message-ID: <200307091256.AA656015658@opusnet.com>

It's easy enough to set up a bootp menu and dos or Linux install
images.  Trouble is, what options do I have to bring authentication
into the picture before anyone is allowed to network boot?  Now for
memtest and X terminal booting there isn't a problem so I don't need
to worry about those options.  This Linux system I'm building from
scratch for intended use as a restore system will offer root
access to the local drives of a client's machine facilitating
dumping to network or restoration from it.  The latter system should
not be bootable or usable without a client authenticating where it's
preferable to authenticate against my samba domain controller.  I 
probably need wrapper scripts to take care of root access to the
tape drive.  I may want to have rmt, I'm looking at just using tar.
Right now my DI30 drive is on my 386 as I can't seem to get it to
work without the 2.2.14 kernel and an apparently proprietary 
patched ide tape driver.  Otherwise I'd have the tape drive on the
same machine I have my dump drive on.  To some degree I'm debating
whether or not NFS is a better choice on the tape server than samba
because of the large files involved.

     --  Michael C. Robinson

From Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com  Wed Jul  9 14:01:02 2003
From: Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com (Daggett, Steve)
Date: Wed Jul  9 14:01:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] KNOPPIX help
Message-ID: <05AD3C7EEA42D311809300902785AC8A0559C62F@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>

Vincent Yau: 
> 
> I just booted KNOPPIX and it is running great.  I am very tempted
> to mount my harddrive and see if I can salvage some data.
> I did not remember what filesystem it was using, I tried both 
> ext2 and ext3,
> but both options complain that it is the wrong filesystem.
> 
> Is there any other trick I can try?  Thanks for any tip/pointer.
> 

  In order:

  Check your boot logs for errors. See if the drive was identified during
boot.

  cat /proc/ide/hda/model

  You should see the drive model number.  This will tell you if the drive is
on the IDE bus and the controller is responding to IDE commands.

  fdisk /dev/hda, and then "p" to print the partition table, type "q" to
exit

  It will show you that the disk is active and the partition table is
intact.  

  fsck -N /dev/hda  

  fsck should show what kind of file systems it finds on the disk.  

Steve D...

: Does anyone have recommendations for VoIP software?  Ideally I'd like it
: to be free (or very low cost), able to make computer-to-computer calls and

: on Linux, but it would be a nice bonus if it did.

My bandwidth is high, with out servers..In the last month, my personal
computer has done 49GB down, and 14GB up. Given, a little bit of that is
inside the network, but most is outside. This month, I think it will be a
lot lower as I have stoped using p2p (The 14GB up is NOT from p2p - I never
shared), but still I use a lot of traffic between my computers and my
friends...

I am looking into a higher-speed (higher-pay..) Comcast package that will
allow servers, because I would like to be allowed to do what I do now but do
more of it (instead of hosting a small site with nothing useful on it,
hosting a useful server with games or something), and then I could make one
of my test servers a production server :)

--Roman

From robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com  Wed Jul  9 19:58:02 2003
From: robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com (robinsoq )
Date: Wed Jul  9 19:58:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Working on building a Linux system from scratch...
Message-ID: <200307091957.AA1080754292@opusnet.com>

I'm going through Linux From Scratch version 4 
and am up to installing Perl in chapter 6.  
Looking ahead I wonder if I need the shadow 
password suite considering that my goal is to 
NFS export this system to network clients?  
Some where I've heard that shadow passwords 
and NFS don't work together.  Besides, I'd 
rather not use a local password database 
anyways.

Another thing I'm wondering is if I need 
autoconf, automake, m4, bin86, lilo, and
patch since I don't want to have compilers 
on this system and I don't want to set this
up as a system that I boot the host system 
up with?

I guess Flex is needed, along with bison...

I would like to authenticate network clients 
to to the passwords on my samba server before 
they are allowed to use my custom Linux system.

The real trick is figuring out how to turn 
this into a system that works via ramdisk and 
NFS mounts for multiple network clients 
simultaneously.  If I remeber right, there is 
a package for replacing the standard tmp dir 
in this situtation and a way to have seperate 
swap files created for each client.  I guess 
/usr would need to be exported read-only.

Can grub password protect and boot a network 
image?  Can grub be booted off a tftp server?  
Anyone have a recipe for doing this?

BTW:  I found the PXE client on my P4 but how 
      do I set up a PXE server
      on my Linux box?

    --  Michael

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Jul 10 15:15:03 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu Jul 10 15:15:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Anti-Spam Mail Address Encoding (fwd)
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0307101512070.30161-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  You admins and oysters might find this useful. It was posted on the
postfix mail list.

Rich

Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President

                       Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
            2404 SW 22nd Street | Troutdale, OR 97060-1247 | U.S.A.
 + 1 503-667-4517 (voice) | + 1 503-667-8863 (fax) | rshepard&#64;appl-ecosys.com
                         http://www.appl-ecosys.com/

---------- Forwarded message ----------

Heh, this is a pretty funny hack.

If you're generating dynamic content on a web page, you might be interested
in something that someone posted today on Perlmonks. It's a pair of
functions to take an IP address and a timestamp, then encrypt it against a
private key with Blowfish, turn it into ASCII... and back again.

Why would you want to do a thing like this? Well when you receive a spam
addressed to one of these addresses, you can determine who harvested you,
and when. You should be able to correlate that with your web log.  That
would be information that a lot of people would be interested in, methinks.

Anyway, the whole article is here, enjoy:

   http://www.perlmonks.org/index.pl?node_id=272924

David
