From robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com  Thu Jul 10 17:54:02 2003
From: robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com (robinsoq )
Date: Thu Jul 10 17:54:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] How something compiles...
Message-ID: <200307101753.AA160497994@opusnet.com>



---------- Original Message ----------------------------------
From: Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net>
Reply-To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Date:  Wed, 9 Jul 2003 23:38:15 -0700 (PDT)

>
>On Wed, 9 Jul 2003, robinsoq  wrote:
>> If you don't put optimizations into the spec file for gcc will configure
>> in general detect what your compiling on and optimize for that?
>
>What spec file?
>
Do an rpm -ql gcc on a Redhat 7.x or newer system and the spec file under
/usr/lib/gcc... something is where you can optimize your compiler
flags.  Strangely though, having done nothing to the global compiler flags
I don't get it why with my Linux From Scratch system that it would by 
default be compiling to the architecture of the host system.  Morover, I'm 
curious what is involved in compiling Linux's libraries for multiple 
architectures: K6, PIII, PII, PI, Duron, Athlon, and 386.  Theoretically, 
I would think through cross compilation that I could have all the 
possibilities.  Then again, compiling for 386 should work everywhere 
where I probably don't need the optimization.  Are all architecture
optimizations contained in Linux's libraries or would having multiple
architecture compatibility ( within the same architecture family ) mean
that you have to have executables compiled in multiple ways?  This would
probably mean a slightly different filesystem structure with a full Linux 
Filesystem Standard tree for each architecture choice.  Setting this up
generically would probably be done most easily by doing multiple LFS 
systems in seperate partitions, one for each architecture.  Talk about 
massive waste :-(  I think autoconfigure is causing optimization to
the host system's architecture.

     --  Michael

on my terminal even though they are displaying on my terminal.  In console mode
it seems like mount is broken.  Is this a network block devices problem?

As far as Linux From Scratch, I'm following version 4 from www.tldp.org and have
followed it verbatim.  It seems like it's optimizing for my host machine, a PIII.
What I don't want to do is I don't want to try doing Linux from scratch on my
386 DX-40 with only 20 megs of ram as that will be really slow.  Without changing
the defaults on a 386 configure would probably optimize for 386, there has to be
a better way though to accomplish this though.  I'm sure Redhat even though 
their binaries are probably compiled for a 386 doesn't actually use a 386, 
same for Mandrake and other Linux Distribution makers.

Since the tape drive isn't on this machine and this machine provides network booting
I should probably finish the instructions, no change, and use this from scratch 
system as an alternative boot option on this server for backing it up.  I'm stuck
with a dilemna though, I either need to figure out how to cross compile all the 
base utilities for a 386 or I need to determine how to gain access to a terminal's
drives under LTSP.

If I what to compress a root filesystem what goes in that filesystem
and for that matter has anyone done this with a modern 2.4 Linux system?
I'm thinking the root filesystem would be an initial ramdisk.  My goal
is to adapt Linux to be a ram based instead of a disk based system.

From robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com  Fri Jul 11 00:15:02 2003
From: robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com (robinsoq )
Date: Fri Jul 11 00:15:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] PowerPC
Message-ID: <200307110014.AA514392368@opusnet.com>


>1) remapping the keyboard to do dvorak 
>
>2) eth0 stops working periodically /etc/init.d/networking restart
>fixes it, so I have a cron job check every 2 min, however this would
>not be tollerable on anything other than a convience machine (if any
>one has reccomendations I'd love to hear them!).
>
>-Rogan
>

This may not be it, however in the past working with Redhat on a 
Pentium III I've noticed that changing the network settings in the 
sysconfig files and then doing a network restart won't change the 
active system settings from those the config files had in them at 
boot.  However, if you manually use ifconfig, route, etc. you can 
enter the new settings manually.  Of course if you reset your files 
those settings will be affective when you reboot also.  BTW, many 
times I've caused a router to stop working by turning off forwarding 
or downing a masquerading firewall.  Usually sysctl, look at 
/etc/stysctl.conf, is configured to turn forwarding off.  The init 
scripts are also good culprits for this where for firewalling, 
especially when taking one down, turning off forwarding and downing 
interfaces is a very good idea.

As always, assume any network conectivity problem is a bad cable or 
other media problem before thinking it's your Linux box.  It may be 
that you have high packet loss somewhere and that resetting your 
networking is cancelling a long retransmit loop.  One thing to look 
out for is an intersection of unshielded network cable and a large 
transformer.  If you have this situation, try wrapping the patch 
cable in aluminum foil to shield it.  With ping there is a flood
option, look at your packet loss when your interface works.  If
you make your own patch cables go buy one instead, they're not 
expensive and stranded wire is less likely to break than the 
solid core stuff that's bought in bulk.

Oh, watch out for 100 megabit/second nics that for some reason
won't run at 10mbits/s under Linux even on low speed hubs.  
I ran into this problem with Intel Etherexpress pro 10/100
builtin cards.  The only solution I've ever found was to 
connect to a 100 mbit/s switch instead of a low speed hub
from these machines.


     --  Michael C. Robinson 



From jeme at brelin.net  Fri Jul 11 01:39:01 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Fri Jul 11 01:39:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] PowerPC
In-Reply-To: <20030711031215.GA2341@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>
References: <000301c34746$91690e90$2f425cc6@gamma> <000f01c3474f$09c7e6b0$6401a8c0@dual>
 <20030711031215.GA2341@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0307110137470.20805@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 10 Jul 2003, Rogan Creswick wrote:
> 2) eth0 stops working periodically /etc/init.d/networking restart fixes
> it, so I have a cron job check every 2 min, however this would not be
> tollerable on anything other than a convience machine (if any one has
> reccomendations I'd love to hear them!).

I've had problems on macs with the arp table just "forgetting" about the
network.  Can you see if that's the case?  A cron job that sends a single
ICMP packet to the gateway every few minutes has always done the trick.

Pain in the ass, but better than restarting the interface.
J.

From jeme at brelin.net  Fri Jul 11 01:43:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Fri Jul 11 01:43:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] PowerPC
In-Reply-To: <200307110014.AA514392368@opusnet.com>
References: <200307110014.AA514392368@opusnet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0307110141310.20805@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Fri, 11 Jul 2003, robinsoq  wrote:
> Oh, watch out for 100 megabit/second nics that for some reason won't run
> at 10mbits/s under Linux even on low speed hubs.  I ran into this
> problem with Intel Etherexpress pro 10/100 builtin cards.  The only
> solution I've ever found was to connect to a 100 mbit/s switch instead
> of a low speed hub from these machines.

Not all 10/100 cards are auto-sensing.

Many of these cards have a soft-switch that needs to be flipped for your
network connection.  There's usually a DOS utility that'll update the
eeprom with the settings for your network.

Oh, and get a journal or a blog or something, ferchrissakes.
J.

From speralta at willamette.edu  Fri Jul 11 08:26:02 2003
From: speralta at willamette.edu (Salvador Peralta)
Date: Fri Jul 11 08:26:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] mozilla
In-Reply-To: <20030711022856.51678.qmail@web10905.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20030711022856.51678.qmail@web10905.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <3F0ED6F4.7060804@willamette.edu>

Lynn Yuan wrote:

>no, I only got a small square box, the title bar is (X
>Mozilla-bin X) and in the middle it says <window ^,
>then I check the ps -ax, it has
>"/usr/lib/mozilla-1.2.1/mozilla-bin -UIlocal en-US".
>
>Mozilla was working fine for me, I don't what's
>happened, it became like this. 
>
The first problem that I see is that -UIlocal is not a valid argument 
for Mozilla.  It should be ignored, but I suppose it could cause 
problems.  Try "-UIlocale en-US".

Also, Mozilla is usually started from the mozilla shell script which is 
usually located in the same directory as mozilla-bin.   Find the script 
`locate "mozilla" | grep "mozilla$"` and try and start with the script.  
To see if you are getting any errors, start Mozilla from a terminal 
window. 

If it still is not working, the problem could be that your user profile 
is damaged.  Mozilla stores user-level configurations in a .mozilla 
directory in the users $HOME.  You can move the profile to a backup 
location (e.g., mv $HOME/.mozilla $HOME/.moz.bak) and start mozilla 
again.  This will require you to recreate your preferences, but will 
also enable you to copy preferences like bookmarks.


-- 
Salvador Peralta
Systems Administrator
Mark O. Hatfield Library
http://www.willamette.edu/~speralta

I know most C preprocessors have a __LINE__ macro for the line number,
is there a similar macro for the name of the current function?

Ie, something like:

printf("%s is the current function. ",__FUNCTION__);

?

-TFC

>
> ?

From speralta at willamette.edu  Fri Jul 11 09:30:02 2003
From: speralta at willamette.edu (Salvador Peralta)
Date: Fri Jul 11 09:30:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] mozilla
In-Reply-To: <20030711161140.15193.qmail@web10901.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20030711161140.15193.qmail@web10901.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <3F0EE5F2.2030102@willamette.edu>

Lynn Yuan wrote:

>Hi 
>
>Thank you for your reply.
>
>(1)I did use "-UIlocal en-US".
>
Don't use "-UIlocal en-US" use "-UIlocale en-US"
                                                                   ^

>(2)I also start mozilla from the terminal window, by
>using "/usr/bin/mozilla", same thing happened.
>  
>
If there was an error, then you should have seen a warning message in 
the terminal window. 

>(3)Then I try "mv /root/.mozilla /root/.maz.bak", and
>start the mozilla from /usr/bin/mozilla, nothing came
>out. How can I recreate the preference?
>
Was there any error in the terminal window when you used it to launch 
Mozilla? 

Some thoughts:

Perhaps the mozilla shell script doesn't like being in a different 
directory that the mozilla-bin executable which is probably not in your 
$PATH.  Either correct the script, add the mozilla-bin executable to 
your $PATH, or try calling mozilla-bin without the locale syntax, or 
with the correct syntax for locale.

It looks as though you are using an RPM build of Mozilla.  The files are 
being put into non-standard, annoying places.  Remove the current 
installation and try using either a compiled version from Mozilla.Org or 
compile your own mozilla distribution.  I have written a Mozilla 
Optimization for Linux mini-HOWTO which you can find at tldp.org

Also, please tell me that you are not always logged in as root on your box.


-- 
Salvador Peralta
Systems Administrator
Mark O. Hatfield Library
http://www.willamette.edu/~speralta







From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Fri Jul 11 10:10:03 2003
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler Creelan)
Date: Fri Jul 11 10:10:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OT: Function name macro in ANSI C ?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0307110924330.19501-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>
References: <20030711155411.GA5347@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU> <Pine.LNX.4.31.0307110924330.19501-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>
Message-ID: <20030711170956.GA5972@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

I asked:

> > I know most C preprocessors have a __LINE__ macro for the line number,
> > is there a similar macro for the name of the current function?
> > Ie, something like:
> >
> > printf("%s is the current function. ",__FUNCTION__);

Hehe, it turns out there is a macro, and it's called __FUNCTION__.

Fedor wrote:

> No, because preprocessor does not know what a "function" is.

Hmm.. well __FUNCTION__ seems to work under gcc and MSVC. In fact, MSVC 
supports a macro for the decorated function name as well (FUNCDNAME), which
wouldn't be possible at all with a traditional preprocessor; there must
be several cycles of preprocessing and compilation to accomodate this.

TFC



From lynnming at yahoo.com  Fri Jul 11 10:22:02 2003
From: lynnming at yahoo.com (Lynn Yuan)
Date: Fri Jul 11 10:22:02 2003

From robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com  Fri Jul 11 11:10:03 2003

Subject: [PLUG] Athlon gotcha...
Message-ID: <200307111109.AA780665024@opusnet.com>

I've been looking on E-Bay for a 1 Ghz Athlon to put on a FIC Aspen 2
motherboard and have discovered that the one I'm bidding on has a 266mhz
front side bus where the ASPEN2 board I want to put it on only supports 
up to 200mhz FSB.  The question I have is, will the 266mhz FSB version 
of the Athlon work on this board?

I'm bidding half on prcoessor and fan for the 1 gigahertz Athlon with 266 mhz
front side bus that I can get a 1 gigahertz Athlon with 200 mhz front side
bus and no fan for buy it now.  The former is only six months used where the 
latter is probably refurb.
 
Maybe someone will still outbid me for the 1 Ghz Athlon 266 mhz FSB at which
point I can just get the other in case I need the other.

I had no idea there were multiple versions of the Athlon operating at the
same cpu clock speed with different internal bus speeds.

   --  Michael C. Robinson

From russj at dimstar.net  Fri Jul 11 11:23:09 2003
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Fri Jul 11 11:23:09 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Athlon gotcha...
In-Reply-To: <200307111109.AA780665024@opusnet.com>
References: <200307111109.AA780665024@opusnet.com>
Message-ID: <3F0F0072.5020809@dimstar.net>

robinsoq wrote:

>I've been looking on E-Bay for a 1 Ghz Athlon to put on a FIC Aspen 2
>motherboard and have discovered that the one I'm bidding on has a 266mhz
>front side bus where the ASPEN2 board I want to put it on only supports 
>up to 200mhz FSB.  The question I have is, will the 266mhz FSB version 
>of the Athlon work on this board?
>
Maybe, but most likely not at 1 ghz. If the FSB is changed, then the 
multiplier would also be different to maintain the same CPU speed. At 
266 FSB, a 1ghz chip would have a 4X multiplier to get to 1ghz. At 4x 
multiplier, a 200 FSB chip would run at 800 mhz.


>I had no idea there were multiple versions of the Athlon operating at the
>same cpu clock speed with different internal bus speeds.
>
Both AMD and Intel do this. The PIII 800 is available in both a 100 and 
133 mhz FSB version. I'm sure there are others, but that's one I've delt 
with.

Russ




From robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com  Fri Jul 11 11:37:02 2003

   I'm doing system V style init.

Do I need a link for /etc/rc.d/rc.sysinit?  Right now there isn't a file 
called rc.sysinit but there is a rcsysinit.d directory.

I'm trying out devfs, 2.4.19 kernel, my root partition
is mounting read only and if the rc.sysinit events aren't

read/write.

restoration purposes.  At the very least it'll make a nice system for

I'm not routing through my gateways and set up an alias on my tape server.

for backup/restore within my local lan where I wouldn't want to be able to
access or be accessed from the Internet.  Can you run different ip networks

From danielx.j.petcher at intel.com  Fri Jul 11 11:52:02 2003
From: danielx.j.petcher at intel.com (Petcher, Danielx J)
Date: Fri Jul 11 11:52:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Trouble with my LFS bootup...
Message-ID: <7D6F4CF55743264F8B23E20353705EEC0A8F59@orsmsx408.amr.corp.intel.com>

> -----Original Message-----
> From: robinsoq [mailto:robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com]
> Sent: Friday, July 11, 2003 11:36 AM
> To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
> Subject: [PLUG] Trouble with my LFS bootup...

<SNIP> 

> I don't have iptables so I'll just put this system on a private class
C
> I'm not routing through my gateways and set up an alias on my tape
server.
> The latter makes more sense because I'm only going to use this system
> for backup/restore within my local lan where I wouldn't want to be
able to
> access or be accessed from the Internet.  Can you run different ip
> networks
> through the same media though?
> 
>      --  Michael C. Robinson

Yes, you can run just about any number of networks through the same
media. I do it all of the time.

If your home network is on a switch, you will keep the privacy you
desire unless someone from out in the Internet manages to gain control
of an internet-connected box and tells it to sniff everything on the
wire. (Since a hub repeats all traffic on all ports, a third-party-owned
computer could capture the private traffic.)

If you're using hubs rather than switches, you will still find that your
collision domain encompases all the devices hooked to the hub in
addition to the small security risk I mentioned above.
-djp

From robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com  Fri Jul 11 12:04:01 2003
From: robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com (robinsoq )
Date: Fri Jul 11 12:04:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux firewall, ssh, and NAT question

---------- Original Message ----------------------------------
From: "Matt Alexander" <m at pdxlug.org>
Reply-To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Date:  Fri, 11 Jul 2003 11:54:53 -0700 (PDT)

>If I have a Linux firewall (iptables) doing NAT, does that mean I can't
>ssh directly to it from the outside?  Do I have to port-forward ssh to
>another machine and then ssh into the firewall using the internal
>interface?
>
>_______________________________________________
>PLUG mailing list
>PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
>http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>

You may need rules to allow ssh to your external interface and it's
important to realize that ssh itself does it's own blocking apart
from what iptables does at the packet level.  Ssh needs to be 
configured to allow connections from the outside.

     --  Michael C. Robinson
 



From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Fri Jul 11 12:12:01 2003
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor Pikus)
Date: Fri Jul 11 12:12:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OT: Function name macro in ANSI C ?
In-Reply-To: <20030711170956.GA5972@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0307111202280.19501-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

On Fri, 11 Jul 2003, Tyler Creelan wrote:
> I asked:
>
> > > I know most C preprocessors have a __LINE__ macro for the line number,
> > > is there a similar macro for the name of the current function?
> > > Ie, something like:
> > >
> > > printf("%s is the current function. ",__FUNCTION__);
>
> Hehe, it turns out there is a macro, and it's called __FUNCTION__.
It's not a preprocessor macro. Try for yourself, write out preprocessor
output (gcc -E), you'll see that __LINE__ is replaced by a number but
__FUNCTION__ is still there. __FUNCTION__ is a GCC-ism. The replacement
of __FUNCTION__ by the function name is done by the compiler. GCC is not the
only compiler which knows this, HP C/C++ compiler can do it, so can Intel
compiler, but not Sun compiler. Also, they differ slightly in what they
return as function name, in some cases.
BTW, if __FUNCTION__ works, odds are __func__works too.


>
> Fedor wrote:
>
> > No, because preprocessor does not know what a "function" is.
>
> Hmm.. well __FUNCTION__ seems to work under gcc and MSVC. In fact, MSVC
> supports a macro for the decorated function name as well (FUNCDNAME), which
> wouldn't be possible at all with a traditional preprocessor; there must
> be several cycles of preprocessing and compilation to accomodate this.
>
> TFC
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>

-- 
                                  Fedor G. Pikus
Mentor Graphics Corporation         | Phone: (503) 685-4857
8405 SW Boeckman Road               | FAX:   (503) 685-1239
Wilsonville, Oregon 97070           | http://www.pikus.net/~pikus/

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Fri Jul 11 13:31:01 2003
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler Creelan)
Date: Fri Jul 11 13:31:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OT: Function name macro in ANSI C ?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0307111202280.19501-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>
References: <20030711170956.GA5972@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU> <Pine.LNX.4.31.0307111202280.19501-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>
Message-ID: <20030711203015.GA2273@or.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Fedor Pikus wrote:

> __FUNCTION__ is a GCC-ism.
[..]
> BTW, if __FUNCTION__ works, odds are __func__works too.

It looks like __func__ is an ANSI C99 addition, so it would be 
preferable to __FUNCTION__, correct?

Btw, it appears MSVC does not support __func__, although VC7 
supports __FUNCTION__.

References:

http://gcc.gnu.org/gcc-3.0/c99status.html
http://msdn.microsoft.com/chats/vstudio/vstudio_022703.asp

TFC

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Fri Jul 11 14:17:02 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Fri Jul 11 14:17:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Testing Intel hardware...
In-Reply-To: <200307111257.AA447152358@opusnet.com>
Message-ID: <23105-81881@sneakemail.com>

This is a good way to test and exercise the memory/CPU:

http://www.memtest86.com/

This system-wide test is a bit dated, but with some work may still be
useful:

http://sourceforge.net/projects/va-ctcs

This has lots of links to more information:

http://www.linux-1u.net/Diags/

This is how I found it all:

http://www.google.com/search?q=linux+system+diagnostics

  -- Steve

On Fri, 11 Jul 2003, robinsoq  robinsoq-at-mail.opusnet.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> there is a CD or something that Intel puts out or maybe even someone

> that I know I don't have a hardware problem before I assume I'm
> dealing with software issues.

From griffint at pobox.com  Fri Jul 11 14:33:02 2003
From: griffint at pobox.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Fri Jul 11 14:33:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux firewall, ssh, and NAT question
In-Reply-To: <32798.68.107.223.201.1057955617.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>; from m@pdxlug.org on Fri, Jul 11, 2003 at 01:33:37PM -0700
References: <200307111203.AA291045560@opusnet.com> <32798.68.107.223.201.1057955617.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
Message-ID: <20030711143241.A22516@aracnet.com>

On Fri, Jul 11, 2003 at 01:33:37PM -0700, Matt Alexander wrote:
> >>If I have a Linux firewall (iptables) doing NAT, does that mean I can't
> >>ssh directly to it from the outside?  Do I have to port-forward ssh to
> >>another machine and then ssh into the firewall using the internal
> >>interface?
> >>
> >
> > You may need rules to allow ssh to your external interface and it's
> > important to realize that ssh itself does it's own blocking apart
> > from what iptables does at the packet level.  Ssh needs to be
> > configured to allow connections from the outside.
> 
> Hmm...  Well, I'm using Arno's IPTables Firewall Script:
> http://freshmeat.net/projects/iptables-firewall/?topic_id=151
> 
> I modified the config file to allow connections to port 22/tcp|udp, but I
> still can't SSH in.  So I thought that maybe having NAT enabled would make
> connections directly to the box impossible from the outside...  any NAT
> experts out there?
> 

No, NAT shouldn't interfere with SSH'ing to the box that's doing the 
NATing, but there could be some other iptables setting that are 
interfering with SSH. You should be able to track this down by adding 
some iptables logging rules just prior to the equivalent deny rules.

Terry
-- 
Terry Griffin <griffint at pobox.com>
http://www.blindchicken.com/~terryg/

	 <3F0B72E8.4050103@ardware.net> <1057719219.552.23.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
	 <3F0B8A85.7090106@ardware.net> <1057723142.553.25.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
	 <3F0CA8B6.3050305@ardware.net> <1057814764.552.52.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
	 <3F0EE18A.4050900@ardware.net> <1057949580.553.76.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
	 <3F0F0843.7070209@ardware.net>
Message-ID: <1057959198.8634.69.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Fri, 2003-07-11 at 11:56, Andrew Dennis wrote:
> >
> >I haven't set up an USB mouse, yet, so I don't know exactly what to look
> >for.
> >
> 
> Did I mention that it works perfectly under Windows?

No, but it doesn't necessarily matter.  PCI devices can share
interrupts, and, I think, be assigned their interrupts when they're
initialized (boot-time usually).  So there are plenty of places where
the hardware itself may be fine, but the drivers might have bugs.  What
does /proc/interrupts look like?

Wil
--

From drl at drloree.com  Fri Jul 11 16:04:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Fri Jul 11 16:04:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Athlon gotcha...
In-Reply-To: <200307111151.AA220201262@opusnet.com>
References: <200307111151.AA220201262@opusnet.com>
Message-ID: <1057964955.573.20.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Fri, 2003-07-11 at 11:51, robinsoq wrote:
> 
> ---------- Original Message ----------------------------------
> From: Russ Johnson <russj at dimstar.net>
> Reply-To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
> Date:  Fri, 11 Jul 2003 11:22:42 -0700
> 
> >robinsoq wrote:
> >
> >>I've been looking on E-Bay for a 1 Ghz Athlon to put on a FIC Aspen 2
> >>motherboard and have discovered that the one I'm bidding on has a 266mhz
> >>front side bus where the ASPEN2 board I want to put it on only supports 
> >>up to 200mhz FSB.  The question I have is, will the 266mhz FSB version 
> >>of the Athlon work on this board?
> >>
> >Maybe, but most likely not at 1 ghz. If the FSB is changed, then the 
> >multiplier would also be different to maintain the same CPU speed. At 
> >266 FSB, a 1ghz chip would have a 4X multiplier to get to 1ghz. At 4x 
> >multiplier, a 200 FSB chip would run at 800 mhz.
> 
> So this Athlon at 266 mhz FSB may not take a 5x multiplier at at 200Mhz
> internal clock speed.  On the other hand, if it will run stably at 800Mhz
> I'm perfectly happy with that as my other two PIII servers only do 866 :-)  
> The motherboard even after shipping is only $16 with a 30 day return 
> warranty to boot.

It is possible to change the multiplier, but it requires physical
modification of the CPU (adding and subtracting conducting paths). 
tomshardware.com has done it several times.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

On Fri, Jul 11, 2003 at 01:39:18AM -0700, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> On Thu, 10 Jul 2003, Rogan Creswick wrote:
> > 2) eth0 stops working periodically /etc/init.d/networking restart fixes
> > it, so I have a cron job check every 2 min, however this would not be
> > tollerable on anything other than a convience machine (if any one has
> > reccomendations I'd love to hear them!).
> 
> I've had problems on macs with the arp table just "forgetting" about the
> network.  Can you see if that's the case?  A cron job that sends a single
> ICMP packet to the gateway every few minutes has always done the trick.

I'm currently pinging my router every 2 minutes with 1 packet, if the
ping dosen't return in 3 seconds, I restart the interface.  When the
network goes down everything dies, so I think it's a bit more drastic
than that :(.

From drl at drloree.com  Fri Jul 11 16:18:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Fri Jul 11 16:18:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Testing Intel hardware...
In-Reply-To: <200307111257.AA447152358@opusnet.com>
References: <200307111257.AA447152358@opusnet.com>
Message-ID: <1057965845.571.34.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Fri, 2003-07-11 at 12:57, robinsoq wrote:
> I'm having a heck of a time with my D845PEBT2 and I'm wondering if there is a CD or
> something that Intel puts out or maybe even someone else for that matter that will
> fully test the board, memory, etc. so that I know I don't have a hardware problem
> before I assume I'm dealing with software issues.

Start with www.memtest86.com, let that run over night, or a couple of
hundred passes, which ever comes first.  Once you have confidence in
your memory, the other weirdness should start making sense.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Fri Jul 11 16:25:04 2003
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Fri Jul 11 16:25:04 2003
Subject: [PLUG] PowerPC
In-Reply-To: <200307110014.AA514392368@opusnet.com>
References: <200307110014.AA514392368@opusnet.com>
Message-ID: <20030711232454.GC3078@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>

On Fri, Jul 11, 2003 at 12:14:01AM -0700, robinsoq  wrote:
> As always, assume any network conectivity problem is a bad cable or 
> other media problem before thinking it's your Linux box.  It may be 
> that you have high packet loss somewhere and that resetting your 
> networking is cancelling a long retransmit loop.  One thing to look 

I've tried a good dozen cables, different paths to the router (eg: up
the stairs rather than through the wall), direct connections via
crossover cables, home made cable and store bought, and various ports
on the switch (which is of the 10/100 auto-sensing full duplex
variety, but not managed), none of which seems to affect the problem.

> out for is an intersection of unshielded network cable and a large 
> transformer.  If you have this situation, try wrapping the patch 
> cable in aluminum foil to shield it.  

There is no power in the walls near the cables in question (I built
the house), and the only electronic devices near the wall are 2 crts.

> With ping there is a flood
> option, look at your packet loss when your interface works.  

0% packet loss when it is behaving, tested with almost 300,000
packets. (279701 packets transmitted, 279655 packets received)

> Oh, watch out for 100 megabit/second nics that for some reason
> won't run at 10mbits/s under Linux even on low speed hubs.  
> I ran into this problem with Intel Etherexpress pro 10/100
> builtin cards.  The only solution I've ever found was to 
> connect to a 100 mbit/s switch instead of a low speed hub
> from these machines.

The interface works at spec, when it is working.

Thanks,
-Rogan



From robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com  Fri Jul 11 16:31:02 2003
From: robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com (robinsoq )
Date: Fri Jul 11 16:31:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Surprised about D845PEBT2
Message-ID: <200307111630.AA314507448@opusnet.com>

They're hard to find but Intel's site has Linux drivers for the motherboard components
that otherwise won't work under Redhat 8 and 9.  There are also drivers for two of the
suse releases.  Don't know if these are binaries, probably.  I'm not complaining 
though :-)  The Intel drivers may make the sound card work, optimize the nic, and
improve agp.

     --  Michael C. Robinson

From stevea at nwtechops.com  Fri Jul 11 17:23:01 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Fri Jul 11 17:23:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux firewall, ssh, and NAT question
In-Reply-To: <20030711143241.A22516@aracnet.com>
References: <200307111203.AA291045560@opusnet.com>
	 <32798.68.107.223.201.1057955617.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
	 <20030711143241.A22516@aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <1057969304.1227.6.camel@main>

On Fri, 2003-07-11 at 14:32, Terry Griffin wrote:
> On Fri, Jul 11, 2003 at 01:33:37PM -0700, Matt Alexander wrote:
> > >>If I have a Linux firewall (iptables) doing NAT, does that mean I can't
> > >>ssh directly to it from the outside?  Do I have to port-forward ssh to
> > >>another machine and then ssh into the firewall using the internal
> > >>interface?
> > >>
> > >
> > > You may need rules to allow ssh to your external interface and it's
> > > important to realize that ssh itself does it's own blocking apart
> > > from what iptables does at the packet level.  Ssh needs to be
> > > configured to allow connections from the outside.
> > 
> > Hmm...  Well, I'm using Arno's IPTables Firewall Script:
> > http://freshmeat.net/projects/iptables-firewall/?topic_id=151
> > 
> > I modified the config file to allow connections to port 22/tcp|udp, but I
> > still can't SSH in.  So I thought that maybe having NAT enabled would make
> > connections directly to the box impossible from the outside...  any NAT
> > experts out there?
> > 
> 
> No, NAT shouldn't interfere with SSH'ing to the box that's doing the 
> NATing, but there could be some other iptables setting that are 
> interfering with SSH. You should be able to track this down by adding 
> some iptables logging rules just prior to the equivalent deny rules.
> 
> Terry

You can also look at the /etc/ssh/sshd.conf ListenAddress entry. If it's
not commented out it should be 0.0.0.0 (all networks). If your going to
do this on a firewall I would recommend that you not allow interactive
authentication but instead stick to key based ssh2.

Steve
--

> ERR:          0
> MIS:          0


Here ya go.  Also I set up both mice to work at the same time and
the built in mouse works perfectly.

Thanks

Andy




Wil Cooley wrote:

>On Fri, 2003-07-11 at 11:56, Andrew Dennis wrote:
>  
>
>>>I haven't set up an USB mouse, yet, so I don't know exactly what to look
>>>for.
>>>
>>>      
>>>
>>Did I mention that it works perfectly under Windows?
>>    
>>
>
>No, but it doesn't necessarily matter.  PCI devices can share
>interrupts, and, I think, be assigned their interrupts when they're
>initialized (boot-time usually).  So there are plenty of places where
>the hardware itself may be fine, but the drivers might have bugs.  What
>does /proc/interrupts look like?
>
>Wil
>  
>

From m at pdxlug.org  Fri Jul 11 17:58:02 2003
From: m at pdxlug.org (Matt Alexander)
Date: Fri Jul 11 17:58:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux firewall, ssh, and NAT question
In-Reply-To: <1057969304.1227.6.camel@main>
References: <200307111203.AA291045560@opusnet.com> 
     <32798.68.107.223.201.1057955617.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org> 
     <20030711143241.A22516@aracnet.com> <1057969304.1227.6.camel@main>
Message-ID: <8048.68.96.48.205.1057971458.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>

Steven A. Adams said:
> On Fri, 2003-07-11 at 14:32, Terry Griffin wrote:
>> On Fri, Jul 11, 2003 at 01:33:37PM -0700, Matt Alexander wrote:
>> > >>If I have a Linux firewall (iptables) doing NAT, does that mean I
>> can't
>> > >>ssh directly to it from the outside?  Do I have to port-forward ssh
>> to
>> > >>another machine and then ssh into the firewall using the internal
>> > >>interface?
>> > >>
>> > >
>> > > You may need rules to allow ssh to your external interface and it's
>> > > important to realize that ssh itself does it's own blocking apart
>> > > from what iptables does at the packet level.  Ssh needs to be
>> > > configured to allow connections from the outside.
>> >
>> > Hmm...  Well, I'm using Arno's IPTables Firewall Script:
>> > http://freshmeat.net/projects/iptables-firewall/?topic_id=151
>> >
>> > I modified the config file to allow connections to port 22/tcp|udp,
>> but I
>> > still can't SSH in.  So I thought that maybe having NAT enabled would
>> make
>> > connections directly to the box impossible from the outside...  any
>> NAT
>> > experts out there?
>> >
>>
>> No, NAT shouldn't interfere with SSH'ing to the box that's doing the
>> NATing, but there could be some other iptables setting that are
>> interfering with SSH. You should be able to track this down by adding
>> some iptables logging rules just prior to the equivalent deny rules.
>>
>> Terry
>
> You can also look at the /etc/ssh/sshd.conf ListenAddress entry. If it's
> not commented out it should be 0.0.0.0 (all networks). If your going to
> do this on a firewall I would recommend that you not allow interactive
> authentication but instead stick to key based ssh2.

I figured it out...  the Arno's IPTables script was blocking access to the
external interface from private IP ranges.  This was a firewall behind
another firewall and I had the external using 192.168.x.x and the internal
using 172.16.x.x.
Thanks to everyone that offered their help.
~M



From sean at fork.com  Fri Jul 11 18:47:02 2003
From: sean at fork.com (Sean Whitney)
Date: Fri Jul 11 18:47:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] [PDXLUG] Noose on mad SCO disease?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0307110805070.32656-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0307110805070.32656-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1057974393.2933.607.camel@einstein.seansdomain.org>

There was a session specifically about that subject.  

http://conferences.oreillynet.com/cs/os2003/view/e_sess/4528

It was dominated by Lawrence Rosen, as well it should be as the subject
matter was about law.

His basic conclusion was this was more a case about law than code, that
the press had really done a great job of blowing it's importance
completely out of the water, and that IBM really had little to fear.

He stressed the absolutely minor significance of the letters sent out by
SCO.  He pointed out a letter is $.37.  Pretty cheap FUD.  If SCO
can scare one company into sending them money or to stop using Linux and
switch to Unixware, then the letters would pay for themselves.  

There was also an interesting interchange between him and Eric S.
Raymond about copyrighting code.  Rosen wanted everything done in a very
strict clear legal sense.  Raymond pointed out the more hoops that
developers have to jump through to publish code as Open Source, the less
developers will do it.

Sean

Sean

On Fri, 2003-07-11 at 17:26, Andrew Dennis wrote:
> > # more /proc/interrupts
> >            CPU0
> >   0:     428997          XT-PIC  timer
> >   1:       1201          XT-PIC  keyboard
> >   2:          0          XT-PIC  cascade
> >   8:          2          XT-PIC  rtc
> >   9:      63154          XT-PIC  acpi, eth0, usb-uhci, usb-uhci, Intel 
> > 82801BA-I
> > CH2, i810 at PCI:0:2:0

There you go--you've got all this stuff on IRQ 9.  Check your BIOS and
see if you can convince some of these devices to use other IRQs.

> Here ya go.  Also I set up both mice to work at the same time and
> the built in mouse works perfectly.

The internal mouse is probably PS/2 and already has its own IRQ.

Wil

From svanhoosen at yahoo.com  Fri Jul 11 20:25:02 2003

You could always ssh into a machine behind your
firewall, then ssh from there to your firewall's
internal IP address.

From stevea at nwtechops.com  Fri Jul 11 22:43:02 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Fri Jul 11 22:43:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] samba, eth1 dhcp
In-Reply-To: <20030712043551.33518.qmail@web10903.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20030712043551.33518.qmail@web10903.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <1057988532.1227.21.camel@main>

No problem, I missed the fact that both networks were IANA non-routable,
the class B usage is a little less common.

Open port 137 and 138 udp and port 139 tcp on the firewall between these
2 internal networks. That should allow file share access from your other
network.

Hope that helps.

> > # more /proc/interrupts
> >            CPU0

> >   1:       1201          XT-PIC  keyboard
> >   2:          0          XT-PIC  cascade
> >   8:          2          XT-PIC  rtc

> > NMI:          0
> > LOC:          0
> > ERR:          0
> > MIS:          0
> 
All those free IRQ's, and 9 gets loaded up, go figure.

it?  Is there anyway to convince the BIOS to reassign IRQ's?

From lynnming at yahoo.com  Fri Jul 11 23:25:02 2003
From: lynnming at yahoo.com (Lynn Yuan)
Date: Fri Jul 11 23:25:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] samba, eth1 dhcp
In-Reply-To: <1057988532.1227.21.camel@main>
Message-ID: <20030712062415.44622.qmail@web10903.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi

Here is my samba config in the iptables file, is there
anything need to be modified? 

  # samba (137) - Accessing remote web sites as a
client
        #

        if [ $SMB_CLIENT -gt 0 ]; then

            iptables -A OUTPUT -o $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE
-p TCP \
        --sport $UNPRIVPORTS --dport 137:139 -s
$EXTERNAL_IP -d $ANYWHERE -j ACCEPT

            iptables -A INPUT -i $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE
-p TCP -m state --state ESTABLISHED,RELATE
D \
        --sport 137:139 --dport $UNPRIVPORTS -s
$ANYWHERE -d $EXTERNAL_IP -j ACCEPT

            if [ $MASQUERADING -gt 0 ]; then
               iptables -A FORWARD -p TCP -s
$INTERNAL_NETWORK --sport $UNPRIVPORTS --dport 137
:139 -j ACCEPT
               iptables -A FORWARD -p TCP -d
$INTERNAL_NETWORK --sport 137:139 --dport $UNPRIVP
ORTS -j ACCEPT
            fi
 if [ $VERBOSE -gt 0 ]; then
                echo "firewall: Clients may access
remote SMB servers"
            fi

        fi

        #
        # SAMBA (137) - Allowing remote access to a
local web server
        #

        if [ $SMB_SERVER -gt 0 ]; then

            iptables -A INPUT -i $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE
-p TCP \
        --sport $UNPRIVPORTS --dport 137:139 -s
$MY_SMB_CLIENTS -d $EXTERNAL_IP -j ACCEPT

            iptables -A OUTPUT -o $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE
-p TCP -m state --state ESTABLISHED,RELAT
ED \
        --sport 137:139 --dport $UNPRIVPORTS -s
$EXTERNAL_IP -d $MY_SMB_CLIENTS -j ACCEPT

            iptables -A INPUT -i $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE
-p TCP \
        --sport $UNPRIVPORTS --dport 137:139 -s
$MY_SMB_CLIENTS -d $EXTERNAL_IP -j ACCEPT

            iptables -A OUTPUT -o $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE
-p TCP -m state --state ESTABLISHED,RELAT
ED \
        --sport 137:139 --dport $UNPRIVPORTS -s
$EXTERNAL_IP -d $MY_SMB_CLIENTS -j ACCEPT

            if [ $VERBOSE -gt 0 ]; then
                echo "firewall: Remote clients may
access local SMB server"
            fi

        fi

m.y.
--- "Steven A. Adams" <stevea at nwtechops.com> wrote:
> No problem, I missed the fact that both networks
> were IANA non-routable,
> the class B usage is a little less common.
> 
> Open port 137 and 138 udp and port 139 tcp on the
> firewall between these
> 2 internal networks. That should allow file share
> access from your other
> network.
> 
> Hope that helps.
>

From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Sat Jul 12 01:15:02 2003
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Sat Jul 12 01:15:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] [PDXLUG] Noose on mad SCO disease?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0307110805070.32656-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0307112210450.593-100000@joan.burling.com>

On Fri, 11 Jul 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   Just out of curiosity, what do you folks at OSCON hear about the mad SCO
> disease?
>
Well, I attended the panel discussion on the SCO Group vs. IBM lawsuit --
which got several write-ups on various internet news sites, which will
tell you most of what was said -- & managed to snag a minute or two of
Larry Rosen's time to get some clarifications, so maybe I can offer
something about this case of interest.

(And I have to say that this panel discussion was not the most interesting
presentation at OSCON; even the panelists appeared a little embarassed
at participating, & stated that they didn't have any new information that
hasn't been masticated into a tasteless pulp by the press. I'd say the
one presenter who had something to say, & packed the room every time
he spoke was Robert Lefkowitz, whose presentations on Open Source &
business were thoughtful, well-researched, & entertaining. As soon as
his slides are put on the O'Reily site, GET them.)

Two things that the news write-ups omitted about what the panel said
about this case were these:

(1) Larry Rosen was largely dismissive of the case & its effect on Linux,
being quite emphatic about the fact that until the SCO Group's claims of
trade secrets is more clearly defined as discovery proceeds, we shouldn't
assume this is anything more than a pissing match between the SCO Group &
IBM. Rosen stated that it's clear the SCO Group is ``making a Hail Mary
play" by suing IBM.

(2) Bradley M. Kuhn of the FSF commented that the code of the software
they own is free of any possible IP taint because they actively vet all
people who contribute code to their project: making sure that the individual
either clearly owns the contributed code, or has his employer's permission
to give it; & verifying that the contributor either is old enough to
legally consent to a contract, or has her/his parents' consent in making
a contribution. While Kuhn further insisted that FSF's ownership of the
code was a Good Thing, Rosen disagreed with him on that point -- but
agreed it was important to vet the coders to be even more careful that
code doesn't get contributed that shouldn't be there.

Eric Raymond spoke up & stated in a blustery fashion that he thought
vetting contributors was a Bad Thing, & any limits on people contributing
code would affect the quality of the project. But then again, I've long
ago come to the conclusion that Raymond mostly likes to hear himself
talk (even more than me), & tuned him out within 30 seconds into his spiel.
I did see him at the conference, but I didn't bother to say anything to
him (I didn't see the point of telling him what I thought to his face after
he had travelled all this way), so about the only thing I learned from
seeing him was that in the flesh he bore an amazing resemblance to Lon
Mabon (whom I've happened to also have seen in the flesh).

As for Rosen's comments to me, they emphasised & clarified his thoughtful
opinion that, so far, this lawsuit is Just Another Lawsuit Between Two
Corporations. He stated it was his belief the SCO Group sent out those
1500 letters concenring Linux in an attempt to put pressure on IBM to
settle out of court. (He stated at the panel he's perfectly happy to
send out letters on his law firm's stationary to compel people to
stop behavior, & if it works, great.) So far, there is nothing out of
the ordinary about this lawsuit: neither IBM nor the SCO Group are doing
anything remarkable (except that the SCO Group has managed by its acts
to make itself the most hated high-tech company in the world -- making
Microsoft a distant second, at best), and the case will take a few
years to grind its way to a conclusion. Until the facts of the actual
code MacBride et alia claim have been put into the Linux kernel are
identified, one shouldn't lose sleep about this case. Although it doesn't
hurt to keep an eye on events . . .

As for outside that panel discussion . . . I have to say this case was
probably most noticeable by its absense: eavesdropping on conversations,
the most common topic appeared to be either ``Man, Wednesday night was
a killer party" or ``Hey, take a look at this code". Yes, there was the
guy with yellow hair who had the words FSCK SCO painted in red on the
back of his head, but he was quite unusual.

Geoff




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sat Jul 12 06:44:03 2003

> which got several write-ups on various internet news sites, which will
> tell you most of what was said -- & managed to snag a minute or two of
> Larry Rosen's time to get some clarifications, so maybe I can offer

  Thanks, Geoff and the others who responded. As an interested bystander who
has detailed knowledge of how the news media -- particularly newspapers --
play up issues just to generate sales, I wondered if there was anything new
happening. Now I know the answer is, "no". We are now in that protracted
stage where the lawyers keep billing by the hour so as to meet their 90%
billability requirements. This will continue until one party or the other
either tires of throwing away money or goes broke. Then the case will be
settled and everyone will claim victory.

Rich

From cooper at cooper.stevenson.name  Sat Jul 12 08:21:02 2003
From: cooper at cooper.stevenson.name (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Sat Jul 12 08:21:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Porting IE Bookmarks to Galeon
Message-ID: <1058024909.31048.751.camel@sparticus>

I wrote this simple bash script (oh, how I pined for 'emerge pdksh') to
convert exported IE bookmarks to Galeon. It turns this:

  [DEFAULT]
  BASEURL=http://accounts.keybank.com/
  [InternetShortcut]
  URL=http://accounts.keybank.com/
  Modified=E064CB6ECCAEC201BA

Into this...

  <bookmark href="http://accounts.keybank.com/">
    <title>Key Bank - Online Banking</title>
  </bookmark>

Simply change the top two variables to suit your needs and place the
output in your ~.galeon/bookmarks.xbel file.

 May you find it useful...


#--------------Begin script----------------------

#!/bin/bash
                                                                                                                                                                                                                            favorites_directory=directory/that/holds/your/exported/bookmarks
output_file=file/to/hold/results                                                                                
                                                                     
find "$favorites_directory" -printf %f\\n | while read file
do
   if [[ -f "$file" ]]
   then
     grep URL "$file" | awk -F '=' '{ print $2 }' | while read url
     do
       echo '<bookmark href="'"$url"'">' >> "$output_file"
       echo '  <title>'"$file"'</title>' >> "$output_file"
       echo '</bookmark>' >> "$output_file"
     done
   fi
done

#----------------------End Script------------------------------------





From stevea at nwtechops.com  Sat Jul 12 08:57:01 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Sat Jul 12 08:57:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] samba, eth1 dhcp
In-Reply-To: <20030712062415.44622.qmail@web10903.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20030712062415.44622.qmail@web10903.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <1058025364.1226.54.camel@main>

I wouldn't look for this to work unless your using TCP for netbios name
and netbios datagram services on your SMB server. Samba, as well as
other SMB servers, normally implement netbios name and datagram services
(port 137 and 138) over UDP. Your opening port 137 and 138 over TCP
here, this is the -p TCP option in the iptables commands that your
script is executing. From looking at your example, it would be possible
to duplicate some of the entries in order to split out port 137:138 from
port 139 with a protocol (-p) of UDP and alter the existing -p TCP
entries to do only port 139.

It would look something like this:


if [ $SMB_CLIENT -gt 0 ]; then

iptables -A OUTPUT -o $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE -p UDP \
--sport $UNPRIVPORTS --dport 137:138 -s $EXTERNAL_IP -d $ANYWHERE -j ACCEPT

iptables -A OUTPUT -o $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE -p TCP \
--sport $UNPRIVPORTS --dport 139 -s $EXTERNAL_IP -d $ANYWHERE -j ACCEPT


Now further down in the script you are matching state with the -m state
option and I don't think that this is going to be valid for UDP entries,
UDP is a connectionless protocol. You can try but if you get an error
then you'll have to remove the state match.



On Fri, 2003-07-11 at 23:24, Lynn Yuan wrote:
> Hi
> 
> Here is my samba config in the iptables file, is there
> anything need to be modified? 
> 
>   # samba (137) - Accessing remote web sites as a
> client
>         #
> 
>         if [ $SMB_CLIENT -gt 0 ]; then
> 
>             iptables -A OUTPUT -o $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE
> -p TCP \
>         --sport $UNPRIVPORTS --dport 137:139 -s
> $EXTERNAL_IP -d $ANYWHERE -j ACCEPT
> 
>             iptables -A INPUT -i $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE
> -p TCP -m state --state ESTABLISHED,RELATE
> D \
>         --sport 137:139 --dport $UNPRIVPORTS -s
> $ANYWHERE -d $EXTERNAL_IP -j ACCEPT
> 
>             if [ $MASQUERADING -gt 0 ]; then
>                iptables -A FORWARD -p TCP -s
> $INTERNAL_NETWORK --sport $UNPRIVPORTS --dport 137
> :139 -j ACCEPT
>                iptables -A FORWARD -p TCP -d
> $INTERNAL_NETWORK --sport 137:139 --dport $UNPRIVP
> ORTS -j ACCEPT
>             fi
>  if [ $VERBOSE -gt 0 ]; then
>                 echo "firewall: Clients may access
> remote SMB servers"
>             fi
> 
>         fi
> 
>         #
>         # SAMBA (137) - Allowing remote access to a
> local web server
>         #
> 
>         if [ $SMB_SERVER -gt 0 ]; then
> 
>             iptables -A INPUT -i $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE
> -p TCP \
>         --sport $UNPRIVPORTS --dport 137:139 -s
> $MY_SMB_CLIENTS -d $EXTERNAL_IP -j ACCEPT
> 
>             iptables -A OUTPUT -o $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE
> -p TCP -m state --state ESTABLISHED,RELAT
> ED \
>         --sport 137:139 --dport $UNPRIVPORTS -s
> $EXTERNAL_IP -d $MY_SMB_CLIENTS -j ACCEPT
> 
>             iptables -A INPUT -i $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE
> -p TCP \
>         --sport $UNPRIVPORTS --dport 137:139 -s
> $MY_SMB_CLIENTS -d $EXTERNAL_IP -j ACCEPT
> 
>             iptables -A OUTPUT -o $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE
> -p TCP -m state --state ESTABLISHED,RELAT
> ED \
>         --sport 137:139 --dport $UNPRIVPORTS -s
> $EXTERNAL_IP -d $MY_SMB_CLIENTS -j ACCEPT
> 
>             if [ $VERBOSE -gt 0 ]; then
>                 echo "firewall: Remote clients may
> access local SMB server"
>             fi
> 
>         fi

I've been using DDS units to backup for a while and haven't had any problems 
related to DDS.  I'm using afbackup for my backup program.  It supports 
client server architecture, multiple backups at the same time, and I can 
backup through a ssh tunnel which is pretty cool.

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Sun Jul 13 14:28:02 2003

> Dear All:

> such a tool?  I do not know what is the file format name but it is whatever
> the Windows Media Player plays in MS Window.

mplayer and xine will play them.

From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Sun Jul 13 16:28:02 2003
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Sun Jul 13 16:28:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Lefkowitz Talk Notes from OSCON
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0307131628290.593-100000@joan.burling.com>

As I said in another email, probably the best presenter at OSCON was
Robert Lefkowitz, who although admittedly a suit from Wall Street, not
only did his homework & was an excellent speaker, also understood
the technical side of Open Source. He promised to turn over his
slides for O'Reilly to put on their web site, but until then you
can get an idea of his presentation ``The Missing Open Source Projects"
at http://www.oreillynet.com/pub/wlg/3501.

Heck, anyone who understands why you want to get reduce your dependence
on Computer Associates gets positive marks in my book!

Geoff





From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sun Jul 13 16:58:01 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Sun Jul 13 16:58:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] advice on buying a cheap DAT Drive
In-Reply-To: <200307130754.12218.sean@fork.com>
References: <EBEKLKENGDOIDOCHLDGLMEAKCKAA.jon@vertex-networking.com>
	<200307130754.12218.sean@fork.com>
Message-ID: <86d6gekmj2.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Sean" == Sean Whitney <sean at fork.com> writes:

Sean> [...] and I can backup through a ssh tunnel which is pretty
Sean> cool.

I can do that with /bin/tar too, e.g.:

  mt -f /dev/nst0 setblk 32768
  mt -f /dev/nst0 rewind
  ssh -l root <remote-hostname> 'tar -C / -clf - .' | dd of=/dev/nst0 obs=32768
  mt -f /dev/nst0 rewind
  dd if=/dev/nst0 ibs=32768 | ssh -l root <remote-host> 'tar -C / -dlf -'


-- 
Russell Senior         ``shtal latta wos ba padre u prett tu nashtonfi
seniorr at aracnet.com      mrlosh''  -- Bashgali Kafir for ``If you have
                         had diarrhoea many days you will surely die.''



From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Sun Jul 13 17:21:01 2003
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Sun Jul 13 17:21:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] usb camera
In-Reply-To: <1058138705.1234.41.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1058138705.1234.41.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <20030714002046.GA4509@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>

On Sun, Jul 13, 2003 at 04:25:05PM -0700, Dirk Ouellette wrote:
> When I try to use my Olympus usb camera on my wife's Redhat 9 machine,
> lsusb gives me many unknown line numbers and finally
> "cannot open /proc/bus/usb, No such file or directory. So the usb isn't
> being turned on automatically as it does on my machine, right?


It sounds like you need to enable USB in your kernel, and/or support
for "preliminary USB device filesystem", also in the kernel.

-Rogan




From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Sun Jul 13 17:21:10 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Sun Jul 13 17:21:10 2003
Subject: [PLUG] advice on buying a cheap DAT Drive
In-Reply-To: <86d6gekmj2.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <EBEKLKENGDOIDOCHLDGLMEAKCKAA.jon@vertex-networking.com>
	 <200307130754.12218.sean@fork.com>  <86d6gekmj2.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <1058141955.25455.4.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Sun, 2003-07-13 at 16:57, Russell Senior wrote:
> >>>>> "Sean" == Sean Whitney <sean at fork.com> writes:
> 
> Sean> [...] and I can backup through a ssh tunnel which is pretty
> Sean> cool.
> 
> I can do that with /bin/tar too, e.g.:
> 
>   mt -f /dev/nst0 setblk 32768
>   mt -f /dev/nst0 rewind
>   ssh -l root <remote-hostname> 'tar -C / -clf - .' | dd of=/dev/nst0 obs=32768
>   mt -f /dev/nst0 rewind
>   dd if=/dev/nst0 ibs=32768 | ssh -l root <remote-host> 'tar -C / -dlf -'

I think you can just set

# RSH=`which ssh`
# export RSH

and then use

# tar cf hostname:/dev/ntape0

At least, this is the way dump(8) works and I think GNU tar implements
it too.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc

From kgmorse at mpcu.com  Sun Jul 13 18:07:02 2003
From: kgmorse at mpcu.com (Keith Morse)
Date: Sun Jul 13 18:07:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] advice on buying a cheap DAT Drive
In-Reply-To: <EBEKLKENGDOIDOCHLDGLMEAKCKAA.jon@vertex-networking.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0307131821020.6878-100000@antares.mpcu.com>

On Sun, 13 Jul 2003, Jon Ladwig wrote:

> I know very little about tape back-up; just thought
> it would be useful to learn a bit more. Maybe backup
> /homes and /var/www/html. 
> 
> Any Linux gotcha's I should know about?
> 
> I'm hoping I can pick up an old internal 4mm
> unit- DDS or DDS-1 or DDS-2. Does around $25 sound
> reasonable for one of those? Brands to avoid?
> 

I'll leave the software side to the many experts who are exponentially 
smarter than me for all things tar, shell, ssh, and dd.

I would make one recommendation.  Please make sure that the DDS2 format is 
sufficient for your needs.  2/4gb may seem okay on the face of it, but 
that capacity can be easily surpassed by future needs.   I'd expect you to 
be able to find a DDS3 (12/24 gb) for $150 or so.  But then again, I 
haven't looked lately so I may be talking out my ass.  Heck for the cost 
of the drives and media, DVD +R/+RW seems to be shaping up as the 
defacto standard for DVD discs and another method for backup.  Might want 
to check this out.




From robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com  Sun Jul 13 18:37:02 2003
From: robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com (robinsoq )
Date: Sun Jul 13 18:37:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] advice on buying a cheap DAT Drive

---------- Original Message ----------------------------------
From: Wil Cooley <wcooley at nakedape.cc>
Reply-To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Date:  13 Jul 2003 17:19:16 -0700

>On Sun, 2003-07-13 at 16:57, Russell Senior wrote:
>> >>>>> "Sean" == Sean Whitney <sean at fork.com> writes:
>> 
>> Sean> [...] and I can backup through a ssh tunnel which is pretty
>> Sean> cool.
>> 
>> I can do that with /bin/tar too, e.g.:
>> 
>>   mt -f /dev/nst0 setblk 32768
>>   mt -f /dev/nst0 rewind
>>   ssh -l root <remote-hostname> 'tar -C / -clf - .' | dd of=/dev/nst0 obs=32768
>>   mt -f /dev/nst0 rewind
>>   dd if=/dev/nst0 ibs=32768 | ssh -l root <remote-host> 'tar -C / -dlf -'
>
>I think you can just set
>
># RSH=`which ssh`
># export RSH
>
>and then use
>
># tar cf hostname:/dev/ntape0
>
>At least, this is the way dump(8) works and I think GNU tar implements
>it too.
>
>Wil
>-- 
>Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
>Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc
>* * * * * *  Linux Services for Small Businesses  * * * * * *
>*       Easy, reliable solutions for small businesses       *
>*    Naked Ape Business Server http://nakedape.cc/r/sms     *
>
>

Okay, cool.  Question  I have is are your backing up the system 
your currently running or do you have to switch to another system 
to backup the one your currently running which has network support?  
I'm trying to use a Linux from scratch system as a second system to 
switch to to backup my main one.  Is there a way to bring the main 
system down to runlevel 1 and a second Linux system up to runlevel 
3 without rebooting the computer?  Are there flags for tar and dump 
to allow backing up full the current running system at runlevel 
3 or 5 without dropping to runlevel 1?

I assume rmt needs rsh and it looks like rsh can be set to ssh.

As far as tape backup, I just got 4 DI30 tapes Verbatim generics for 
around $100 which are supposed to be able to store 30 megs a piece of 
2:1 compressed data.

The tapes are expernsive but I got the drive for $150.  The secret is to 
buy at least six tapes if you get a DI30 drive now.  Everything else I've 
looked at for tape drives appears to be in the $800 to $1000+ range.  
Some models may be changers though I've heard strong recommendations to 
stay away from Travans.  The thing about libraries, tape drives that hold 
multiple tapes, is that you can't span a dump over multiple tapes.  The 
latter can supposedly be solved by using the fcut utility with tar to 
cut a large dump into pieces that will fit on individual tapes.  With 
tape drives you can either have cheap media or a cheap drive.  If you 
can afford it, an expensive drive is probably the better way to go as 
the whole point of a tape system over say hard drives is being able to 
buy a lot of tapes and do multiple backups.  Well, tapes supposedly
last longer and hold up better than hard drives too :-)

IBM has a technology called honeycomb and I imagine with a sheet of steel
and the proper laser you could manipulate atoms on the steel plate and store 
an incredible amount of data that way.  The latter technology may end up
being similar to a CD-R technology, then again it's not that hard to recycle
a plate of steel to a fresh mirror finish and reuse it.

     --  Michael C. Robinson

Yeah, a DVD writer runs about $300:

a backup solution for low-end systems.  The backup software I sell also
supports it: http://nakedape.cc/products/software/microlite

slot, 4 drive library I manage does span volumes quite nicely, thank you.

platform that does it.




From marcm at dsl-only.net  Sun Jul 13 22:36:01 2003
From: marcm at dsl-only.net (Marc)
Date: Sun Jul 13 22:36:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] usb camera
In-Reply-To: <20030714002046.GA4509@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>
References: <1058138705.1234.41.camel@localhost.localdomain> <20030714002046.GA4509@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <20030714053547.GA1389@mentorg.com>

Dirk,

Does your RH9 machine include the following in /etc/fstab:

    none  /proc/bus/usb    usbdevfs  noauto    0 0

Also, when you run "lsmod | grep -i usb", what do you get?  Here is my output
for reference:

    # lsmod | grep -i usb
    usb-storage            68628   0
    scsi_mod              106200   4  [usb-storage sg sd_mod ide-scsi]
    usb-uhci               25868   0  (unused)
    usbcore                77696   1  [usb-storage printer hid usb-uhci]

If I understand correctly, the script /etc/rc.d/rc.sysinit is responsible for
taking care of getting the modules loaded and mounting the /proc/bus/usb
directory at boot time.  

Marc


On Sun 07/13/03 17:20, Rogan Creswick wrote:
> On Sun, Jul 13, 2003 at 04:25:05PM -0700, Dirk Ouellette wrote:

From bderr at myrealbox.com  Mon Jul 14 04:31:02 2003
From: bderr at myrealbox.com (Brian Derr)
Date: Mon Jul 14 04:31:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] jazz install etc
In-Reply-To: <20030714055908.29987.qmail@web12505.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20030714055908.29987.qmail@web12505.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20030714113110.GA21515@brian.brianandkellyderr.com>

On Sun, Jul 13, 2003 at 10:59:08PM -0700, Timothy Kelly wrote:
> Hello,
>          I am brand new to this whole linux thing. 
> The main reason I use my computer is for midi
> sequencing.  I have a program called jazz that I got
> off of a cd.  I tried to install it, but when I try to
> run it, I get a message telling me to set the
> environment variable.  I tried to do this based on the
> instructions in a text file in the program, and also
> from a lycos tutorial, but have been unable to get it
> to run.  I would realy like to be able to use the
> sequencing program.  Any sugestions or advice?
> 
> Thanks

Which environment variable is it asking you to set?  Assuming you're
using bash you would set it like this:  export VARIABLE_NAME=foo

You can try the getting-started howto on www.tldp.org to learn some
of the essentials to managing a linux system.

Brian

From stevea at nwtechops.com  Mon Jul 14 05:31:01 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Mon Jul 14 05:31:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ipchains ==> howto
In-Reply-To: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCMEJACNAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
References: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCMEJACNAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <1058185762.1226.71.camel@main>

On Sun, 2003-07-13 at 22:52, Billy Dimaculangan wrote:
> i'm cnfiguring a web server and added ipchains in it. i have here the rule
> that i just added in my ipchains, but still i cannot access the page.  the
> error seems that port 80 is still unaccessible, what am i missing.  And
> after i've addded do i need to restart the server for the changes to take
> effect or just need to restart the service?
> 
> #ipchains -A input -s 0.0.0.0/0 www -d my.web.server.ip -j ACCEPT
> 
> 

You have opened a hole from all hosts/all networks coming in from source
port 80 and you need to open the destination port 80. 

The line should look like this:

#ipchains -A input -s 0.0.0.0/0 1025:65535 -d my.web.server.ip 80 -j
ACCEPT

This will allow traffic from any host/any network, destined for WWW, to
cross the INPUT chain.





From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Mon Jul 14 09:03:01 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Mon Jul 14 09:03:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] advice on buying a cheap DAT Drive
In-Reply-To: <EBEKLKENGDOIDOCHLDGLMEAKCKAA.jon@vertex-networking.com>
Message-ID: <8320-28758@sneakemail.com>

On Sun, 13 Jul 2003, Jon Ladwig jon-at-vertex-networking.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> I'm hoping I can pick up an old internal 4mm unit- DDS or DDS-1 or
> DDS-2. Does around $25 sound reasonable for one of those? Brands to
> avoid?

I've had problems with older DDS units.  In addition to the slow write
speed, the tapes seem to develop bad blocks a bit too frequently for my
needs.

I would suggest that you look into using a CD-R drive.  The write speed
can be quite high now, and I've had excellent luck with them being
readable even years down the road.

I use "dump" since I like the interactive restore feature, and it's
cheap.  (free)

  -- Steve





From mikedela at ipns.com  Mon Jul 14 09:37:02 2003
From: mikedela at ipns.com (Mike De La Mater)
Date: Mon Jul 14 09:37:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] XP Home will not see running samba
Message-ID: <1058200516.14882.48.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>

XP home won't play with my RH8.0 box. It won't "find" it, ping it or be
pinged by it. "smbclient -L 192.168.10. " shows it, but won't connect by
the name shown or IP address.

I've got running shares on RH, passwords are encrypted on the system, XP
sees peers and connects to the internet. XP is fully patched.

Googling the problem, I find similar problems, no solutions. It's been
suggested on some sites that XPHome is XPscrewed when it comes to samba.

Anybody had success connecting XP Home Edition to Samba?

-- 
Mike De La Mater
Small Business Networks and Consulting
503-702-6749

From drl at drloree.com  Mon Jul 14 10:02:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Mon Jul 14 10:02:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] XP Home will not see running samba
In-Reply-To: <1058200516.14882.48.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
References: <1058200516.14882.48.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
Message-ID: <1058202466.565.5.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Mon, 2003-07-14 at 09:35, Mike De La Mater wrote:
> XP home won't play with my RH8.0 box. It won't "find" it, ping it or be
> pinged by it. "smbclient -L 192.168.10. " shows it, but won't connect by
> the name shown or IP address.
> 
> I've got running shares on RH, passwords are encrypted on the system, XP
> sees peers and connects to the internet. XP is fully patched.
> 
> Googling the problem, I find similar problems, no solutions. It's been
> suggested on some sites that XPHome is XPscrewed when it comes to samba.
> 
> Anybody had success connecting XP Home Edition to Samba?

Do you have the RH box set up as the WINS server?

Did you turn off the Browse Master service on the XP box?

There is a utility called "Browmon" that might help sort this out.  I
think I downloaded it from M$.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

From drl at drloree.com  Mon Jul 14 11:22:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Mon Jul 14 11:22:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] XP Home will not see running samba
In-Reply-To: <oprsa9yar6wminw6@localhost>
References: <1058200516.14882.48.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
	 <1058202466.565.5.camel@fastlinux.homenet>  <oprsa9yar6wminw6@localhost>
Message-ID: <1058207254.561.15.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Mon, 2003-07-14 at 10:38, Mike De La Mater wrote:
> On 14 Jul 2003 10:07:46 -0700, Derek Loree <drl at drloree.com> wrote:
> >
> > Do you have the RH box set up as the WINS server?
> >
> > Did you turn off the Browse Master service on the XP box?
> >
> > There is a utility called "Browmon" that might help sort this out.  I
> > think I downloaded it from M$.
> 
> No the RH box is not a WINS server, It's just a simple small TCP/IP 
> network, no DHCP even.

Letting the RH box be the WINS server, and telling all other
workstations about it, will probably straighten things out.  Make sure
the OS level is greater than 128.
> 
> 
> I'm looking, but I have not found out how to turn off the browswmaster 
> switch here, it's not under file and print sharing on this PC...
> 
It's a registry setting.  HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE, System, CurrentControlSet,
Services, Browser.  Set the IsBrowseMaster and MaintainList to "false".

Good Luck,

Derek Loree




From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Mon Jul 14 14:33:01 2003
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler Creelan)
Date: Mon Jul 14 14:33:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] M-x q under Vim ?
Message-ID: <20030714213228.GA19909@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Hi folks -

What is the Vim equivalent of "M-x q" under Emacs? For example what
command in Vim will format a paragraph of ragged lines, like this:

"Storm Claudette took 
aim for the Texas coast Monday slightly farther north then expected, 
prompting a 
hurricane 
warning from Baffin"

Any pointers on how to search for this sort of thing in the vim docs? 

TFC



From rob at euglug.net  Mon Jul 14 14:39:02 2003
From: rob at euglug.net (Rob Hudson)
Date: Mon Jul 14 14:39:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] M-x q under Vim ?
In-Reply-To: <20030714213228.GA19909@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>; from creelan@engr.orst.edu on Mon, Jul 14, 2003 at 02:32:28PM -0700
References: <20030714213228.GA19909@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <20030714143711.B68963@cogit8.org>

gq}

the '}' means to the end of a paragraph.


> On 20030714.1432, Tyler Creelan said ...
>
> Hi folks -

> "Storm Claudette took 
> aim for the Texas coast Monday slightly farther north then expected, 
> prompting a 
> hurricane 
> warning from Baffin"

> Any pointers on how to search for this sort of thing in the vim docs?

From heinlein at madboa.com  Mon Jul 14 14:50:02 2003
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon Jul 14 14:50:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] M-x q under Vim ?
In-Reply-To: <20030714143711.B68963@cogit8.org>
References: <20030714213228.GA19909@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU> <20030714143711.B68963@cogit8.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0307141445390.27809@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 14 Jul 2003, Rob Hudson wrote:

> gq}
>
> the '}' means to the end of a paragraph.

Or, in the spirit of "there's more than one way to do things":

  !}fmt

which will pipe the following paragraph though the fmt(1) utility.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>



From plug at ardware.net  Mon Jul 14 15:05:02 2003
From: plug at ardware.net (Andrew Dennis)
Date: Mon Jul 14 15:05:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] USB Interrupts - Chunky Mouse
Message-ID: <3F132943.5060700@ardware.net>

So I have determined that my chunky mouse behavior is caused
by the overloading of my interrupt 9 with way too many
devices.

I did some research and one source said that it's impossible to
reassign interrupts on my machine, a Sony Vaio FX220 laptop.

Is this true, or is there a magical way to offload some of the
tasks onto another interrupts?  Below is what /proc/interrupts
contains.


Thanks

Andy


# more /proc/interrupts
           CPU0
  0:    2677433          XT-PIC  timer
  1:       7497          XT-PIC  keyboard
  2:          0          XT-PIC  cascade
  8:          2          XT-PIC  rtc
  9:     522154          XT-PIC  acpi, eth0, usb-uhci, usb-uhci, Intel 
82801BA-I
CH2, i810 at PCI:0:2:0
 12:        152          XT-PIC  PS/2 Mouse
 14:      78427          XT-PIC  ide0
 15:         47          XT-PIC  ide1
NMI:          0
LOC:          0
ERR:          0
MIS:          0

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Mon Jul 14 15:35:02 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Mon Jul 14 15:35:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] M-x q under Vim ?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0307141517580.23012-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0307141517580.23012-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1058221967.2632.84.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Mon, 2003-07-14 at 15:19, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   Wow! In emacs I use alt-q (or, meta-q in emacian). Fewer stokes for
> diff'rent folks. :-)

I shouldn't respond lest this quickly devolve into a vi-vs-emacs flame
war, but most people map the necessary keystrokes.  Mine is mapped to
CTRL-K.

.vimrc:
map <C-K> j{!}fmt -w76 -u<cr>}


Wil

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Mon Jul 14 17:58:01 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Mon Jul 14 17:58:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ATA vs. SCSI
Message-ID: <16648-65976@sneakemail.com>

At the risk of inviting this age-old flame-war to once again visit PLUG, I
had to pass along a really interesting article I found.  As the authors
are from Seagate, one can expect it to be biased towards the more
expensive drives, but I found the discussion to be quite
interesting.  It also has extensively documented references.

The article can be found at:

http://www.seagate.com/content/docs/pdf/whitepaper/D2c_More_than_Interface_ATA_vs_SCSI_042003.pdf

or

ftp://ftp.gutenpress.org/mbrs/sean/ATA_vs_SCSI.pdf

The article doesn't discuss the effects of RAID on overall
reliability/performance, though they do discuss how "consumer" grade
disks are designed around single-disk enclosures and suffer more problems
from the vibrations of other disks around them than "enterprise" grade
disks.

I found it via a current slashdot article here:

http://slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=03/07/13/0349206

I hope some of you find it as interesting as I did.

  -- Steve Bonds




From jeme at brelin.net  Mon Jul 14 19:21:02 2003

From drl at drloree.com  Mon Jul 14 20:26:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Mon Jul 14 20:26:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] USB Interrupts - Chunky Mouse
In-Reply-To: <3F132943.5060700@ardware.net>
References: <3F132943.5060700@ardware.net>
Message-ID: <1058239895.8521.593.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Mon, 2003-07-14 at 15:05, Andrew Dennis wrote:
> So I have determined that my chunky mouse behavior is caused
> by the overloading of my interrupt 9 with way too many
> devices.
> 
> I did some research and one source said that it's impossible to
> reassign interrupts on my machine, a Sony Vaio FX220 laptop.
> 
> Is this true, or is there a magical way to offload some of the
> tasks onto another interrupts?  Below is what /proc/interrupts
> contains.

There is no magical way, but there are some things to try.  Turning off
ACPI support might do it (beware that your win2k might not boot). 
Turning off "Assign IRQ to USB" might do it.  Changing slots with your
eth0 device might do it.  Sometimes you need to enable a reset or
reassignment.  A new, freshly rolled kernel might do it too.  Isn't plug
and pray fun?

Good Luck,

Derek Loree





From rob at euglug.net  Mon Jul 14 20:28:01 2003
From: rob at euglug.net (Rob Hudson)
Date: Mon Jul 14 20:28:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Spamassassin, procmail, and wtf
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0307141932180.25591@shaft.bitmine.net>; from jeme@brelin.net on Mon, Jul 14, 2003 at 07:33:39PM -0700
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0307141919050.25591@shaft.bitmine.net> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0307141923140.25591@shaft.bitmine.net> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0307141932180.25591@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <20030714202605.A70336@cogit8.org>

I've got this in my mutt rc file:

# Using no-rebuild to take less time.  Have to run rebuild occassionally (cron)
macro index \cb         "| sa-learn --spam --no-rebuild --single" "Learn as spam"

So when a spam comes in, I press Ctrl-b (b = baaaad).

-Rob

I also have a cron job that runs that looks like this:

## Rebuild Bayesian database for SpamAssassin
##
30  1 * * * root  /usr/local/bin/sa-learn --rebuild


Since I'm telling it not to rebuild since, from the sounds of it, is
somewhat time-consuming.

-Rob

Curious though.  It says using the DB is very CPU intensive.  Does that
mean the SA will get worst and worst as the DB builds?  Seems very counter
productive if that is the case.

this, does this result in all messages in the cd directory to be handed to
SA one at a time to be 'learnt'?  Can I just feed it a file of my email
messages?  example:  /home/josh/mail/learn_spam

I see sa-learn has the argument -mbox and -file but not sure if that means
the type of files that are directories like the mail is stored.

Thanks again.  This sounds promising but the CPU drain warning seems very
threatening to proformance.

Josh



From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Mon Jul 14 23:18:01 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)

Message-ID: <1058249793.2632.209.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Mon, 2003-07-14 at 22:58, Rob Hudson wrote:
> Yep.  :)
> 
> I also have a cron job that runs that looks like this:
> 
> ## Rebuild Bayesian database for SpamAssassin
> ##
> 30  1 * * * root  /usr/local/bin/sa-learn --rebuild

> Since I'm telling it not to rebuild since, from the sounds of it, is
> somewhat time-consuming.

I don't think you need to do that if you're running 2.55; it's supposed
to handle auto-expiration and stuff a lot better than the previous
couple.  Ah, maybe so.

Also, I recommend to anyone using SA that you also install Razor2 and
DCC.  I just recently added DCC and updated from Razor1 to Razor2 and
I've cut out almost all of that 10% of spam I was missing.

Is anyone keeping track of their SA scores, such as for the high score
competition? 
http://news.spamassassin.org/modules.php?op=modload&name=News&file=article&sid=25&mode=nested&order=1&thold=0

I've only been paying attention for a couple of days, but I've already
got one 47.10.


Wil
