From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Fri Jul 25 10:32:02 2003
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: Fri Jul 25 10:32:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Running RPM -Uvh gives segmentation fault
In-Reply-To: <1059102383.1479.12.camel@atlas.cadtocam.com>
References: <016501c35139$20a5fa40$bf00000a@quantecllc.com>
	 <1059083032.1557.91.camel@kat>
	 <1059102383.1479.12.camel@atlas.cadtocam.com>
Message-ID: <1059154224.1557.194.camel@kat>

On Thu, 2003-07-24 at 20:06, Kenneth G. Stephens wrote:
> r
> 
> How about  doing an rpm2cpio on the rpm and seeing if the package is
> complete.  You can actually get a file list and information directly
> from the package by using:
> 
> rpm -qilp package.name.rpm
> 
> Ken

Eric recommended the -K option which is the same as checksig.  From the
man page:

      rpm {--checksig} [--nosignature] [--nodigest]
           PACKAGE_FILE ...

       The  --checksig  option checks all the digests and signatures contained
       in PACKAGE_FILE to ensure the integrity and origin of the package. Note
       that  signatures  are  now  verified  whenever  a  package is read, and
       --checksig is useful to verify all of the digests and signatures  asso-
       ciated with a package.

       Digital  signatures  cannot be verified without a public key.  An ascii
       armored public key can be added to the rpm database using --import.  An
       imported  public key is carried in a header, and key ring management is
       performed exactly like package management. For example,  all  currently
       imported public keys can be displayed by:


Now I am not sure if the internals to know if this really works, i.e. it
checks every file, or if it checks a sig to the whole cpio....


-- 
Zot O'Connor

http://www.ZotConsulting.com
http://www.WhiteKnightHackers.com




From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Fri Jul 25 10:36:01 2003
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: Fri Jul 25 10:36:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] printer issue
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0307250923050.30610@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: 
	 <Pine.LNX.4.44.0307250854370.15636-100000@aluminum.bavariati.org>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0307250923050.30610@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1059154494.1557.199.camel@kat>

>   OO.o can be a major PITA to configure properly and consistently. As root
> you need to run spdadmin to set up the printers.

Actually you can do as this as a user, and it saves the files as a user
(in ~/OpenOffice.xxx)

>
>  You also need to define the
> layout you want -- including page size and margins -- and save that as the
> default. I find all this to be rather ugly and a bother each time I upgrade,
> but that's the price to be paid for slavishly following Microsoft.

A lot of these values can be copied, but the pattern does not take long
for me.  OpenOffice has a better understanding of the printers than
merely "lp" so you have to set it up.  The abstraction layer of lpr
prevents apps from being able to tweak a printer (like margin, fonts,
etc.)  In windows this is done somewhat automatically since the printer
driver is evident in the local OS.

-- 
Zot O'Connor

http://www.ZotConsulting.com
http://www.WhiteKnightHackers.com

makes a point.

From robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com  Fri Jul 25 12:49:01 2003
From: robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com (robinsoq )
Date: Fri Jul 25 12:49:01 2003
Subject: Integrated MB (was: Re: [PLUG] New Linux PVR)
Message-ID: <200307251248.AA45088984@opusnet.com>

>
>> On Thu, 2003-07-24 at 01:10, robinsoq wrote:
>> > There was
>> > a time in the 386 era when nothing was integrated and you had real control
>> > over hardware, will we ever see those days again?  Less integration may
>> > have meant more cost but how much does it cost to throw out a whole entire
>> > motherboard let alone potentially the processor too?
>>
>> You can still find motherboards without sound and video and modems, etc,
>> integrated onto them; it is hard (or perhaps impossible) to find one
>> without an IDE controller build into it though.
>>
>> Personally, I don't want to go back to the bad old days - I like not
>> having to buy 3 cards to supply video, sound, and ethernet and have no
>> trouble finding motherboards that are compatible with linux.  Also from
>> what I can remember one can buy four P4 motherboards and CPUs for the
>> cost of one 386mb+cpu back in the day.
>>
>> --Brent
>>
Careful about doing cost arguments without adjusting for inflation.
Some technological change that is not dependent on integration would
make it cheaper to produce boards that are non integrated likes the
ones in the 386 days...

My problem is this:

    The quality of PC computers is arguably as bas as it was before the 386.

    With the 386 a number of standardizations from the IDE hard drive
    controller to a standard expansion bus speed to a true 32 bit 
    architecture made matters better than they had been.

    Today as much as you might be told about modern Intel machines is that
    they are 386's on steroids.  If all the changes since the 386 were truly
    transparent we wouldn't be talking about cleaning up the PC as much as
    we are these days.

    Who offers a fool proof service to assist in choosing motherboards
    and other PC parts that will be 100% under Linux even under proper
    QC tests at a price that the general public can even consider?

    Integration forces you to choose a lot of parts at once which makes
    purchasing a motherboard a difficult business.  With Linux, being
    able to ignore bios and the fact that chipsets are being modified 
    in arcane and mysterious ways for onboard devices, incompatible
    devices can very easily mean that your toast.

    It's not like the old days where pulling a card out meant for sure 
    that it was gone where the chipsets were fairly standard.

    My frustration with Intel is this:

          1) An attitude of zero responsibility for labeling products
             that are poorly tested or have experimental parts on them.

          2) An attitude about IP that the information to produce a 
             suitable Linux driver for one of their products whether
             integrated or not is solely the property of Intel even
             when Intel fails to produce that suitable driver.

          3) A proprosed opinion that it is absurd and impossible to
             write drivers for Linux systems because of the number of
             distributions, kernels, etc...

I proprose Intel addresses the above problems in one to four ways:

          a)  Release the blue prints for components that are not well
              supported under Linux to the public.

          b)  Do a release to third parties under nondisclosure
              agreement that can be expected to produce the
              drivers that Intel itself either can't or won't.

          c)  Just label products better so that it's easier to find
              the ones that won't work well for a particular purpose
              including Linux use.

          d)  Require Engineers designing Intel products to familiarize
              themselves better with Linux.

As far as the absurdity opinion on writing drivers, what's wrong with
taking the current standard kernel as a base and working from there?
After all, who cares if there are multiple kernel branches so long
as companies make a good faith effort to stay within the kernel's
important structures and critical Linux architectural boundaries?
I thought API's among other things are supposed to make it possible
for various players to work independently of one another to develop
on the same platform.  Linux has documentation on how to add drivers
to the kernel properly, if a novice can find this why can't Intel?

          --  Michael C. Robinson

who will see the stupid message and also get annoyed.  Then if they are
cleaver and feel like having fun will just remove your header and replace

so the users can't complain.  Either case it has the potential to be a big
waste of production to many people, even if it is funny.

whatever you like.  I'm sure the next version of KDE mail will read the
headers and display them like MS does anyhow.  Then everyone will be
confused.  :-)

From robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com  Fri Jul 25 20:05:03 2003

Subject: [PLUG] Asus P5S-VM and msclient 3...

I'm trying to set up a netbootable msclient 3.0 dos 6.2 image on my Linux box
for an asus P5S-VM machine that has an Fa311 card in it.  Updating fa311.dos fixed
it so that it would finish booting...  however, the pop up still crashes.  This is
the only computer I have that does this and I've pulled everything thinking a
card might be causing this...  It has to be the built in video.  Is there a trick
with emm386 or something to map the video cards memory or is this something else?

Well, at the very least the net use commands now work on that machine.  I have a 
secondary network set up with a dedicated samba server to distributed 98SE's
cab files from.  The pop up is the equivalent of network neighborhood under 98SE
and is very convenient, when it works.

This is limited to 8.3 filenames but it's a nice stand in until I get a netbootable
to ramdisk Linux system working.

Actually the board has a phoenix bios and is an HP OEM product out of a builders
lot of 50 or so of these.  The board revision is 1.01 if that's a clue at all.

     --  Michael C. Robinson   



From robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com  Fri Jul 25 21:10:02 2003
From: robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com (robinsoq )
Date: Fri Jul 25 21:10:02 2003
Subject: Integrated MB (was: Re: [PLUG] New Linux PVR)
Message-ID: <200307252109.AA78905560@opusnet.com>

>Realize Intel's primary chipset customers are vendors like Dell, HP, and
>Gateway, few of which plan on shipping linux desktop systems. Intel is
>probably hesitant to produce linux drivers until their customers want
>them.


Linux can run on a playstation II of all things.  It is very popular.
Intel is creating a chicken and the egg situation.  If Intel doesn't
rate it's products for Linux people are afraid to switch.  The problem
with Gateway, Dell, etc. are that these companies tend to produce
proprietary systems that can only use the operating system they
provide, or at least these companies seem to be trying to accomplish 
that.  The trouble with Microsoft software is the proprosition that 
you have an alternative where you need to pay Microsoft a lot
of cash for no support to use Windows.

What kind of alternative is there if the only way for Linux to run 
on some Intel hardware is for a hacker to reverse engineer it?  
Someone can and likely will do this, however, by the time it happens 
Windows may have unfairly win as "best" choice and the myth that 
noone wants to use Linux for their workstation purposes is 
perpetuated to another generation of Intel PC's.

Intel is lying if it says it can't provide a full featured alsa
driver for the D845PEBT2 under Linux where the card reportedly works 
under XP without a hitch.  The only reason to integrate an alsa 
instead of a Linux supported alternative such as a soundblaster 
live that I can see is to give Windows XP an unfair advantage
over Linux.

There needs to be a law to support people who want to build Linux
systems in a market controlled by Dell, Gateway, Compaq...  These 
companies have sealed up the reality of Intel for Windows only for 
years.  All I would hope for is priviledged access to hardware blue 
prints for a company that builds Linux based workstation PC's.  
Otherwise, I hope Intel takes their alsa driver for Linux to a 
truly functional level addressing whatever seg fault issues they
have run into and increasing the number of channels supported 
to all eight instead of just two.

How can the public tell Intel they want solid Linux compatibility
information on Intel products?  I bet you a million bucks the plug
list could generate a ton of original requests for Intel to adjust 
business practices and better support Linux if information on where
to send those requests were provided.  If Intel is truly committed
to finding out if people wabt to switch to Linux and potentially
support that fully why aren't there questionnares about Linux 
interest on Intel's web site or with newly purchased Intel products?

Anyone who believes there isn't pursueable interest in Linux on the
desktop hasn't paid enough attention to this list nor have they
paid enough attention to Linux in general.

If Intel officially claims that people want XP instead of Linux,
regardless of public sentiment, the only choice the public is
going to have is to abandon Intel entirely where the goal is
to build a Linux workstation.  I have with the system I'm 
building now which is an Athlon.

Maynard and Beatte, two Intel employees, are plenty smart enough
to figure out how to develop hardware with Linux compatibility
in mind.

     -- Michael C. Robinson

From robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com  Sat Jul 26 06:52:01 2003
From: robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com (robinsoq )
Date: Sat Jul 26 06:52:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Skutch AS-4 verses a more expensive...
Message-ID: <200307260651.AA232915072@opusnet.com>

telephone line simulator.  Is the AS-4 sufficient for setting up a test
between a Linux dial-up server and some dial-up client?  The ad says you
have to play with a ringer switch to make it work.  I'm asking to determine
whether or not I should really try to win an auction for one or if I should
let it go because it won't do the trick.  The AS-4 is a LOT cheaper than
alternative single line telephone simulators like the TLS-3 or TLS-4.  
I just want to play with setting up a dial up server using an old 386 
I have for the server side and anoher old machine for a client.

The other simulators on E-Bay all appear to cost more than $100.  For 
that kind of money I might as well pay for two more normal phone lines 
for a month to two.   In Scappoose two months even for two lines 
out of pocket including $40 hookup fee, don't know about extended 
area service, will probably cost as much or less than a single 
TLS-3 or TLS-4 simulator. 

The nice thing about the AS-4 is that it costs about as much as a local 
service line, assuming the auction will go for between $25 to $40, for 
a single month minus the $40 hookup fee.  The advantage of a simulator 
is no time limit on using it and you're not too far apart in a situation
where you block a partners only phone line.

If a more expensive simulator is what's needed to test a dial-up
server without using local phonelines I can always save for one 
long term.

Come to think of it, I think a lot of the cell phones have dial-up
service through a built-in modem.  Problem with cell phones is that
there is no such thing as a local service area where you usually buy
one for cheap long distance or roadside emergencies.

I wonder if it is necessary with the AS-4 to use the ringer or if
you just have to pick up on both ends of the simulator simultaneously
to have a connection.  For a modem test it should be possible to work
without a ringer.

     --  Michael C. Robinson  



From robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com  Sat Jul 26 08:04:02 2003
From: robinsoq at mail.opusnet.com (robinsoq )
Date: Sat Jul 26 08:04:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Optional programmable roms...
Message-ID: <200307260803.AA114688210@opusnet.com>

Does anyone know where to get an extended rom card?  My fa311 doesn't have a bootrom
socket where the fa312 is so expensive it doesn't seem worth it.  I wonder if PXE
can be installed into the flash ram of a FIC VA503+, ASUS P5S-VM, or ASUS P5A-B
with the bios?

The etherboot documentation talks about an ISA card you can build with a EPROM
on it to program PXE or etherboot into, I wonder if anyone sells such a card?  
How about a PCI version?  Many machines have open expansion slots, I'm surprised
bootprom sockets weren't succeeded by an extra card a long time ago since a lot
of nics no longer have the socket and it's often difficult to get the right EPROM
or EEPROM.  I guess 32k and 64k NVRAM used in cell phones isn't that expensive
anymore.

A rom card depending on how much memory it has is useful for more than just
setting up PXE where the onboard nic won't take a boot chip.  It is also
interesting for turning say an old pentium into a switch via an embedded 
Linux system.  A more practical use may be to build a Linux tape server 
in a rom.  A firewall appliance also comes to mind.

Using a disk drive to start etherboot or pxe is a royal pain even with xosl
making it easier to get to say a local Linux or Windows system without
having to eject the etherboot floppy all the time.  Unless you don't use
the floppy drive it's easy to lose the netbooting disk.

The other option I suppose is to install two 1.44 meg floppy drives so that
the etherboot disk never has to be taken out.  I guess the smart move would
be to program xosl to boot drive b and call the selection etherboot. 

Will etherboot fit on a 1.2 meg disk?  Does anyone make 5.25" inch floppies
anymore?  I need some low density 5.25" disks for my color computer where 
some of our newer computers have a 5.25" inch drive.  I'm uncertain if you 
can add a third disk drive to the standard onboard floppy controller on 
most motherboards let alone if xosl can boot to a third floppy drive.

   --  Michael C. Robinson 



From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sat Jul 26 09:03:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sat Jul 26 09:03:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Disappearing network interface
In-Reply-To: <1059016680.17129.55.camel@main>

On Wed, 23 Jul 2003, Steven A. Adams wrote:

> >   According to the linux on laptops Web site, the Zonet fast ethernet cards
> > require the pcnet_cs module. Anyone know where I can find such a beast for
> > the 2.4.20 kernel in Slackware-9.0.0?

> Here's a couple of interesting links that you can look too:
> The first is the source for pcnet_cs, the second is the project source
> for the pcmcia-cs project.

Steve, et al.:

  The pcnet_cs module is in /etc/rc.d/rc.pcmcia. The process, /sbin/cardmgr,
is in the list waiting to be run. 'lsmod' shows pcmcia_core is loaded.
'find' doesn't find pcnet_cs.

  I seem to be stuck in a deep rut here. If pcnet_cs is listed in
/etc/rc.d/rc.pcmcia, shouldn't it be loaded if a card requiring that module
is in the slot? I did try '/etc/rc.d/rc.pcmcia stop' followed by 'start'
with no different results.

  When I read 'dmesg' I see that the card is properly detected, then
cardservices are unloaded:

8139too Fast Ethernet driver 0.9.26
8139too Fast Ethernet driver 0.9.26
scsi0 : SCSI host adapter emulation for IDE ATAPI devices
Linux Kernel Card Services 3.1.22
  options:  [pci] [cardbus] [pm]
isapnp: Scanning for PnP cards...
isapnp: No Plug & Play device found
Intel PCIC probe: not found.
Databook TCIC-2 PCMCIA probe: not found.
PCI: Found IRQ 11 for device 00:02.0
PCI: Sharing IRQ 11 with 00:06.0
PCI: Sharing IRQ 11 with 01:00.0
PCI: Found IRQ 11 for device 00:02.1
Yenta IRQ list 0618, PCI irq11
Socket status: 30000006
Yenta IRQ list 0618, PCI irq11
Socket status: 30000006
cs: IO port probe 0x0c00-0x0cff: clean.
cs: IO port probe 0x0800-0x08ff: clean.
cs: IO port probe 0x0100-0x04ff: excluding 0x130-0x137 0x170-0x177 0x200-0x207 0x220-0x22f 0x370-0x37f 0x388-0x38f 0x3b8-0x3df 0x4d0-0x4d7

... (a bunch of USB stuff)
unloading Kernel Card Services
Linux Kernel Card Services 3.1.22
  options:  [pci] [cardbus] [pm]
... (the above repeats)

  Can someone interpret this for me, please? What am I missing in order to

unreachable". It must have something to do with the pcnet_cs module not
being loaded.

> Steve, et al.:
> 
>   The pcnet_cs module is in /etc/rc.d/rc.pcmcia. The process, /sbin/cardmgr,
> is in the list waiting to be run. 'lsmod' shows pcmcia_core is loaded.
> 'find' doesn't find pcnet_cs.

Look for  pcnet_cs.o.  You might look at /etc/modules.conf and see if
any alias statement refers to that module.  Should be in
/lib/modules/`uname -r`/kernel/drivers/net/
> 
>   I seem to be stuck in a deep rut here. If pcnet_cs is listed in
> /etc/rc.d/rc.pcmcia, shouldn't it be loaded if a card requiring that module

> with no different results.

On Sat, 2003-07-26 at 09:01, Rich Shepard wrote:
> Steve, et al.:
> 
>   The pcnet_cs module is in /etc/rc.d/rc.pcmcia. The process, /sbin/cardmgr,
> is in the list waiting to be run. 'lsmod' shows pcmcia_core is loaded.
> 'find' doesn't find pcnet_cs.
> 
>   I seem to be stuck in a deep rut here. If pcnet_cs is listed in
> /etc/rc.d/rc.pcmcia, shouldn't it be loaded if a card requiring that module
> is in the slot? I did try '/etc/rc.d/rc.pcmcia stop' followed by 'start'
> with no different results.
> 
>   When I read 'dmesg' I see that the card is properly detected, then
> cardservices are unloaded:
> 
> 8139too Fast Ethernet driver 0.9.26
> 8139too Fast Ethernet driver 0.9.26
> scsi0 : SCSI host adapter emulation for IDE ATAPI devices
> Linux Kernel Card Services 3.1.22
>   options:  [pci] [cardbus] [pm]
> isapnp: Scanning for PnP cards...
> isapnp: No Plug & Play device found
> Intel PCIC probe: not found.
> Databook TCIC-2 PCMCIA probe: not found.
> PCI: Found IRQ 11 for device 00:02.0
> PCI: Sharing IRQ 11 with 00:06.0
> PCI: Sharing IRQ 11 with 01:00.0
> PCI: Found IRQ 11 for device 00:02.1
> Yenta IRQ list 0618, PCI irq11
> Socket status: 30000006
> Yenta IRQ list 0618, PCI irq11
> Socket status: 30000006
> cs: IO port probe 0x0c00-0x0cff: clean.
> cs: IO port probe 0x0800-0x08ff: clean.
> cs: IO port probe 0x0100-0x04ff: excluding 0x130-0x137 0x170-0x177 0x200-0x207 0x220-0x22f 0x370-0x37f 0x388-0x38f 0x3b8-0x3df 0x4d0-0x4d7
> cs: IO port probe 0x0a00-0x0aff: clean.
> cs: cb_alloc(bus 2): vendor 0x10ec, device 0x8139
> PCI: Enabling device 02:00.0 (0000 -> 0003)
> ... (a bunch of USB stuff)
> unloading Kernel Card Services
> Linux Kernel Card Services 3.1.22
>   options:  [pci] [cardbus] [pm]
> ... (the above repeats)
> 

Does the alias line for pcmcia (in /etc/modules.conf) have an option
entry line associated with it? You might add one with the option cardbus
if it doesn't already exist. Also, in prior years there were issues with
pcmcia in laptops not keeping up with the specification as quickly as
the cards were. Take a look at the BIOS revision of the laptop and make
sure it supports the cardbus revision of the NIC that your using.

> Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President

Are you sure of that model number? According to netgear.com, it does not 
exist. 

At any rate, to find the chipset, run lspci. Do lspci -v for more details. 
Then you can find the correct driver. Chipsets are more meaningful than model 
numbers, as hardware manufacturers like to mix n match, and not bother to 
tell us. After all, us non-Winduhs customers don't count.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sat Jul 26 21:50:02 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Sat Jul 26 21:50:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] [Debian] duplicating a set of installed packages between systems?
In-Reply-To: <86ispoaprc.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <86ispoaprc.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <86smos8th6.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Russell" == Russell Senior <seniorr at aracnet.com> writes:

Russell> I had a harddisk failure this morning that boogered the root
Russell> directory on my desktop system.  I lost some files and want
Russell> to do a clean debian install, but I want to duplicate the set
Russell> of packages I had installed before.  I presume there is a
Russell> dpkg status file or something similar that has the
Russell> information this would need.  Does anyone know how?

After having a nice time talking to the neighbors at the summer block
party, the answer gradually came to me: dpkg --get-selections and dpkg
--set-selections < foo.  I don't immediately see a way to force a
particular (the old) status file (except to temporarily copy it into
the right location) and then move the real one back.  Then I needed to
run dselect or aptitude afterwards to actually install the
selections.  Seems to be working!


--

seniorr at aracnet.com      mrlosh''  -- Bashgali Kafir for ``If you have
                         had diarrhoea many days you will surely die.''

From karl.vollmer at orst.edu  Sun Jul 27 02:22:02 2003
From: karl.vollmer at orst.edu (Vollmer, Karl)
Date: Sun Jul 27 02:22:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Maintain 2.1-beta1 Released
Message-ID: <5E5DC8D41EED984B8400631297D489706DB3@mtshasta.nws.oregonstate.edu>

Hello,
 
 	We are proud to announce the release of Maintain 2.1-beta1 under the GPL. It is now available for download from http://oss.oregonstate.edu/maintain/download.php. This release requires a great deal of configuration to get working.  We
will be working on ease-of-use and installation in future versions but want to get something out now. Please report any bugs you encounter to maintain-devel at lists.orst.edu. Feedback and feature requests are always welcome. 

 Features:
 
     * Web-based interface for DNS/DHCP management
     * Ability to delegate authority of zone information to individual users/groups
     * Quick updates (compleate config builds in ~60 seconds)
     * Advanced error reporting for zone transfers and DHCP server problems
     * Generate zone files and DHCP configurations for primary and secondary DNS & DHCP
       servers
     * Edit host information including MAC address, hostname, domain name, etc.
     * Zone statistics such as total bandwidth used and bandwidth history for individual
       hosts (requires flo module)
     * Support for automatic registration on public networks (using authentication)
     * Search on any informational field, domain name, ip address, hardware type...
     * Ability to develop additional features through a module interface
     * Automatic Host Expiration
     * Many bug fixes and code improvements over previous versions
     * Enhanced Auto-registration tools.
     * Searchable Host History
     * Improved Domain Migration Module
     * Display of Subnet/Workgroup options on each host
     * Improvement of Administrative tools
     * Support for LDAP and Mysql authentication
     * Edit and Create all DNS records
     * And many many more. . .
 
 For more Information about Maintain please visit 
 	http://oss.oregonstate.edu/maintain/
 
 For help with installation and development discussion please visit

	http://oss.oregonstate.edu/forums/

 You can also find us on irc.freenode.net in #maintain 

Thanks,
 
-Karl Vollmer
Maintain Development Team
Oregon State University, Network Engineering
Maintain-devel at lists.orst.edu

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sun Jul 27 07:50:02 2003

Date: Sun Jul 27 07:50:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] KVM switch
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0307270746340.21955@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  As I set up my new workstation/server I want to use the same keyboard,
monitor and mouse with it and the old box. There seem to be quite a few
brands available for these switches.

  Does anyone have experience with them and can provide thoughts on what to
get or what to avoid?

Thanks,

From kgmorse at mpcu.com  Sun Jul 27 08:36:02 2003
From: kgmorse at mpcu.com (Keith Morse)
Date: Sun Jul 27 08:36:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] KVM switch
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0307270746340.21955@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Sun, 27 Jul 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   As I set up my new workstation/server I want to use the same keyboard,
> monitor and mouse with it and the old box. There seem to be quite a few
> brands available for these switches.
> 
>   Does anyone have experience with them and can provide thoughts on what to
> get or what to avoid?
> 


I've heard of mouse issues with some of the cheaper KVM's. I don't like 
the low Dlink ones.  It appears the firmware doesn't provide a method for 
disabling the annoying screen identifier.  The high end stuff, Avocent 
(formerly Cybex) and Blackbox all seem to work well.

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Sun Jul 27 09:10:02 2003
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Sun Jul 27 09:10:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] KVM switch
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0307270746340.21955@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <3F23F949.8010102@pacifier.com>

Rich Shepard wrote:
>   As I set up my new workstation/server I want to use the same keyboard,
> monitor and mouse with it and the old box. There seem to be quite a few
> brands available for these switches.
> 
>   Does anyone have experience with them and can provide thoughts on what to
> get or what to avoid?

I have a Cybex 4-port SwitchView, that works mostly.  Doesn't work with 
Toshiba laptop, though--I either get mouse or keyboard control, but not 
both.  Another time, it stopped responding to the hot-key sequence 
<ctrl><ctrl> which required hitting the select button on the front.  It 
seems to be working again.

Have used the more professional Commander which worked flawlessly, but at 
$600 it was not for home use.

If your machines use USB, make sure your KVM can.  As Robby just mentioned 
Synergy, which may work for you, note from the FAQ:

	# Can synergy share the display in addition to the mouse and 			keyboard?

	No. Synergy is a KM solution not a KVM (keyboard, video, mouse) 		solution. 
However, future versions will probably support KVM. 			Hopefully, this will 
make synergy suitable for managing large 			numbers of headless servers.

Cheers,
Kyle Accardi

From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Sun Jul 27 10:30:02 2003
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: Sun Jul 27 10:30:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] KVM switch
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0307270746340.21955@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0307270746340.21955@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1059326890.1557.236.camel@kat>

On Sun, 2003-07-27 at 07:48, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   Does anyone have experience with them and can provide thoughts on what to
> get or what to avoid?

The best ones I have used so far are the el cheapo from Fry.  The boxes
say "ICS" And as best I can see it is Intelligent Computer Switch.  The
16 port ones are called Maestro I think.  It passed the all important
"Can I boot NT and still get a mouse working without watching the
frickin' NT boot screens?" test.  Linksys and several others did not
pass this test.  Mine is about 4 years old.

The only issue is that scroll mice do not work through them (under
linux).  This is *now* a showstopper for me.

This is the 4 port version.  The things I like:  Talks to AT or PS/2
keyboards, talks to ps/2 or serial mice ports (requires PS/2 mouse). 
Cables are standard cables, albeit gender bendering odd, the GQ cheap
cables work great, this can save a bundle.

If I had to but another one I would look for one that accepts USB
keyboards and mice.  Cutting a cable out is awesome, esp when the new
cable is standard.  This is one of the best uses of USB I have ever
seen.

The cost of 2 v 4 is minimal, so I would go with 4.  This would allow
you to put your laptop on there as well.

Things I would avoid:  Physical switches.  They tend to break.  They are
cheap though.  I have one for 6 years, and a few paper weights.

Some other things:

When buying the cables.  Take the box and the cables over to a PC and
open them and test them.  Whenever I fail to do this I get some gender
wrong.  I have a bag full of incorrect cables, some exactly like the
others I previously mis-bought.  Getting gender, length and pin type is
tricky.  Also check every package.  The packages get mixed on the
shelves, and when you buy 30 cables, getting a M-M HD15 bag (or a
couple) instead of VGA pin outs, sucks.  Each time, it sucks more.

When you are done, twist tie or cable tie the cables.  Then *label*
them, esp mouse vs keyboard.



-- 
Zot O'Connor

http://www.ZotConsulting.com
http://www.WhiteKnightHackers.com

On Sun, 27 Jul 2003, Tyler Creelan wrote:

> Just curious - what's the advantage of a KVM versus SSHing into the
> second box, with serial console as backup in case the network fails?

  Good point. I can take the new box to the dining room, hook up a monitor
and keyboard there and install the OS separately. Then I can see if there's
any hassle getting it connected to the network. Once that works, what I want
to do is copy all of /usr/local /usr1 and /opt to the new box.

  My plan is to copy off everything that's not kernel/GNU tool-specific.
Then, when I'm comfortable that everything on the old box is up and running
on the new one, I can shut down the old one, transplant the SCSI adapter,
cd-rw and tape drive to the new box, boot the new one and expect to have it
all run perfectly.

  I thought it easier to do the transfers using a kvm setup, but I can tar
an entire file system and move it across via scp. Thank you for pointing out
the obvious to me.

  Because I use the soon-to-be-replaced box as my main server/workstation in
a production environment (i.e., my business), I want to make the transfer
error-free, quick, reliable and easy. If I've missed something in my
strategy, please let me know.

Rich

Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President

            2404 SW 22nd Street | Troutdale, OR 97060-1247 | U.S.A.
 + 1 503-667-4517 (voice) | + 1 503-667-8863 (fax) | rshepard&#64;appl-ecosys.com

Rich>   I thought it easier to do the transfers using a kvm setup, but
Rich> I can tar an entire file system and move it across via
Rich> scp. 

Unless you want to save an archival copy, there isn't any good reason
to tar to a file.  Instead you can do the tar-to-tar trick (check the
archives) or use rsync.

From edasher at javelin.net  Sun Jul 27 15:34:01 2003
From: edasher at javelin.net (Erik)
Date: Sun Jul 27 15:34:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] KVM switch
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0307270746340.21955@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <000101c3548f$1d702090$641010ac@lemonhead>

Rich,

I've used Linksys (two different models), Cybex, BlackBox, Raritan (2 or
3 different models.)

I recommend avoiding unpowered KVMs at all costs.  In my experience,
unpowered KVMs of all brands are less stable then the powered KVMs.

My two cents.  Hope that helps.
Erik.

From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Sun Jul 27 16:08:01 2003
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Sun Jul 27 16:08:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] KVM switch
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0307270746340.21955@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0307271557560.1213-100000@joan.burling.com>

On Sun, 27 Jul 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   As I set up my new workstation/server I want to use the same keyboard,
> monitor and mouse with it and the old box. There seem to be quite a few
> brands available for these switches.
>
>   Does anyone have experience with them and can provide thoughts on what to
> get or what to avoid?
>
Where I'm currently working, we use a fair number of KVM boxes made by
Cybex & others connected to flat screen monitors. Which combination has
produced an interesting problem:

Take machine connected to a KVM box, boot from either a RedHat install
CD or a Knoppix CD, & watch the system go thru the usual messages as the
OS starts. Until the booting comes to starting the X server, when an
error message stating that the server can't start, at which point everything
shuts down.

I've seen it twice, & both times pulling the KVM out of the setup solves
the problem. I admit I haven't researched this issue (except to suspect it
lies with some bug in XFree, rather than either distro or the window
manager), but it *is* something to be aware of.

And, no, Windows in the same hardware configuration has no problems.

I'm not fishing for a solution for this problem, but would be happy to
help in troubleshooting this odd problem.

Geoff




From josh at emediatedesigns.com  Sun Jul 27 16:13:02 2003
From: josh at emediatedesigns.com (Josh Orchard)
Date: Sun Jul 27 16:13:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] KVM switch
Message-ID: <2703.216.99.218.67.1059347547.squirrel@sautez.com>

> On Sun, 27 Jul 2003, Russell Senior wrote:
>
>> Unless you want to save an archival copy, there isn't any good reason
>> to tar to a file.  Instead you can do the tar-to-tar trick (check the
>> archives) or use rsync.
>
>   Thanks, Russell. I need to read up on rsync as I believe that's the
> tool.
> For archival purposes I have the tape backups.
>
> Rich

Rich,

Here is the simple command I use to backup on the same machine.

rsync --archive --verbose /etc /drive2/backup

That backs up the /etc dir to my second drive in the same machine.  But I
use the same command across SSH.

Josh



From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Jul 28 09:31:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)

Subject: [PLUG] pcmcia NIC problem solved!

  Well! I just learned a useful lesson. The Zonet pcmcia card I bought is a
32-bit version. Apparently, the ThinkPad 600E needs a 16-bit card. My 3Com
worked because it's 16-bits. I just ordered another 3Com and it will be here
Wednesday.

Live 'n' learn,

Rich

From aaron at speakeasy.org  Mon Jul 28 10:02:02 2003
From: aaron at speakeasy.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Mon Jul 28 10:02:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Driver for FA-330?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0307271154190.21955@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0307280938160.13377-100000@aluminum.bavariati.org>

On Sun, 27 Jul 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:
<snip>
>   I've not yet fired up the box; just put it together yesterday. My FA-310
> cards use the tulip driver and I'm trying to find out about the 331.

Did some looking (I like detective work.)  FA331 appears to be an OEM
version of the FA311; from the signs and portents, I'm guessing the FA330
is the low-profile version.

The one FA331 driver I found was for some sort of National chipset.  The
FA311 is based on the DP83815, which uses Linux's "natsemi" driver.

> According to Ed's post, Slackware-9.0 does not have a good implementation of
> the tulip driver. Or, something else that causes problems.

I'd guess the second; recent kernels have decent Tulip drivers IIRC.

>   After fighting for several days with a Zonet pcmcia NIC, I just want stuff
> that works. What I "save" on product purchase I lose many times over in
> futzing with the machine trying to get it to work.

Ayuh.  Even if you have the particular skillset available, it's rarely
worth it.  At my last job, I couldn't believe how much time and hassle it
cost us when a vendor changed network or SCSI boards on us.

Since hardware expert was one of the hats I wore, I put a lot of effort
into vetting purchase orders--at least until Purchasing got tired of
having an extra, cantankerous link in the chain.  After that, I had to
support whatever came in, which was much less hassle for them. ;)

                -----------------------------------

So, in other words, use the "natsemi" driver.

BTW, it *really* helps if you provide info on the big chip(s) on the
board and/or lspci output.




From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Mon Jul 28 10:06:01 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Mon Jul 28 10:06:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] pcmcia NIC problem solved!
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0307280924200.25578@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0307280924200.25578@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1059411755.10064.361.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Mon, 2003-07-28 at 09:30, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   Well! I just learned a useful lesson. The Zonet pcmcia card I bought is a
> 32-bit version. Apparently, the ThinkPad 600E needs a 16-bit card. My 3Com
> worked because it's 16-bits. I just ordered another 3Com and it will be here
> Wednesday.
> 
> Live 'n' learn,

Yes, there's a difference between "PCMCIA" and "PC Card" slots, being 16
and 32, respectively.  PC Card slots are backwards compatible, AFAICT,
with PCMCIA.

Wil

Wil wrote regarding VNC:

> Except it won't let you get into the BIOS or boot loader.

I think a firmware-based serial console would give access to the BIOS
and boot loader, but normal home PCs don't have this so the serial
console has to be started by lilo or grub, and the BIOS is still
inaccessible...

> 
> I think a firmware-based serial console would give access to the BIOS
> and boot loader, but normal home PCs don't have this so the serial
> console has to be started by lilo or grub, and the BIOS is still
> inaccessible...

That's certainly possible, but serial consoles only come stock on
embedded boards and server boards.

Wil

From guy1656 at ados.com  Mon Jul 28 17:26:01 2003
From: guy1656 at ados.com (guy1656)
Date: Mon Jul 28 17:26:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Should be a TRIVIAL fix ...
Message-ID: <200307281024.47526.guy1656@ados.com>

Greetings:

I am running Mandrake 9.0

Trying to get an IOmega external zip drive to work again.
It USED to work, but no longer does.
I USED to mount it with the command mount mnt/zip1/
(returns guff*) then mount mnt/zip/

and I could use the drive. When this didn't work, I was told to try
rmmod usb-storage
modprobe usb-storage

and that was cool, because it worked.

Then it stopped working.

I had a Linux consultant come over, and after THREE & A HALF HOURS,
he had the following comments:

- Having problem accessing zip250 usb drive.
- System finds drive in /proc/bus/usb
- Raw contents exist at /dev/scsi/host0/bus0/target0/lun0/disc
- /log/messages finds drive at /dev/sda
- attempting to mount drive returns "too many file systems open" or
"not a block device" errors
- Downloaded iomega tool (iw) and it returns similar errors
- I can't find anything obviously wrong, but can't mount drive....

Any other hints? 

- GLL

From drl at drloree.com  Mon Jul 28 18:13:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Mon Jul 28 18:13:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Should be a TRIVIAL fix ...
In-Reply-To: <200307281024.47526.guy1656@ados.com>
References: <200307281024.47526.guy1656@ados.com>
Message-ID: <1059441588.567.36.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Mon, 2003-07-28 at 10:24, guy1656 wrote:
> Greetings:
> 
> I am running Mandrake 9.0
> 
> Trying to get an IOmega external zip drive to work again.
> It USED to work, but no longer does.
> I USED to mount it with the command mount mnt/zip1/
> (returns guff*) then mount mnt/zip/
> 
> and I could use the drive. When this didn't work, I was told to try
> rmmod usb-storage
> modprobe usb-storage
> 
> and that was cool, because it worked.
> 
> Then it stopped working.
> 
> I had a Linux consultant come over, and after THREE & A HALF HOURS,
> he had the following comments:
> 
> - Having problem accessing zip250 usb drive.
> - System finds drive in /proc/bus/usb
> - Raw contents exist at /dev/scsi/host0/bus0/target0/lun0/disc
> - /log/messages finds drive at /dev/sda

This is good, any partition information?

Was fdisk able to display any partition information on /dev/sda?

> - attempting to mount drive returns "too many file systems open" or
> "not a block device" errors

What exactly did you try to mount? I believe that the stock formated zip
drives mount as /dev/sda4, even though there is only one partition.

> - Downloaded iomega tool (iw) and it returns similar errors
> - I can't find anything obviously wrong, but can't mount drive....

The drive may have lost its partition table, think of it more as a funny
hard drive, than as a funny floppy drive; it has to have at least one
partition for it to be accessed correctly.  Why the manufacturer choose
to have the one partition read as partition 4 is beyond me.  IIRC, both
Winblowz and Linux don't care what the partition number is, so you
should be able to set it to the first partition without any problems.

HTH

Derek Loree





From stevea at nwtechops.com  Mon Jul 28 18:33:02 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Mon Jul 28 18:33:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Error opening or locking INBOX
In-Reply-To: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCEEEBCOAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
References: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCEEEBCOAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <1059442313.1375.64.camel@main>

On Mon, 2003-07-28 at 17:39, Billy Dimaculangan wrote:
> i'm encountering "Error opening or locking INBOX" in our maillog. email
> users cannot access their inbox from their windows machine.  what i'm doing
> is quickly remove their account and add it back.  my question is why is this
> happening in some of our users?  does removing and adding it back again the
> solution for this problem?
> 

Removing and adding back the user probably equates to changing the UID
for that user. Check the permissions on the effected users home and/or
mail directory and make sure that the user in question still owns it.
When you recreate users you should use the -u option in useradd to make
sure that the UID remains the same for the new user.

From kgmorse at mpcu.com  Mon Jul 28 22:13:02 2003
From: kgmorse at mpcu.com (Keith Morse)
Date: Mon Jul 28 22:13:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] KVM switch
In-Reply-To: <1059453107.2928.3.camel@sthelens.dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0307282215270.20735-100000@antares.mpcu.com>

On 28 Jul 2003, Russ Johnson wrote:

> On Sun, 2003-07-27 at 13:03, Tyler Creelan wrote:
> > Rich Shepard wrote:
> > 
> > >   Thanks, Robby. This shares keyboard and rodent but each machine
> > >   requires its own monitor. I don't have the room for that, either.
> > 
> > Just curious - what's the advantage of a KVM versus SSHing into the
> > second box, with serial console as backup in case the network fails? 
> 
> Ever tried to configure the BIOs on an X86 system headless?
> 
> This is one area that Sun got right. You can access everything via
> serial console, including NRAM settings. 


Watching this debate with interest and first time I've seen my concerns 
asked.  The remote management/use of a host beit VNC, ssh, X, and others 
(which I all use) doesn't address the issue of booting the pc.  Most 
bios's I'm aware don't support operation without a keyboard and stop the 
boot process if one is not found.  Yes, there are some but they seem to  
be the exception.  An item like a "keyboard loopback plug" seem to 
non-existent.  


I agree, Sun got right. OpenBoot is a nifty environment.  I've heard some 
rumblings about using Linux as a base for smart bios, serial interface 
included.  Hmmm, I'll have to search for that again.

The upshod is that most Intel computers require a keyboard to boot 
successfully.  A KVM alleviates a cacophony of keyboards in a small area.




From josh at emediatedesigns.com  Mon Jul 28 22:37:01 2003
From: josh at emediatedesigns.com (Josh Orchard)
Date: Mon Jul 28 22:37:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] KVM switch
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0307282215270.20735-100000@antares.mpcu.com>
References: <1059453107.2928.3.camel@sthelens.dimstar.net>
    <Pine.LNX.4.44.0307282215270.20735-100000@antares.mpcu.com>
Message-ID: <2232.216.99.218.67.1059456947.squirrel@sautez.com>

....
>  Most
> bios's I'm aware don't support operation without a keyboard and stop the
> boot process if one is not found.  Yes, there are some but they seem to
> be the exception.  An item like a "keyboard loopback plug" seem to
> non-existent.
....
> The upshod is that most Intel computers require a keyboard to boot
> successfully.  A KVM alleviates a cacophony of keyboards in a small area.

If you go into many modern bios you can tell it not to halt of any errors.
 The keyboard and mouse are considered errors.  Just tell it not to halt
on Keyboard error.  I have a headless/mouseless/keyboardless linux box
that I use and remote boot all the time.  I just had to tell the bios not
to halt on errors.

Still can't play with the bios settings and boot stuff but usually don't
need that.

Josh

a wiki? Sort of a paper napkin blueprint tool? Ideally it would let

choose from some patterns to 'stamp' onto the drawing, for instance,

I've been looking around and I've found some simple Java and
Javascript programs that are close, so I figure someone must have
done this already.

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Tue Jul 29 07:03:02 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Tue Jul 29 07:03:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Should be a TRIVIAL fix ...
In-Reply-To: <200307290641.35211.guy1656@ados.com>
Message-ID: <29520-81435@sneakemail.com>

On Tue, 29 Jul 2003, guy1656 guy1656-at-ados.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> : This is good, any partition information?
> : Was fdisk able to display any partition information on /dev/sda?
> 
> The consultant is gone now, how do I do that?

"fdisk -l /dev/sda", as root.  This lists the partitions on /dev/sda.

You may find this background information helpful to understand what's
going on with partitions:

http://www.pcguide.com/ref/hdd/file/struct_Boot.htm

  -- Steve





From aaron at speakeasy.org  Tue Jul 29 07:54:01 2003
From: aaron at speakeasy.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Tue Jul 29 07:54:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] KVM switch
In-Reply-To: <1059458906.17675.20555.camel@obelisk.spek.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0307290742030.32608-100000@aluminum.bavariati.org>

On 28 Jul 2003, Brent Rieck wrote:
> > This is one area that Sun got right. You can access everything via
> > serial console, including NRAM settings.
>
> Has anybody used a Serverworks chipset MB?  I've never seen one (I've
> never had the need for a serial console either, I leave the serious
> sysadmin stuff to others) but I've heard they do a decent job of a
> serial console.

Only if the motherboard maker paid for the feature.  F'r instance, the
ASUS CUR-DLS used in the VA1220s didn't come with it, but the
near-identical CUR-DLSR did.  IIRC it was more-or-less possible to do BIOS
setup, but the Mylex cards used an Alt- sequence to go into RAID setup,
which didn't work via serial console.

It may seem like a funny thing to skimp on, but these guys are dealing
with teeny, tiny margins.

Dell's serial console support on the PE2650s is pretty nice, but it only
works at 9600 baud.  I was pretty impressed with SuperMicro's serial
console redirect, but it didn't support 38400 baud, which is what we used.


Wish they'd just used OpenFirmware,
  Aaron

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Tue Jul 29 11:03:01 2003
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler Creelan)
Date: Tue Jul 29 11:03:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Reply-To header for each list?
Message-ID: <20030729180248.GA28596@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Under Mutt I'd like to include with each message I send to a list a
Reply-To directing responses back to the list. For example, I would
specify a certain set of lists: 

user at debian.org
lkml at linux.com
foo-users at bar.com

and every message I post to lkml would contain "Reply-To:
lkml at linux.com". 

Under pine I would use "Roles" for this; what is the equivalent feature
under Mutt?

Thx!

Tyler

PS. On lists that don't use Reply-To munging, message responses are
frequently addressed (by accident or design) both to the original poster
and the list. With Mutt, this behavior is controlled via the Followup-To
header, which works well assuming everyone uses Mutt. And in general duplicate
messages are handled trivially under procmail. I'm just curious about trying this...



From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Tue Jul 29 12:58:02 2003
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler Creelan)
Date: Tue Jul 29 12:58:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] PADNUG Meeting - Thursday 7/31
Message-ID: <20030729195709.GA29823@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Hi everyone -
  
The Portland Area .NET User's Group (PADNUG) is meeting this Thursday,
7/31. Anyone with an interest in .NET or Mono programming is welcome to
attend, although (warning!) most participants come from a windows
background.
 
Networking and free pizza starts at 6:00pm. The meeting begins at 6:30
with group announcements, immediately followed by the featured
speaker's presentation. This month's presentation is on user interface 
design under the .NET framework, hosted by Phil Weber.
 
PADNUG meetings are free and open to the public. For more information
on future meetings and joining the PADNUG mailing list see
http://www.padnug.org.
  
  Presentation:   Create Great .NET User Interfaces
  Time:           6:30pm, 7/31/2003
  Place:          Step Technology 6915 SW Macadam, Suite 200, Portland OR
  Directions: http://www.steptech.com/aboutus/map.asp?navarea=contactus

  Description:

  Even the most beautifully coded application will flop if people hate
  to use it. And they will, if its user interface is not designed with
  their goals in mind. What makes a great UI? How can you apply the
  principles that work so well for the guts of an application to its
  front end?

  We'll show you specific techniques (with code!) that you can use
  immediately to reduce complexity for your users and improve your
  presentation layer's efficiency and maintainability."
  
  More Information:
  
  http://www.padnug.org

-TFC
  
--------------------------
Tyler Creelan
Dept. Computer Science
Oregon State University

>

Didn't try fdisk.  The partition info seems to be intact since it was
possible to access the drive using vmware/win2k.  This also indicates
that the hardware and disk are working and properly formatted.

> > - attempting to mount drive returns "too many file systems open" or
> > "not a block device" errors
>
> What exactly did you try to mount? I believe that the stock formated zip
> drives mount as /dev/sda4, even though there is only one partition.

I did trying mounting both sda and sda4.  I fact, since I've gotten
tricked by similar situations with other media, I tried mounting all
possible variations - sda1, sda2, sda3, sda4, sda5, etc.  All returned
"not a block device" errors except sda, which returned "too many open
file systems or bad superblock" errors.

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Jul 29 21:36:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue Jul 29 21:36:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] KVM switch
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0307282215270.20735-100000@antares.mpcu.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0307282215270.20735-100000@antares.mpcu.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0307292127340.14773@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Mon, 28 Jul 2003, Keith Morse wrote:
> Watching this debate with interest and first time I've seen my concerns
> asked.  The remote management/use of a host beit VNC, ssh, X, and others
> (which I all use) doesn't address the issue of booting the pc.  Most
> bios's I'm aware don't support operation without a keyboard and stop the
> boot process if one is not found.  Yes, there are some but they seem to
> be the exception.  An item like a "keyboard loopback plug" seem to
> non-existent.

I'm totally confused here.

What kind of hardware are you guys BUYING?

I think the only system I've EVER had that wouldn't boot without a
keyboard was a cheap ass Dell that I found in a dumpster and which I
tossed after a few months because of proprietary hardware issues across
the board.

I have many makes and models of motherboard from the past to the present
(OK, I haven't bought a NEW motherboard in just over a year) and they all
seem perfectly happy to boot headless.

I do have a friend whose mother's floppyfw box can't boot without a
keyboard, but it runs fine when the keyboard's unplugged, so she knows to
plug one in if she ever has to turn the thing off.  It's a hassle, but
I can't think of any other examples of that problem in the real world.

> I agree, Sun got right. OpenBoot is a nifty environment.  I've heard
> some rumblings about using Linux as a base for smart bios, serial
> interface included.  Hmmm, I'll have to search for that again.

Firm-ware, O-pen firmware.
It's appropriate techno-lo-geeeeee...

(Does anyone else remember the Open Firmware song?)

Yeah, it's good stuff.  Apple's using it now, too, aren't they?

I also remember someone (the name coyote comes to mind) selling an ISA
card that would output just about any x86 bios to a serial port and then
the card acted as a regular serial card when booted.  Pretty nifty.  I
remember it being ungodly expensive.

> The upshod is that most Intel computers require a keyboard to boot
> successfully.  A KVM alleviates a cacophony of keyboards in a small
> area.

jbrelin at shaft:~/News$ grep upsho /usr/share/dict/words
upshot
upshots

But anyway, I'm totally shocked that anyone has this problem in the modern
age.  I have a KVM switch (a fancy digital NTI box that somehow ended up
at my house) but it's only attached to two machines out of the five or six
on my rack here.  I keep it so that I can switch to something when my
workstation isn't doing what it should and I really need to read mail or
something.  I'd recommend this brand to anyone that has heaps of money to
spare.  They're great, but not priced for the home.

J.

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Jul 29 21:38:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue Jul 29 21:38:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Reply-To header for each list?
In-Reply-To: <20030729180248.GA28596@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
References: <20030729180248.GA28596@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0307292137100.14773@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Tue, 29 Jul 2003, Tyler Creelan wrote:
> Under Mutt I'd like to include with each message I send to a list a
> Reply-To directing responses back to the list. For example, I would
> specify a certain set of lists:
>
> user at debian.org
> lkml at linux.com
> foo-users at bar.com
>
> and every message I post to lkml would contain "Reply-To:
> lkml at linux.com".
>
> Under pine I would use "Roles" for this; what is the equivalent feature
> under Mutt?

You probably want some fancy combination of folder hooks and aliases.

> PS. On lists that don't use Reply-To munging, message responses are
> frequently addressed (by accident or design) both to the original poster
> and the list. With Mutt, this behavior is controlled via the Followup-To
> header, which works well assuming everyone uses Mutt. And in general
> duplicate messages are handled trivially under procmail. I'm just
> curious about trying this...

So you want to punish the conscientous to accomodate the lazy?

If somebody does the RIGHT thing with their mail (i.e., uses the common
"reply to all" function of their MUA and edits the recipient list
appropriately), you're going to make it very hard for them to reply only
to you.

Educate, don't accomodate.
J.

---------- Forwarded message ----------

   Trade Practices Act Is Basis for Australian Complaint Against SCO:
   http://www.linuxjournal.com/article.php?sid=7037 -- Making claims and
   trying to make people pay before the claims have been proven might
   be--what's the word--illegal. In Australia, it's definitely counter to
   the country's Trade Practices Act, and Linux users are invoking it to
   prevent SCO from making people pay to use Linux.

   Interview with Brian Kernighan:
   http://www.linuxjournal.com/article.php?sid=7035 -- Aleksey Dolya
   spoke with Brian Kernighan, one of the people behind AWK and AMPL,
   about his days at Bell Labs and his new gig at Princeton University.

   Large Scale Samba Installations:
   http://www.linuxjournal.com/article.php?sid=6604 -- David Lechnyr
   wrote a howto for setting up different scenarios integrating Samba
   with Windows 2000 and XP, including a Windows 2000/XP non-domain
   member accessing Samba domain and tunneling SMB with SSH.



From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Jul 30 08:21:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed Jul 30 08:21:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Creating XML records
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0307300814210.322@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  I'm slowly moving my reference library database to XML. Even with emac's
tag completion capabilities it's a slow, painful process to set up the
complete set of tags for each book and journal article. It would be much
more efficient if I had a form with all tags present and I could repeatedly
fill in a blank copy for each record.

  The kludgy way of doing this is to create a file with all tags and
constantly import it for each record. There must be a better way but I've
not yet found it. I think the ideal solution would be a stylesheet with all
the tags to be filled in. Then, when I did a search on the indexed records,
each one could be displayed in its own little window.

  Does anyone know of something like this? If not, what sort of search
phrase would you suggest I use on google, sourceforge or freshmeat?

TIA,

Rich

From ptkwt at aracnet.com  Wed Jul 30 08:50:02 2003
From: ptkwt at aracnet.com (Phil Tomson)
Date: Wed Jul 30 08:50:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Slightly OT:  PCC software engineering program
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0307300220150.13458-100000@ns1.billmercer.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0307300837000.18956-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>


On Wed, 30 Jul 2003, Bill wrote:

> Anybody have any experience with PCC's software engineering program, or
> graduates thereof?  I'm looking for a relatively short-term way to move up
> the foodchain a bit and get into more interesting work.  I have decent
> computer skills at the moment, but can't get work in the field (especially
> any sort of work I'd want; call center bull#$%^ doesn't appeal to me
> much).
>

People with Master's degrees from reputable universities are having
trouble getting work at this point.  I honestly don't think that  a PCC
degree (or certificate or whatever it is) is going to help you at all in
this market (especially if you don't already have a good bit of software
engineering experience).  Things _might_ change in a couple of
years, however, I doubt it will ever be like it was in the late 90's when,
if you had a Community College certificate in Software Engineering you
could get several offers.... those days are gone forever.

I'd recommend that if you want to get into Software Engineering that you
be able to go without food for long periods of time and that you
have a tent to live in ... ;-)  Actually, if you _really_ want to get
into sofware engineering be aware that many of those jobs are going to be
outsourced to India or China in the next few years, so you have to find a
niche area that will be less likely to be outsourced.  My advice:
BioInformatics (Oh, they'll be able to outsource those jobs too, but it'll
take a bit longer before that starts).  OHSU/OGI apparently has a
BioInformatics program starting.

Phil

From drl at drloree.com  Wed Jul 30 10:55:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Wed Jul 30 10:55:02 2003
Subject: Fwd: Re: [PLUG] Should be a TRIVIAL fix ...
In-Reply-To: <200307291435.29875.guy1656@ados.com>
References: <200307291435.29875.guy1656@ados.com>
Message-ID: <1059588127.572.15.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Tue, 2003-07-29 at 14:35, guy1656 wrote:
> [snip]
> > > - Having problem accessing zip250 usb drive.
> > > - System finds drive in /proc/bus/usb
> > > - Raw contents exist at /dev/scsi/host0/bus0/target0/lun0/disc
> > > - /log/messages finds drive at /dev/sda
[snip]
> Didn't try fdisk.  The partition info seems to be intact since it was
> possible to access the drive using vmware/win2k.  This also indicates
> that the hardware and disk are working and properly formatted.
[snip]
> I did trying mounting both sda and sda4.  I fact, since I've gotten
> tricked by similar situations with other media, I tried mounting all
> possible variations - sda1, sda2, sda3, sda4, sda5, etc.  All returned
> "not a block device" errors except sda, which returned "too many open
> file systems or bad superblock" errors.

A list of files inside /dev/scsi/host0/bus0/target0/lun0/ should show
the parts of the disk that devfs has found.  If devfs isn't creating the
symlinks, you may have to mount the partition in its long form, for
example:

mount -t vfat /dev/scsi/host0/bus0/target0/lun0/part4 /mnt/zip

But if it doesn't exist, it won't mount it.

HTH,

Derek Loree




From kgmorse at mpcu.com  Wed Jul 30 11:07:01 2003
From: kgmorse at mpcu.com (Keith Morse)
Date: Wed Jul 30 11:07:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] KVM switch
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0307292127340.14773@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0307301127030.15375-100000@antares.mpcu.com>

On Tue, 29 Jul 2003, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

> 
> On Mon, 28 Jul 2003, Keith Morse wrote:

From kyle at silverbeach.net  Wed Jul 30 12:07:02 2003
From: kyle at silverbeach.net (Kyle Hayes)
Date: Wed Jul 30 12:07:02 2003
Subject: OT Re: [PLUG] KVM switch - spelling
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0307301157111.693@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0307292127340.14773@shaft.bitmine.net> <200307301151.50370.pluglist@bratgrrl.com> <Pine.LNX.4.56.0307301157111.693@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200307301203.13409.kyle@silverbeach.net>

On Wednesday 30 July 2003 11:58, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Wed, 30 Jul 2003, Carla Schroder wrote:
> > Oh dang, I thought pinging the boss meant bouncing a stapler or metal
> > ruler off his or her head....because of the sound it makes...
>
>   And I thought it was the high-tech equivalent of plinking -- as in empty
> cans with a .22.

I used to work with a guy that had been in the US Navy submarine fleet and 
spent considerable time in subs.  We talked about this one and he thought 
that it had actually originated with sonar operators back in the '60s.  Up 
until then, I had always assumed that it came from the "ping" utility (and 
subsequent new verb meaning).

I guess when you're underwater for months at a time, you come up with some 
interesting things to think about.  The friend had some interesting phrases 
and sayings based on "ping" that I've never heard anywhere else.

Best,
Kyle

From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Jul 30 12:28:01 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Wed Jul 30 12:28:01 2003
Subject: OT Re: [PLUG] KVM switch - spelling
In-Reply-To: <200307301203.13409.kyle@silverbeach.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0307292127340.14773@shaft.bitmine.net>
 <200307301151.50370.pluglist@bratgrrl.com> <Pine.LNX.4.56.0307301157111.693@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
 <200307301203.13409.kyle@silverbeach.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0307301226270.26565@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Wed, 30 Jul 2003, Kyle Hayes wrote:
> I used to work with a guy that had been in the US Navy submarine fleet
> and spent considerable time in subs.  We talked about this one and he
> thought that it had actually originated with sonar operators back in the
> '60s.  Up until then, I had always assumed that it came from the "ping"
> utility (and subsequent new verb meaning).

I always thought ping was a very apt analogy and the origin was obvious to
me.

You send out a ping and listen for it to come back.  The time it takes is
a good measure of the distance if you know what kind of connection you
have (density of the medium between you both) or a good measure of the
kind of connection you have if you know the distance.

"Verify range to target.  One ping only."
   -- The Hunt For Red October

> I guess when you're underwater for months at a time, you come up with
> some interesting things to think about.  The friend had some interesting
> phrases and sayings based on "ping" that I've never heard anywhere else.

Those I'd like to see.

J.

:   If devfs isn't creating the
: symlinks, you may have to mount the partition in its long form, for
: example:

> : mount -t vfat /dev/scsi/host0/bus0/target0/lun0/part4 /mnt/zip
>
> HOORAY !! It Worked!!
> Mongo thanks!
>
> Now, so far, I have to be root to do this. Any way to allow my 'regular'
> user to mount that?

This seems like a disadvantage of devfs (which I've never used, so please
take that as a "educate me" type comment).  That is to say, I've become
pretty accustomed to changing permissions and ownership on my devices to
suit the needs of the system.  How's that done in devfs?

Oh, and Guy... if there is a group that has rw permissions on the device
listed above (/dev/scsi...lun0/part4), then add the users that need to
mount and umount the sucker to that group.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Wed Jul 30 16:51:02 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Wed Jul 30 16:51:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] .midi player for Linux
In-Reply-To: <20030730221336.83324.qmail@web9602.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20030730221336.83324.qmail@web9602.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <86adav3777.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Robert" == Robert Kopp <iconoklastic at yahoo.com> writes:

Robert> Much of the streaming music on the Web is in .midi format, and
Robert> I don't seem to have a player for it. I am not too familiar
Robert> with the available software for it, but have not succeeded in
Robert> installing it, in any case.  Does anyone have recommendations?

Some audio cards do sequencing for you, but if yours (or its currently
available drivers) doesn't, then you can use Timidity.  I got mine
from debian.  Not sure where the canonical site is.  What looks like
it (judging by google) appears to be off the air at the moment.

You might try here:

   <http://timidity.sourceforge.net/index.html.en>

Russell Senior         ``shtal latta wos ba padre u prett tu nashtonfi

Keith,

I just find it alarming that the world or business is using technical
words or programs to describe human actions. Before someone would have
said. "After the meeting I'll discuss this with my boss for her opinion"

Now "I'll ping my boss after we are offline"

Terminology like that bothers me.  Not really sure why but I guess to
makes them appear uneducated.  And this is from PhD's and otherwise
intelligent people

Josh



From jschwaber at wesleyan.edu  Wed Jul 30 21:39:02 2003
From: jschwaber at wesleyan.edu (Jeff Schwaber)
Date: Wed Jul 30 21:39:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] IMP webmail
In-Reply-To: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCKEGICOAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
References: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCKEGICOAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <1059600555.5898.24.camel@zadie>

On Thu, 2003-07-31 at 00:53, Billy Dimaculangan wrote:
> we're using IMP(horde) for remote mail access, but whenever we send mail
> from this webmail the from filed appears to myuser at localhost.mydomain.com.
> what am i missing?

I dunno, cause I gave up on setting up IMP after I started getting
errors in PHP libraries, but may I suggest:

cd /path/to/imp/installation
egrep -r "myuser at localhost.mydomain.com" .

If that doesn't turn up anything, is it possible /etc/hosts has
localhost.mydomain.com in it? Then you could just search for myuser

in fact, I emend that to say

egrep -r "myuser" . | less

Jeff

From russj at dimstar.net  Wed Jul 30 23:20:03 2003
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Wed Jul 30 23:20:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] KVM switch - spelling
In-Reply-To: <4384.216.99.218.67.1059625240.squirrel@sautez.com>
References: <1258.134.244.174.93.1059589942.squirrel@sautez.com>    <Pine.LNX.4.44.0307301821170.23047-100000@antares.mpcu.com> <4384.216.99.218.67.1059625240.squirrel@sautez.com>
Message-ID: <3F28B4F4.8020307@dimstar.net>

Keep in mind that I've refrained for hours in replying to this WAY OFF 
TOPIC thread. :)

Josh Orchard wrote:

>Before someone would have
>said. "After the meeting I'll discuss this with my boss for her opinion"
>
>Now "I'll ping my boss after we are offline"
>
>Terminology like that bothers me.  Not really sure why but I guess to
>makes them appear uneducated.  And this is from PhD's and otherwise
>intelligent people
>
Why? It's more concise, it conveys the same message, and English is an 
evolving language.

My pet peeve is contractions that cause redundancy.

Such as the ever popular "You've got mail." When this "simple" sentance 
is expanded, you have "You have got mail". I was taught that this is 
improper. "You got mail" is also wrong. In addition, it just doesn't 
sound right if you say, "You've mail." So, my English Professor would 
have said that the proper form of this sentence would be, "You have mail".

But then I look at what I wrote you in response to your "bother". Why 
does this bother me? It still conveys the same message. English is an 
evolving language.

On and on and on and on.

Yada yada yada.

-- 

Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

From guy1656 at ados.com  Thu Jul 31 06:48:02 2003
From: guy1656 at ados.com (guy1656)
Date: Thu Jul 31 06:48:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OT - On-line
In-Reply-To: <2044.216.99.218.67.1059640433.squirrel@sautez.com>
References: <1258.134.244.174.93.1059589942.squirrel@sautez.com> <3F28B4F4.8020307@dimstar.net> <2044.216.99.218.67.1059640433.squirrel@sautez.com>
Message-ID: <200307310646.24428.guy1656@ados.com>

: say discuss, talk about, address, or consult makes no sense.  Maybe I'm
:  I'm supposed to think I
: was ever 'online'?  I was on the phone.  When did the phone conversation
: constitute being online?

My lesiure reading is taking me through a bunch of machinist's and jobb 
shopper's autobiographical anecdotes. The earliest use I saw of 'online' went 
back to the "line shaft." Mills of the 1880's, be they waterpower or steam, 
would often build in one or powered shaft running the length of the shop 
floor or assembly line. All the machines, such as drill presses, lathes, and 
trip hammers, drew their rotational power from leather belts leading down 
from pulleys mounted along the line shaft. 

Although I haven't seen 'off line' used for a machine stopped (such as for 
repair or adjustment) by throwing off its belt, I have seen 'on line' (two 
words) used for operating machines connected to the line shaft.

Nasty thing to remember was that safety glasses were seen as a wussy 
exception, and most people worked in collared shirts and ties around all 
these unguarded spindles and pinching hazards.
OSHA hadn't been invented yet...

GLL



From russj at dimstar.net  Thu Jul 31 09:55:02 2003
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Thu Jul 31 09:55:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] KVM switch - spelling
In-Reply-To: <2044.216.99.218.67.1059640433.squirrel@sautez.com>
References: <1258.134.244.174.93.1059589942.squirrel@sautez.com>       <Pine.LNX.4.44.0307301821170.23047-100000@antares.mpcu.com>    <4384.216.99.218.67.1059625240.squirrel@sautez.com>    <3F28B4F4.8020307@dimstar.net> <2044.216.99.218.67.1059640433.squirrel@sautez.com>
Message-ID: <3F2949D3.3010302@dimstar.net>

Josh Orchard wrote:

> True, English is an evolving language but the use of 'ping' to determine
> distance in all prior cases makes more sense.

You are correct in this, IMHO.

> But to use it as a way to
> say discuss, talk about, address, or consult makes no sense.  Maybe I'm
> missing something.

Well, to discuss something, at least in this context, is to find out how 
far away your idea is from mine. So the ping analogy holds.

I often throught of it as the sound. "I'll ping my boss." Could be 
throwing a lead pipe at him to hear the "PING!!!" as it bounces off his 
head... :) Of course, I have no way to measure the length of time it 
takes for the pipe to travel, or for the ping to return... But I'm going 
off the deep end again.

> As is the use of 'offline'.  I'm suppose to think I
> was ever 'online'?  I was on the phone.  When did the phone conversation
> constitute being online?

With a modem?

In my mind, a muddled place if there ever was one, "online" refers to 
any conversation, in person or not. While the conversation is ongoing, 
you are "online". I've heard (for years) when a topic goes down a 
rathole in a meeting, "We'll take this up offline." Referring to after 
the meeting.

> Going offline for a while, (time to sleep)

Perfect. :)

From miken at hotsushi.com  Thu Jul 31 10:50:02 2003
From: miken at hotsushi.com (Mike Neal)
Date: Thu Jul 31 10:50:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] fwd: OSDL - SCO - Linux Position Paper
Message-ID: <4.3.1.0.20030731105008.00b83228@www.hotsushi.com>

On July 24, 2003 Prof. Eden Moglen of Columbia Law School and General
Council of the Free Software Foundation, addressed OSDL's Linux User
Advisory Council. His presentation was an analysis of SCO's threat to
require end users to buy a license to use Linux. Prof. Moglen has
summarized his talk in a position paper that OSDL has published.
This paper can be found at the following link:

http://www.osdl.org/docs/osdl_eben_moglen_position_paper.pdf

This paper is entitled Questioning SCO: A Hard Look at Nebulous Claims.
It is designed to help readers understand the legal basis - or lack
thereof - of SCO's action. It also provides some questions they should
ask themselves and their legal council regarding the legal exposure
- or lack thereof -they face by continuing to use Linux. We think
you'll find this interesting reading.
Please pass this note along to anyone you believe should see it.
Thanks,
Tim

Timothy D. Witham - Lab Director - wookie at osdlab.org
Open Source Development Lab Inc - A non-profit corporation

On Thu, 2003-07-31 at 01:33, Josh Orchard wrote:

> 
> True, English is an evolving language but the use of 'ping' to determine
> distance in all prior cases makes more sense.  

Wxcept, haveing ben around since BEFORE TCP/IP, there is an alternate
derivation of "ping" which is one half on the pair "ping-pong"  in cases
where ICMP was not inplace one would write a pair of programs, ping and
pong, pong being a responder for ping.  This was usially (as is often
still the case) simply for testing conectivity.

From kgmorse at mpcu.com  Thu Jul 31 17:33:02 2003
From: kgmorse at mpcu.com (Keith Morse)
Date: Thu Jul 31 17:33:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] The "mail" comand and searching the list archives.
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0307311747190.10786-100000@antares.mpcu.com>


I thought I saw on this list how to redirect the output of mail's message 
listing but can no longer find reference to it.

Example.  On a host that has the "mail" command, I run it as that user.  
Entering a "?" I get the following.

? ?
?               print this help message
#               display message number #
-               print previous
+               next (no delete)
! cmd           execute cmd
<CR>            next (no delete)
a               position at and read newly arrived mail
d [#]           delete message # (default current message)
dp              delete current message and print the next
dq              delete current message and exit
h a             display all headers
h d             display headers of letters scheduled for deletion
h [#]           display headers around # (default current message)
m user          mail (and delete) current message to user
n               next (no delete)
p               print (override any warnings of binary content)
P               override default 'brief' mode and display ALL header lines
q, ^D           quit
r [args]        reply to (and delete) current letter via mail [args]
s [files]       save (and delete) current message (default mbox)
u [#]           undelete message # (default current message)
w [files]       save (and delete) current message without header
x               exit without changing mail
y [files]       save (and delete) current message (default mbox)
? 


Then doing a header list "h a" I see there a 23 messages.  Reading 
message number 15, the message scrolls by rather quickly.  I thought I saw 
somebody post a sequence like this recently.

. | ! more

to pass the output from mail to a system command such as "more".  But I'll 
be dogged if'n if I can find the right voodoo to make it happens.  Google 
is being onery with me and not honoring quotes resulting hundreds of 
thousands of hits.



Next, is there a preferred method of searching this mail lists archive 
from some type of search engine?  The list archive web page seems to only 
provide access to the archive in web form but no way to specific searches.
